Contador blames food contamination
Three-time Tour de France champion Alberto Contador has claimed he is the victim of contaminated food after testing positive for a banned drug.
The muscle-building and fat-burning drug clenbuterol was detected in his system during this year's Tour.
Contador
column3: the greatest rider of his generation
column4: said that contaminated meat brought in from Spain was responsible for his positive test on 21 July.

column1: It is a clear case of food contamination

column1: A World Anti-Doping Agency-accredited lab in Cologne
column2: Germany
column3: found a ""very small concentration"" of clenbuterol in Contador's urine sample on 21 July at the Tour
column4: according to the UCI.

column1: Spain's Alberto Contador is cycling's biggest star

Please turn on JavaScript. Media requires JavaScript to play.

England's women's hockey team feel the heat in a special chamber that can recreate Delhi's climate.
By Paul Harris
I am gasping the moment I step inside. The air is heavy and the heat intense.
I try to take another step but it is so humid that it feels like the air is resisting me. The camera is faring no better
column2: the lens has steamed up and cannot see a thing.

column1: I'm in a special environmental chamber where they can recreate the heat
column2: humidity and altitude of almost any location in the world. Today the chamber is set to 30 degrees Celsius and 85% humidity to mirror conditions in Delhi where the Commonwealth Games are due to start.

column1: I can't imagine doing anything in these conditions let alone cycling and lifting weights for an hour but that is exactly what the England women's hockey team are here to do.
They have recently returned from the World Cup in Argentina
column2: where they took bronze and need to acclimatise quickly to the conditions in Delhi.

column1: This environmental chamber at the English Institute of Sport's (EIS) high performance centre at Bisham Abbey is the largest non-military chamber in the UK but is still no larger than the temporary buildings you would find on a building site.
Crista Cullen does battle with the Netherlands' Maartje Goderie

There are three hour-long sessions in which the athletes are split into two groups. Half of the group go through a ""robustness"" session which involves waddling around the chamber with a heavy load across the shoulders.
It's not the most elegant sight but they're strengthening the soft tissue around the hip and lower back - the part of the body that hockey taxes the most.
The other half are on the bikes and for 30 minutes they alternate between a minute's worth of high intensity cycling and a minute's rest.
Andy Hudson
column2: EIS's strength and conditioning coach
column3: explains that this is a chance for the athletes' bodies to get used to the Indian climate.

column1: What we're trying to do through this acclimation process is give them the opportunity to experience the elevated heart rate and blood flow that comes hand in hand with the increased heat and pressure and give them an opportunity internally to adapt to the hot environment.""
England are keen to improve on the bronze medal they secured in last month's World Cup and are looking to exploit any advantage they can find.
Mentally
column2: it's making them able to understand what kind of pressures they might be under

column1: Tom Cross
column2: performance pyschologist

column1: It's uncomfortable to do high intensity exercise in this sort of environment and therefore just doing it more frequently ahead of travelling gives them an opportunity to get slightly ahead of the curve
column2: he adds.

column1: It's clear that although the session is designed to maintain the athletes physically
column2: it is as much to do with preparing the team mentally for the conditions that await them.

column1: Athletes often struggle in unfamiliar surroundings because their thoughts interfere with their performance. But this session is part of England's psychological training
column2: which includes visualisation and cognitive behavioural therapy.

column1: Tom Cross
column2: EIS's performance psychologist
column3: explains; ""Mentally
column4: it's making them able to understand what kind of pressures they might be under and how they can keep their thoughts and minds focused on what they need to be focused on
column5: which is playing hockey"".

column1: In elite competition
column2: they say you need a physiotherapist for your body and a psychologist for your mind.

column1: England's hockey team have both and should be prepared to in peak physical and mental condition as they touch down in Delhi.

column2: the three-time winner of the Tour de France
column3: tested positive for a banned substance during this year’s race has sent cycling reeling into yet another doping scandal just as the sport’s reputation appeared to be on the mend.

column1: Related

Alberto Contador won his third Tour de France after a positive drug test on the final rest day.
The best cyclist of his generation
column2: Contador is the sport’s latest star to test positive for a prohibited substance. If the positive result is upheld
column3: he faces a two-year suspension from competition.

column1: Contador insists
column2: however
column3: that his failed drug test for clenbuterol
column4: a banned weight-loss and muscle-building drug
column5: is a huge mistake. At a news conference in Spain on Thursday
column6: he said that he did not knowingly use the drug and that he believed the positive urine sample was a result of his consuming contaminated beef that a friend had brought from Spain for him and his Astana teammates.

column1: “I’m the victim
column2: ” a visibly emotional Contador said at the news conference in Pinto
column3: his hometown
column4: on the outskirts of Madrid. “I’m sad
column5: disappointed
column6: but am keeping my head held high
column7: ” he said. “It’s a clear case of food contamination. I won’t tolerate any sanction.”

column1: Though cycling has one of the strictest
column2: most thorough antidoping programs in all of sports
column3: its credibility has come into question yet again. Excluding Carlos Sastre
column4: who won in 2008
column5: every Tour winner dating to 1996 has either tested positive
column6: confessed to doping or been at the center of a doping scandal. Currently
column7: there is a federal investigation into suspected doping on the United States Postal Service team that starred the seven-time Tour winner Lance Armstrong .

column1: Contador tested positive for a “very small concentration” of the drug on the final rest day of the Tour

column1: Since then
column2: Contador has hired a team of experts to help prove his food-contamination case

column5: to get a final ruling. A Dutch scientist hired by Contador
column6: Douwe de Boer
column7: has already generated a paper concluding that “it is extremely likely and would be only fair” to say that the existence of clenbuterol in Contador’s system was from an accidental ingestion of contaminated meat.

column1: An expert in clenbuterol contamination in meat
column2: however
column3: characterized Contador’s explanation as almost impossible.

column1: The only other rider to lose the Tour title because of doping was Floyd Landis
column2: who tested positive for synthetic testosterone three days after winning in 2006. Fourteen months later
column3: after a public and heated legal fight with antidoping authorities
column4: he was stripped of the Tour title.

column1: Contador’s case will not be simple
column2: antidoping experts say.

column1: Pat McQuaid
column2: the cycling union’s president
column3: did not return phone calls or e-mails
column4: but the union said in a statement that Contador’s case “required further scientific investigation before any conclusion could be drawn.”

column1: The case is complex because it is possible that Contador did ingest the drug by accident.
Clenbuterol has been found in meat before — pork contaminated with the drug caused 70 people to become ill in China last year. Still
column2: even a trace amount of the substance in an athlete’s urine — no matter how it got there — triggers a positive test.

column1: “There are a couple of substances that have a threshold amount
column2: but this is not one of them
column3: ” David Howman
column4: the director general of the World Anti-Doping Agency
column5: said by telephone from India
column6: where he is attending the Commonwealth Games. “A case must be pursued if it’s found in an athlete’s system.”

column1: The American swimmer Jessica Hardy missed the 2008 Olympics after testing positive for the same drug; she said she had taken a contaminated nutritional supplement. An arbitration panel ruled that her claim was true
column2: but only reduced her two-year ban to one year.

column1: Howard Jacobs
column2: Hardy’s lawyer
column3: said that an athlete who ingests a contaminated nutritional supplement must receive a sanction under antidoping rules
column4: but that one who ingests a contaminated food product
column5: like meat
column6: has a chance of receiving no sanction at all.

column1: “If Contador proves that it came from contaminated meat
column2: I think he would be a good candidate for a no-fault finding
column3: which would mean no penalty
column4: ” Jacobs said. “With supplements
column5: you’re supposed to know what’s in them. But if it’s in beef
column6: no one would expect that the steak they are eating would cause a positive test of clenbuterol.”

column1: Even if Contador proves the meat was contaminated — challenging in itself because the meat cannot be tested — Jacobs said there would be a question of what would happen with his Tour results. Even in a no-fault finding
column2: competition results from that day are usually nullified. But Contador tested positive on a rest day
column3: with no competition.

column1: “It’s kind of a peculiar situation
column2: ” Jacobs said. “From the legal side
column3: there are some interesting issues.”

column1: Unlike the Tour de France
column2: the Race Across America is not a stage race; once it begins

column4: so determining when and how long to sleep is the event’s primary strategic element. The winner generally sleeps less than two hours out of 24 and finishes in less than nine days (although Robic’s winning time this past June was a relatively lethargic 9 days 46 minutes).

column2: Robic won the race and two weeks later won Le Tour Direct
column3: a 2

column5: 000 feet of climbing — almost the equivalent of starting at sea level and ascending Mt. Everest five times. His time was 7 days 19 hours.

column1: Robic became accustomed to both the physical and mental stress that pushing himself to extremes brought on. In the later stages of long-distance races

49;"September 24
N.B.A. Refereeing
column2: There Will Be a Quiz

column1: By JONATHAN ABRAMS

The N.B.A. announced a crackdown on players complaining about calls at its annual referee camp on Thursday and a marginal increase in instant replay to include its use in clear-path fouls and all of overtime.
(Before
column2: the league used instant replay automatically only during the last two minutes of regulation and the last two minutes of overtime).

column1: The camp also included a test given to media based on controversial situations. The referees are allowed to chide the media for getting answers wrong — their one shot of the year at retribution.
Below are a sample of five questions from the true-or-false test. If you have complained about officiating in the past
column2: go ahead and try it. The league’s referees are graded on a test containing similar material at the end of the camp. (The answers are below).

column1: 1) Player A5 legally taps the opening jump ball and player A1 gains possession near the baseline in his backcourt. A shot clock violation occurs when Team A fails to attempt a shot and the horn sounds at 11:34. The game clock MUST be reset to 11:36 (12:00 minus 24 equals 11:36).

2) Player A1 throws an alley-oop pass during a throw-in with 0.2 seconds left on the game clock. Player A5 taps the ball into the basket. The officials will use instant replay to confirm the ball was released prior to 0:00.
3) Defender B1 commits a foul at 1:23 of the 4th quarter and the officials are notified it is his fifth personal foul. At 1:12
column2: Player B1 is fouled in the act of shooting and the scorer informs the officials that player B1 had in fact
column3: received his sixth foul at 1:23 and not his fifth. This is a correctable error and because it was discovered within 24 seconds
column4: Player B1 will be removed
column5: the game clock reset to 1:23 and the foul at 1:12 will be nullified.

column1: 4) Player A6 enters the game prior to Team A’s throw-in. A 20-second timeout is granted when Team A cannot inbound the ball. Players A7 and A8 may replace A5 and A6 prior to the throw-in.
5) Following a successful basket at 3.3 seconds of the quarter
column2: thrower-in A5 rolls the ball up court. The clock incorrectly starts and the official blows the whistle after the ball is picked up near the 28’ mark. The ball should be returned to the baseline and the game clock reset to 3.3.

column1: Answers
1. False. Time can elapse between A5’s tap and when A1 gains possession of the ball.
2. False. There is no instant replay when there is less than .3 seconds on the clock. The only legal play is a tip. An offensive player does not have enough time to gain full possession of the ball.
3. False. The league does not consider this a correctable error. Player B1 would be removed from the game. The elapsed time would count and the player who took his place would shoot his free throws.
4. False. The player has to be involved in some type of basketball play before he can be substituted for.

The US plans to move 8
column2: 000 Marines and 10

column1: Visitors from Japan are the mainstay of the tourist industry. Away from the resorts and shopping malls

column1: Guam is home to several US attack submarines
Guam's diverse population includes Japanese

column3: and incomers from other Pacific islands. The indigenous Chamorro are a people of mixed Micronesian

column1: The island was settled in the second century BC. A Spanish expedition led by Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan arrived in 1521; under Spanish rule the native population was decimated by disease and the suppression of rebellions.

Guam was ceded to the US in 1898 after the Spanish-American War. The island was occupied by Japan during World War II. Many Guamanians died under the occupation before the territory was wrested from Japanese control in 1944.
After more than a century of change and development
column2: Spain's mark is still apparent in the Chamorro language

Hong Kong is governed under the principle of ""one country
column2: two systems""
column3: under which China has agreed to give the region a high degree of autonomy and to preserve its economic and social systems for 50 years from the date of the handover.

column1: Hong Kong's Victoria Peak offers spectacular vistas
Hong Kong's constitution
column2: the Basic Law
column3: provides for the development of democratic processes. However
column4: Beijing can veto changes to the political system and pro-democracy forces have been frustrated by what they see as the slow pace of political reform.

column1: China controls Hong Kong's foreign and defence policies

column1: Hong Kong's economy has moved away from manufacturing and is now services-based. The region is a major corporate and banking centre as well as a conduit for China's burgeoning exports. Its deepwater port is one of the world's busiest.
Companies based in Hong Kong employ millions of workers in the neighbouring Chinese province of Guangdong.
China ceded Hong Kong island to Britain in 1842 after the First Opium War. Britain later added parts of the Kowloon peninsula and the many smaller islands surrounding Hong Kong to its holdings.
In the 19th and 20th centuries Hong Kong's population was boosted by the arrival of hundreds of thousands of migrants from China
column2: many of whom were fleeing domestic upheavals. Industrialisation gathered pace
column3: and by the 1970s Hong Kong had become an ""Asian tiger""; one of the region's economic powerhouses.

column1: With little room for expansion across its hilly terrain
column2: high-rise Hong Kong has among the highest population density in the world; some 6
column3: 300 people per square kilometre. Skyscrapers and temples
column4: shopping malls and traditional markets sit cheek-by-jowl.

column1: But amid the urban hustle there are quiet parks and green spaces
column2: beaches and mountain-top views.

President: Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono
Former army general Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono won Indonesia's first-ever direct presidential elections in September 2004
column2: in what was hailed as the first peaceful transition of power in Indonesia's history.

column1: Mr Yudhoyono has made the fight against terrorism a key priority
He was re-elected in July 2009 in a landslide victory on the back of improved security and strong growth in Southeast Asia's biggest economy.

Mr Yudhoyono has cultivated an image as a tough and dedicated corruption fighter with high moral integrity; pledges to crack down even harder on corruption were one of the main planks of his 2009 election campaign.
However
column2: his failure to take a firmer line against two officials at the centre of a high-level corruption scandal that broke towards the end of 2009 raised questions about his commitment to root out graft in Indonesia.

column1: He is credited with having ushered in an era of financial and political stability
column2: restoring economic growth as the country slowly recovered from the devastating Asian financial crisis of 1997-98.

column1: The global financial crisis of 2008-9 did not hit Indonesia as badly as some of its neighbours
column2: though millions of Indonesian citizens still live under the poverty line.

column1: A former security minister in the Megawati government
column2: Mr Yudhoyono has identified the fight against terrorism as a key challenge. As security minister he spearheaded operations to capture the Islamic extremists blamed for the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings.

column1: The first year of Mr Yudhoyono's first term brought perhaps his biggest challenge
column2: the 2004 Asian tsunami disaster. His administration also won international plaudits for signing a peace deal in 2005 with separatist rebels in Aceh province.

column1: His Democratic Party emerged from the April 2009 parliamentary elections as the largest party.
Mr Yudhoyono
column2: a fluent English speaker
column3: studied for his master's degree in the US. Rising through the ranks under former President Suharto
column4: he led his country's peacekeeping contingent in Bosnia in the 1990s.

column1: Mr Yudhoyono also completed several tours of duty in the Indonesian-occupied East Timor.
Married with two sons
column2: the president has released several albums featuring his own love songs
column3: some of them now covered by Indonesian boy bands.

Akihito succeeded his father

column1: Prime minister: Naoto Kan
Naoto Kan became prime minister in June 2010
column2: following the resignation of Yukio Hatoyama amid a damaging dispute over a US air base.

column1: Naoto Kan exposed government culpability in a tainted blood scandal
A former leftist activist
column2: Mr Kan is Japan's fifth premier in four years
column3: and the first in over a decade not to hail from a political dynasty.

column1: Mr Hatoyama's government
column2: in which Mr Kan served as deputy PM
column3: came to power in a groundbreaking election in 2009 which saw the centre-left Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ) end decades of rule by the conservative Liberal Democratic Party.

column1: But Mr Hatoyama's support plummeted after he backtracked on an election promise to move the unpopular US base off Okinawa
column2: enraging locals as well as the pacifist Social Democrats
column3: who quit his coalition.

column1: Mr Kan said he would honour an agreement to relocate the US Marine Corps Air Station Futenma within Okinawa.
But soon after he became PM
column2: his government lost its majority in the upper house of parliament in July elections. The defeat meant it would need opposition support in the upper house to pass some legislation.

column1: The loss was blamed on comments by Mr Kan suggesting that Japan's 5% sales tax be doubled. In September
column2: however
column3: he survived a leadership challenge from the DPJ's veteran power-broker
column4: Ichiro Ozawa.

column1: The same month
column2: Mr Kan's poll ratings were hit by the decision to free a Chinese trawler captain arrested in disputed waters
column3: in what was widely seen as a diplomatic defeat.

column1: Mr Kan
column2: the son of a factory manager and a graduate of applied sciences
column3: campaigned in the 1970s for pacifist and environmental causes and entered parliament with a leftist party in 1980. He help to found the then-opposition Democratic Party in 1996.

column1: He achieved popularity in the mid-1990s when as health minister he brought to light government culpability in a scandal over HIV-tainted blood products. In January 2010
column2: Mr Kan
column3: took over as finance minister.

Ethnically the country is as diverse

column6: Chechens and others accounting for the rest.

column1: These groups generally live in harmony

column1: Astana: Oil money is driving the new capital's development
The main religion
column2: Islam
column3: was suppressed like all others under Communist rule
column4: but has enjoyed a revival since the collapse of the Soviet Union.

column1: There has been major foreign investment in the Caspian oil sector. Oil development has brought rapid economic growth
column2: although expansion slowed in 2009 as a result of the global financial crisis.

column1: An oil pipeline linking the Tengiz oil field in western Kazakhstan to the Russian Black Sea port of Novorossiysk opened in 2001. In 2008
column2: Kazakhstan began pumping some oil exports through the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan pipeline
column3: as part of a drive to lessen its dependence on Russia as a transit country. A pipeline to China was opened in late 2005
column4: with work on another starting in 2008.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: poverty is still widespread and Kazakhstan continues to face major economic challenges
column3: particularly with unemployment and inflation. At the same time
column4: a small minority of Kazakhs grew very rich after independence through privatization and other business deals which opposition politician alleged to have been corrupt.

column1: The people of Kazakhstan also have to live with the aftermath of Soviet-era nuclear testing and toxic waste dumping
column2: as well as with increasing drug addiction and a growing incidence of HIV/Aids. Inefficient Soviet irrigation projects led to severe shrinkage of the heavily polluted Aral Sea.

column1: 104;"Kiribati used to lie either side of the International Date Line
column2: but the government unilaterally moved the line eastwards in 1995 to ensure the day was the same in the whole country.

column1: Rising sea levels threaten the low-lying islands
This was a shrewd move as Kiribati marketed itself as the first inhabited place on Earth to greet the new millennium on 1 January 2000. The world's media descended on Caroline Island
column2: renamed Millennium Island
column3: to record the event.

column1: Kiribati's economy is weak and is affected by rises and falls in the world demand for coconut.
Fishing licences
column2: foreign aid and money sent home by workers abroad also play their part
column3: as does a trust fund set up with revenues from phosphate mining on the island of Banaba. The mines were depleted by 1980
column4: precipitating the evacuation of much of the population.

column1: Kiribati is home to the South Pacific's largest marine reserve.

After the Korean War
column2: Kim Il-sung introduced the personal philosophy of Juche
column3: or self-reliance
column4: which became a guiding light for North Korea's development. Kim Il-sung's son
column5: Kim Jong-il
column6: is now head of state
column7: but the post of president has been assigned ""eternally"" to his late father.

column1: AT-A-GLANCE
Politics: Supreme leader Kim Jong-il heads a secretive
column2: communist regime which tolerates no dissent

column1: Economy: North Korea's command economy is dilapidated
column2: hit by natural disasters
column3: poor planning and a failure to modernise

column1: International: The armstice of 1953 ended armed conflict on the Korean peninsular
column2: but the two Koreas are technically still at war; tensions have been exacerbated in recent decades by North Korea's nuclear ambitions

column1: Timeline
Decades of this rigid state-controlled system have led to stagnation and a leadership dependent on the cult of personality.

Aid agencies have estimated that up to two million people have died since the mid-1990s because of acute food shortages caused by natural disasters and economic mismanagement. The country relies on foreign aid to feed millions of its people.
The totalitarian state also stands accused of systematic human rights abuses. Reports of torture
column2: public executions
column3: slave labour
column4: and forced abortions and infanticides in prison camps have emerged. A US-based rights group has estimated that there are up to 200
column5: 000 political prisoners in North Korea.

column1: Pyongyang has accused successive South Korean governments of being US ""puppets""
column2: but South Korean President Kim Dae-jung's visit in 2000 signalled a thaw in relations. Seoul's ""sunshine policy"" towards the north aimed to encourage change through dialogue and aid.

column1: Nuclear tensions
This tentative reaching-out to the world was dealt a blow in 2002 by Pyongyang's decision to reactivate a nuclear reactor and to expel international inspectors.
In October 2006 North Korea said it had successfully tested a nuclear weapon
column2: spreading alarm throughout the region.

column1: Since then
column2: intensive diplomatic efforts have aimed to rein in North Korea's nuclear ambitions. After years of on-and-off talks
column3: a deal was thrashed out in February 2007 under which Pyongyang agreed to shut down its main nuclear reactor in return for aid and diplomatic concessions.

column1: But negotiations stalled as North Korea accused its negotiating partners - the US
column2: South Korea
column3: Japan
column4: China and Russia - of failing to meet agreed obligations.

column1: Tensions between North Korea and the rest of the world increased steadily again from late 2008 onwards
column2: especially after the new South Korean president
column3: Lee Myung-bak
column4: ended his predecessor's ""sunshine policy"" of rapprochement with the North.

column1: In April 2009 North Korea walked out of international talks aimed at ending its nuclear activities. The following month the country carried out its second ever underground nuclear test and announced that it no longer considered itself bound by the terms of the 1953 truce that ended the war between the two Koreas.
Tensions reached a new high in spring 2010
column2: when the South accused North Korea of being responsible for sinking of one of its warships
column3: the Cheonan
column4: and cut off all cross-border trade. Pyongyang denied the claims
column5: and in turn severed all ties with Seoul.

column1: After the US imposed tough sanctions in August
column2: the North began to make overtures again. Kim Jong-il signalled a readiness to resume six-party nuclear talks during a visit to China
column3: and indicated a willingness to accept Southern aid to cope with major flood damage.

column1: North Korea maintains one of the world's largest standing armies and militarism pervades everyday life. But standards of training
column2: discipline and equipment in the force are said to be low.

column1: 106;"The following four decades were marked by authoritarian rule. Government-sponsored schemes encouraged the growth of family-owned industrial conglomerates
column2: known as ""chaebol"". Foremost among them were the Hyundai and Samsung groups.

column1: Please turn on JavaScript. Media requires JavaScript to play.
They helped transform South Korea into one of the world's major economies and a leading exporter of cars and electronic goods.
Although the South Korean economy is now the third largest in Asia and the 13th in the world
column2: the high levels of foreign debt held by the country's banks have left them exposed to the fallout from the global credit crisis.

column1: A multi-party political system was restored in 1987
column2: and President Roh Tae-Woo launched an anti-corruption campaign against both his own party and his political predecessor.

column1: The South-North border is the world's most heavily-fortified frontier
Relations with its northern neighbour remain a major concern in Seoul
column2: particularly over the North's fragile economy and its nuclear ambitions. South Korea generally resisted international calls for sanctions against the North over its nuclear programme and pursued a ""sunshine"" policy of engagement in the late 1990s.

column1: This has involved aid - including shipments of fertiliser and rice - reunions between North and South Koreans
column2: tourist projects and economic cooperation. South Korean companies employed thousands of North Korean workers at the Kaesong industrial complex near the border.

column1: The ""sunshine"" ended with the election in 2008 of conservative President Lee Myung-bak
column2: who adopted a tougher tone towards the North in response to its failure to move on the nuclear issue.

column1: Tensions were heightened further by a spate of Northern missile tests in 2009 and then by the sinking of the Southern naval ship Cheonan in March 2010
column2: in which 46 sailors died.

column1: After international investigators reported finding evidence that the Cheonan was sunk by a torpedo from a North Korean submarine
column2: South Korea stopped all trade between the two states. Pyongyang rejected the claim as ""fabrication"" and retaliated by cutting all relations with Seoul.

column1: The demilitarised zone (DMZ) between South and North Korea is the world's most heavily-fortified frontier. But the US
column2: which maintains tens of thousands of soldiers in South Korea
column3: is pulling its forces away from the front line and plans to reduce troop numbers.

a popular revolt sparked by allegations of government interference in parliamentary elections and fuelled by poverty and corruption swept President Askar Akayev - who had led the country since independence - from power.

column1: AT-A-GLANCE
Politics: First two post-Soviet presidents
column2: Askar Akayev and Kurmanbek Bakiyev
column3: were swept from power by popular uprisings. Ethnic tensions have led to violence

column1: Economics: Kyrgyzstan is one of the poorest countries of the former Soviet Union
International: Kyrgyzstan hosts Russian and US military airbases
Timeline
Kyrgyzstan's democratic credentials were regarded as relatively strong in the immediate post-Soviet era
column2: but this reputation was lost when corruption and nepotism took hold during President Akayev's years in office. Parliamentary and presidential elections were flawed
column3: opposition figures faced harassment and imprisonment
column4: and opposition newspapers were closed.

column1: His successor after the 2005 revolt
column2: Kurmanbek Bakiyev
column3: failed to restore full confidence in state institutions at home or abroad. His time in office was marred by political instability and an almost constant struggle with parliament over the constitutional balance of power.

column1: Elections held under Mr Bakiyev were criticised as being undemocratic
column2: and human rights groups expressed concern over the curtailing of civil liberties and attacks on the media.

column1: Civil tensions again came to a head in April 2010
column2: when Mr Bakiyev himself was toppled and an interim government was set up under the leadership of former Foreign Minister Roza Otunbayeva.

column1: The Kyrgyz make up nearly 70% of the population
column2: with Uzbeks accounting for about 15% and concentrated in the Ferghana Valley in the south. Russians have a significant presence in the north and in the capital
column3: Bishkek.

column1: There is tension between the Kyrgyz and Uzbek communities in the south over land and housing
column2: and relations with Uzbekistan were strained following the flight of refugees into Kyrgyzstan after clashes in the Uzbek city Andijan in 2005.

column1: There have been several serious outbreaks of Kyrgyz-Uzbek interethnic violence in the southern city of Osh
column2: notably in 1990 - when hundreds were killed - and again in June 2010 following the overthrow of Kurmanbek Bakiyev. Osh had been a Bakiyev stronghold.

column1: Most of the population of Kyrgyzstan is nominally Muslim
column2: and there has been a growing interest in Islam among those seeking a new ethnic or national identity.

column1: The government is worried about inroads by jihadist groups like Hizb-ut Tahrir
column2: and there have been periodic outbreaks of fighting in the south.

column1: Kyrgyzstan also features in the US-Russian rivalry for control of Central Asia
column2: as both powers have military air bases in the country.

column1: The US established an air base at the Manas international airport near Bishkek in late 2001 to support military operations in Afghanistan. President Bakiyev threatened to close it in October 2008 after agreeing to a Russian loan. He reversed the decision when the US agreed to more than triple its annual rent for the base.
Weeks later Kyrgyzstan tentatively agreed to allow Russia to open a second military base on its territory
column2: apparently expanding Moscow's military reach to balance the US presence.

The government has implemented gradual economic and business reforms since 2005 to somewhat liberalize its domestic markets. Its longterm plans for reform include high-profile projects such as the Nam Theun 2 power project.
Thailand is the largest foreign investor in Laos. While this support is badly needed
column2: the dangers of exposing Laos's fragile economy to world trends are clear.

column1: AT A GLANCE
Politics: Ruling communists maintain a monopoly of political power
Economy: One of the world's poorest nations
column2: Laos has little industry and relies on foreign aid; hopes are pinned on a hydroelectric project

column1: International: Communist regime is backed by China and Vietnam
Timeline
The Asian currency crisis of 1997 caused the national currency
column2: the kip
column3: to lose more than nine-tenths of its value against the US dollar.

column1: Laos is a landlocked
column2: mountainous country
column3: widely covered by largely unspoilt tropical forest. Less than 5% of the land is suitable for subsistence agriculture
column4: which nevertheless provides around 80% of employment.

column1: The main crop is rice
column2: which is grown on the fertile floodplain of the Mekong River. Vegetables
column3: fruit
column4: spices and cotton are also grown. Part of the region's heroin-producing ""Golden Triangle""
column5: Laos has all but stamped out opium production.

column1: Outside the capital
column2: many people live without electricity or access to basic facilities. But Laos is banking on the anticipated returns from a billion-dollar dam scheme
column3: intended to generate electricity for export to Thailand
column4: to boost its economy and infrastructure.

column1: Several small bomb blasts in recent years in and around the capital
column2: Vientiane
column3: have suggested that opposition to the ruling party may be growing. But any public dissent is dealt with harshly by the authorities.

column1: The country's human rights record has come under scrutiny. Laos denies accusations of abuses by the military against the ethnic minority Hmong. Hmong groups have been fighting a low-level rebellion against the communist regime since 1975.

Its economy revolves around tourism. Macau has capitalised on its long history as a gambling centre
column2: drawing many thousands of visitors from China and Hong Kong.

column1: Foreign casino companies have invested heavily since Hong Kong tycoon Stanley Ho's decades-long monopoly on the gaming industry ended in 2002. New ""mega-casinos""
column2: which include major hotel developments
column3: have replaced traditional gambling dens.

column1: Colonial architecture remains
column2: but Portugal's stamp on Macau is fading

column1: In 2006 the returns from the casino boom surpassed the revenues of the US gambling mecca
column2: Las Vegas. But analysts warn that Macau risks relying too much on the industry.

column1: Some politicians and academics say most locals have yet to benefit from the economic boom.
The former colony reverted to Chinese sovereignty in 1999 after 400 years of Portuguese rule. Beijing promised to uphold Western-style freedoms for at least 50 years.
Although it is part of China
column2: Macau is governed under the ""one country
column3: two systems"" principle
column4: under which it has a large degree of autonomy.

column1: Pro-reform forces are less vocal in Macau than in Hong Kong. A new state security law came into effect in 2009 with very little opposition
column2: whereas attempts by the Chinese government to introduce a similar law in Hong Kong in 2003 triggered mass protests.

column1: The campaign for universal suffrage in Hong Kong is being watched with keen interest in Macau. China is unlikely to grant greater democratic rights unless consistent pressure is applied by pro-democract campaigners - something that seems far less likely to happen in Macau than in Hong Kong.
Portuguese seafarers settled in the area in the 1500s. Initially
column2: the colony prospered on the lucrative returns from regional trade
column3: and European-style mansions and churches mushroomed.

column1: Trade dwindled from the 1600s
column2: but the introduction of licensed gambling in the mid 1800s revived Macau's fortunes.

column1: 110;"Head of state: Sultan Mizan Zainal Abidin
Sultan Mizan Zainal Abidin was installed as Malaysia's 13th king in December 2006.
Sultan Mizan Zainal Abidin's role is mainly ceremonial
Malaysia's new king takes office
The sultan is a former ruler of oil-rich Terengganu state. He was 44 when he was sworn in.
The king's role is largely ceremonial
column2: although he is nominal head of the armed forces and all laws and the appointment of every cabinet minister require his assent.

column1: Under Malaysia's constitutional monarchy
column2: the position of king is rotated every five years between each of the nine hereditary state rulers.

column1: Malaysia's first prime minister
column2: Tunku Abdul Rahman
column3: himself a prince
column4: devised the system after independence in 1957 to spread power among the sultans and rajas who had ruled over fiefdoms on the Malay peninsula for hundreds of years.

column1: Prime minister: Najib Abdul Razak
Najib Razak was guaranteed the post of prime minister in March 2009 when he became the leader of the United Malays National Organisation
column2: the main party in the National Front ruling coalition.

column1: Like his predecessor
column2: Mr Najib came to the job promising reforms

column1: The son of the country's second prime minister and nephew of the third
column2: Mr Najib is regarded by many Malaysians as political blue blood and seems to have been destined for the premiership from an early age.

column1: A British-trained economist
column2: he first entered parliament at the age of 23 - becoming the youngest MP in Malaysian history - and quickly rose to prominence.

column1: He held numerous cabinet posts - including finance and defence - before becoming prime minister.
He took over the premiership at a turbulent time
column2: and faces the enormous challenge of steering the country through the global financial crisis
column3: which has hit the economy hard.

column1: Mr Najib pledged radical reforms and a more transparent government. He said that one of his priorities would be to close a widening ethnic and religious divide
column2: after Malaysia's ethnic minorities shifted towards the opposition in large numbers in the 2008 polls
column3: fearing their rights were being eroded.

column1: But his rise to power was marked by a government crackdown on the resurgent opposition
column2: with allegations that strong-arm tactics were being used to stifle political dissent.

column1: His predecessor
column2: Abdullah Ahmad Badawi
column3: resigned as prime minister in April 2009 after the governing coalition suffered a heavy defeat in a general election in March 2008.

column1: 111;"The compact came into force in 1986 and was renegotiated in 2003. The US controls the security and defence of the islands

column1: MARK OF NUCLEAR PAST
A huge concrete dome over a crater left by nuclear blasts on Runit Island caps off radioactive debris from tests in the 1940s and 1950s
Under the compact
column2: the US pays an annual rent to use the Kwajalein atoll as a base and missile test range.

column1: The legacy of the post-war US occupation is seen particularly starkly on Bikini and Enewetak
column2: which were both used for nuclear weapons testing between 1946 and 1958.

column1: The US paid $150 million in a compensation package for the test victims in the 1980s. But whilst Enewetak has been partly decontaminated
column2: Bikini is still uninhabitable. The Marshall Islands has petitioned for additional compensation.

column1: A major problem for the islands is how to gain some measure of financial independence from the US. Imports dwarf exports
column2: unemployment is high and many islanders live by subsistence farming.

column1: Tourism is one option; unspoiled beaches abound and the islands are an ideal base for scuba diving and sports fishing. The islands also sell fishing rights to other countries
column2: and offer ship registrations under the Marshall Islands flag.

column1: 112;"Media
Though formally independent
column2: in 1986 Micronesia signed a ""Compact of Free Association"" with the US. Under this
column3: Washington took on responsibility for defence and gained the right to set up military bases and deny other nations access to Micronesia. In return
column4: Micronesia received financial assistance averaging $100m per year
column5: and the right of Micronesians to live and work in the US. Micronesia also takes its cue from Washington on foreign policy.

column1: A renegotiated 20-year compact
column2: worth $3.5 billion to Micronesia and the Marshall Islands
column3: was signed by US President George W Bush in December 2003. Some of the money is being diverted into trust funds
column4: intended to provide a financial resource for Micronesia after the compact expires.

column1: Despite its small population and the large amount of incoming aid from the US
column2: Japan and elsewhere
column3: Micronesia has relatively high unemployment
column4: a matter compounded by increasing numbers of Filipino migrant workers.

column1: Many Micronesians live without electricity or running water
column2: which is in short supply and is sometimes rationed. The gap between rich and poor is increasing as business and officials benefit disproportionately from US aid donations.

column1: Micronesia's biggest challenge is to find a way of lessening its dependence on foreign aid. Given the islands' splendid beaches and scuba diving opportunities
column2: tourism offers one possibility
column3: but this is constrained by the lack of adequate infrastructure and the islands' remoteness.

President: Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj
Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj won the presidency with a narrow election win over incumbent Nambaryn Enkhbayar in May 2009 and took office in June.
Mr Elbegdorj was elected on a pledge to fight graft and poverty.
Standing for the opposition Democratic Party
column2: Mr Elbegdorj won just over 51% of the vote
column3: to 47% for Mr Enkhbayar
column4: whose ruling Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party (MPRP) said it accepted the result as fair.

column1: The peaceful outcome came after fears of a repeat of the violence which followed opposition claims of fraud after the Democratic Party's defeat in the 2008 parliamentary elections.
Mr Elbegdorj campaigned on promises to fight corruption and to spread the profits of Mongolia's mineral wealth more widely.
To achieve the second aim
column2: he planned to tighten rules for contracts under which foreign mining firms operate.

column1: His message proved popular in the big cities
column2: especially the capital Ulan Bator
column3: and was helped by widespread poverty.

column1: However
column2: he faced a parliament which continued to be dominated by a solid MPRP majority
column3: but the then MPRP prime minister
column4: Sanjagiin Bayar
column5: promised to ensure that his government would work well with the president.

column1: Although the prime minister and parliament exercise real political power
column2: the president heads the armed forces and has the power of veto in parliament. Frequent changes of government have enhanced the role of the presidency.

column1: Born in 1963
column2: Tsakhiagiin Elbegdorj was one of the leaders of the peaceful revolution that ended the Communist dictatorship in 1990.

column1: Since then
column2: he has served as prime minister twice
column3: briefly in 1998
column4: and in 2006-8.

column1: Prime Minister: Sukhbaataryn Batbold
Foreign Minister Sukhbaataryn Batbold became prime minister unexpectedly in October 2009 when his predecessor Sanjagiin Bayar resigned for health reasons.
Mr Batbold consolidated his hold on power when he also took over from Mr Bayar as leader of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party (MPRP) in April 2010.
Born in 1963
column2: Mr Batbold ran the Mongolian side of a major gold-mining venture with the Canadian company Centerra Gold in 1992-2000
column3: and his wife now runs his hotel and cashmere industry interests in the Altai Trading Company.

column1: Mr Batbold has continued his predecessor's policy of encouraging foreign investment in the mining industries and seeking to work with President Elbegdorj of the rival Democratic Party.

When the 50-year-old Benigno Aquino won the 2010 presidential election
column2: he was at that stage better known for his parents than for any of his own achievements.

column1: Until he ran for president
column2: Noynoy Aquino was relatively unknown

column1: But the fact his mother was the former President Cory Aquino and his father the pro-democracy hero Benigno ""Ninoy"" Aquino meant that he was virtually predestined for a career in public life.

column2: Mr Aquino - who is more commonly known as Noynoy - underlined his desire to emulate his mother by carrying on her pro-democracy agenda.

column1: His other main campaign pledge was to combat corruption
column2: and he suggested that he had some very powerful people in his sights. He has indicated that he even plans to have his predecessor Gloria Arroyo investigated for alleged vote-rigging in the 2004 presidential election - an accusation she denies.

column1: His campaign slogan - ""When no one's corrupt
column2: no one will be poor"" - linked corruption in high places with the grinding poverty endured by many of his compatriots. A third of the 90 million population lives on just one US dollar a day.

column1: Another challenge he will face is the high level of localised violence
column2: particularly on the southern island of Mindanao
column3: where the armed forces are fighting both Islamic and communist rebels. The Arroyo administration had been engaged in peace talks with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF)
column4: and he has vowed to continue these.

column1: But perhaps Mr Aquino's greatest challenge will be to step out of the shadow of his famous family.
The only son of Cory and Ninoy Aquino
column2: Noynoy Aquino studied economics before starting a career in business. His father was murdered when he returned to the Philippines from exile in 1983. Four years later
column3: Noynoy himself was seriously injured during the first coup attempt against his mother
column4: who had become president in 1986.

International attention was focused on the territory in 2008 during the run-up to the Beijing Olympics. Fatal clashes between anti-Chinese protesters and the authorities in Tibet were given wide publicity and the torch relay in London
column2: Paris and San Francisco was dogged by pro-Tibet protests and stunts.

column1: AT A GLANCE
Sovereignty: The Dalai Lama says Tibet was independent and has been colonised. China says its sovereignty over Tibet goes back centuries.
What is Tibet? China considers this to be the Tibetan Autonomous Region. Dalai Lama says it should include neighbouring provinces with Tibetan populations.
Repression: Dalai Lama says 1.2 million people were killed under Chinese rule. China disputes this.
Culture: Dalai Lama says China actively suppressed Tibetan identity. China acknowledges some abuses but says it is helping the revival of Tibetan culture.
Development: China says it has brought improvements in health and the economy. Dalai Lama says development has favoured Han Chinese immigrants.
International response: No country openly disputes China's claim to sovereignty
column2: and China has blocked all UN resolutions on Tibet.

column1: The free-Tibet movement: The Tibetan cause has won the sympathy of individuals and groups
column2: many of whom campaign for an independent Tibet.

column1: Q&A: China and Tibet
Tibet has had a tumultuous history
column2: during which it has spent some periods functioning as an independent entity and others ruled by powerful Chinese and Mongolian dynasties.

column1: China sent in thousands of troops to enforce its claim on the region in 1950. Some areas became the Tibetan Autonomous Region and others were incorporated into neighbouring Chinese provinces.

column2: after a failed anti-Chinese uprising
column3: the 14th Dalai Lama fled Tibet and set up a government in exile in India. Most of Tibet's monasteries were destroyed in the 1960s and 1970s during China's Cultural Revolution. Thousands of Tibetans are believed to have been killed during periods of repression and martial law.

column1: Under international pressure
column2: China eased its grip on Tibet in the 1980s
column3: introducing ""Open Door"" reforms and boosting investment.

column1: Beijing says Tibet has developed considerably under its rule. But rights groups say China continues to violate human rights
column2: accusing Beijing of political and religious repression. Beijing denies any abuses.

column1: Tourism and the ongoing modernisation drive stand in contrast to Tibet's former isolation. But Beijing's critics say Tibetans have little say in building their future.
China says a new railway link between Lhasa and the western Chinese province of Qinghai will boost economic expansion. The link is likely to increase the influx of Chinese migrants.
Buddhism reached Tibet in the seventh century. The Dalai Lama
column2: or Ocean of Wisdom
column3: is the leading spiritual figure; the Panchen Lama is the second most important figure. Both are seen as the reincarnations of their predecessors.

column1: The selection of a Dalai Lama and a Panchen Lama has traditionally followed a strict process. But the Dalai Lama and Beijing are at odds over the 11th incarnation of the Panchen Lama
column2: having identified different youngsters for the role. The Dalai Lama's choice
column3: Gedhun Choekyi Nyima
column4: has not been seen since his detention by the Chinese authorities in 1995.

column1: Tibet's spiritual leader
column2: the Dalai Lama
column3: leads a government in exile

column1: There have been intermittent and indirect contacts between China and the Dalai Lama. The exiled spiritual leader advocates a non-violent
column2: negotiated solution to the Tibet problem and accepts the notion of real autonomy for Tibet under Chinese sovereignty. China has questioned his claims that he does not seek independence.

column1: Tibet's economy depends largely on agriculture. Forests and grasslands occupy large parts of the country. The territory is rich in minerals
column2: but poor transport links have limited their exploitation. Tourism is an important revenue earner.

column1: The country has been unable to benefit fully from its gas and oil deposits because of an absence of export routes and a dispute between the Caspian Sea littoral states over the legal status of offshore oil.

column1: 133;"Uzbekistan is the most populous Central Asian country and has the largest armed forces. There is no legal political opposition and the media is tightly controlled by the state. A UN report has described the use of torture as ""systematic"".
The ancient city of Samarkand was a major Silk Route trading post
Politics: Long-term leader Islam Karimov tolerates no opposition; political and rights activists have fled. He shows no signs of giving up power
Economics: Uzbekistan is a leading cotton grower. Natural gas is a big attraction abroad. Central control of the economy dates back to the Soviet era.
International: Despite frequent criticism of its poor human rights record
column2: Uzbekistan's energy resources and strategic location have led both Russia and the West to seek closer ties.

column1: Timeline
The country is one of the world's biggest producers of cotton and is rich in natural resources
column2: including oil
column3: gas and gold. However
column4: economic reform has been slow and poverty and unemployment are widespread.

column1: Following the 11 September attacks on the US
column2: Uzbekistan won favour with Washington by allowing its forces a base in Uzbekistan
column3: affording ready access across the Afghan border.

column1: Human rights groups accused the international community of ignoring the many reported cases of abuse and torture.
Since independence
column2: the country has faced sporadic bombings and shootings
column3: which the authorities have been quick to blame on Islamic extremists.

column1: In May 2005
column2: troops in the eastern city of Andijan opened fire on protesters demonstrating against the imprisonment of people charged with Islamic extremism. Witnesses reported a bloodbath with several hundred civilian deaths. The Uzbek authorities say fewer than 190 died.

column1: Opponents of President Karimov blamed the authorities' brutal determination to crush all dissent. The president blamed fundamentalists seeking to overthrow the government and establish a Muslim caliphate in Central Asia.
The government's reaction to the Andijan unrest prompted strong criticism from the West
column2: and relations cooled. In response
column3: Uzbekistan expelled US forces from their base and moved closer to Russia
column4: with Mr Karimov at one point describing it as Tashkent's ""most reliable partner and ally"".

column1: From 2008 onwards
column2: ties with the West began improving again
column3: spurred on by Europeans' search for alternative energy sources in Central Asia and Uzbekistan's strategic importance for the anti-Taliban operation in Afghanistan.

column1: The EU eased sanctions imposed after the Andijan killings
column2: and the World Bank reversed a decision to suspend loans to Uzbekistan. In 2009 the EU lifted its arms embargo.

column1: At the same time
column2: relations with Moscow became less warm
column3: with Uzbekistan in 2009 criticising plans for a Russian base in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan.

column1: President Karimov's uncompromising policies have also at times created friction between Uzbekistan and other Central Asian countries
column2: and Uzbekistan has been wary of moves towards closer political integration.

Xinjiang
column2: about the size of Iran
column3: is divided into the Dzungarian Basin in the north and the Tarim Basin in the south by a mountain range.

column1: The economy of this once agricultural region has developed fast since 1949
column2: and oil and petrochemicals now account for about 60 per cent of its GDP. It is also an important trade and pipeline route into Central Asia and beyond.

column1: The region was contested by various Turkic groups
column2: Mongols and the Chinese until the 18th century
column3: when the Chinese Qing Dynasty brought the whole area under its control.

column1: Russia's conquest of the neighbouring Central Asian states of Kokand and Bukhara led to a renewed struggle for control over the area
column2: with the Kokand general Yaqub Bek establishing a de facto independent state in Kashgar in 1865. China gradually regained control of the region and formally set up Xinjiang Province in 1884.

column1: Russian influence remained strong
column2: especially during the rule of various warlords after the fall of the Qing Dynasty in 1912. The Soviet Union supported an Uighur-led separatist East Turkestan Republic in the north of the region in 1944-1949
column3: but helped to extinguish it when the Communists took over in China proper.

column1: XINJIANG: ETHNIC UNREST
Main ethnic division: 45% Uighur
column2: 40% Han Chinese

column1: 26 June: Mass factory brawl after dispute between Han Chinese and Uighurs in Guangdong
column2: southern China
column3: leaves two Uighurs dead

column1: 5 July: Uighur protest in Urumqi over the dispute turns violent
column2: leaving 156 dead - most of them thought to be Han - and more than 1
column3: 000 hurt

column1: 7 July: Uighur women protest at arrests of menfolk. Han Chinese make armed counter-march
8 July: President Hu Jintao returns from G8 summit to tackle crisis
July-August: More than 1
column2: 500 people are arrested in connection with the riots

column1: October: 12 people sentenced to death for involvement in the violence
Views from China
Communist China established the Autonomous Region in 1955
column2: and began to encourage Han Chinese to settle there in new industrial towns and farming villages run by the quasi-military Xinjiang Production and Development Corps. China also set up its nuclear testing facility at Lop Nur in the Tarim Basin
column3: conducting the first test there in 1964.

column1: In the 2000 census Han Chinese made up 40 per cent of the population of Xinjiang
column2: excluding large numbers of troops stationed in the region and unknown numbers of unregistered migrants
column3: and Uighurs accounted for about 45 per cent.

column1: Ethnic unrest
International attention turned to Xinjiang in July 2009 when bloody clashes between Uighurs and Han Chinese in the region's main city
column2: Urumqi
column3: promoted the Chinese government to send large numbers of troops to patrol the streets. Nearly 200 people were killed in the unrest
column4: most of them Han
column5: according to officials.

column1: Protests against Chinese rule had already emerged in the 1990s
column2: to which the Chinese authorities reacted forcefully. These culminated in clashes in the city of Yining (Ghulja in Uighur) in 1997 in protest at the execution of 30 alleged separatists. The authorities reported nine dead in the violence
column3: although separatists said more than a hundred protestors were killed.

column1: Protests resumed in March 2008 in the cities of Urumqi and Hotan
column2: and spread to Kashgar and elsewhere through the summer - coinciding with the Olympic Games in Beijing. There were reports of bus bombings and attacks on police stations.

column1: The main Uighur groups abroad are the separatist East Turkestan Liberation Movement

China tycoon pledges fortune to charity
US billionaires Bill Gates and Warren Buffett are hosting a dinner in Beijing for some of China's richest individuals.
They are hoping to learn about philanthropy in China - and perhaps persuade some of their guests to give more to charity. The BBC's Michael Bristow spoke to one of those invited to dine.
Mr Chen says he learned about charity mainly from the example set by his mother
Businessman Chen Guangbiao has been inspired by the two US billionaires.
The 42-year-old is a well-known philanthropist
column2: but decided to go one step further when he got a call from Bill Gates and Warren Buffett.

column1: Mr Chen sat down and wrote them a letter declaring that all his money will go to charity after he dies.
Perhaps surprisingly
column2: the news was not greeted with universal approval in China
column3: where giving to charity is not as established as in other countries.

column1: There was particular criticism when people found out that Mr Chen does not even give money to his own siblings.
His sister earns 1
column3: £170) a month washing dishes in a hotel; his brother earns only slightly more working as a security guard.

column1: On that issue
column2: Mr Chen is unrepentant. He said he had helped them in the past
column3: but they had squandered his money.

column1: He said his brother gambled and his sister began a loan business that eventually failed.
I'm determined never to help them again
column2: he told the BBC in an interview at his plush Beijing apartment.

column1: Entrepreneurial spirit
Chen Guangbiao's story is a classic tale of rags to riches.
He was born into a poor family in Anhui Province
column2: where it was a constant battle to survive. He said two of his siblings died of starvation.

As a schoolboy he soon amassed what was to him a small fortune by selling anything he could - water
column2: ice-cream - and doing odd jobs.

column1: His firm recycles waste material from the construction industry

column1: When other people's kids had no milk
column2: my mother would breastfeed them herself
column3: said the businessman.

column1: She also invited beggars into their home to share their meagre meals.

The father of two said giving was a habit he has maintained over the years.
Inspired
A report on philanthropy in China published by the Shanghai-based Huran Research Institute earlier this year listed Mr Chen as the country's fourth-most-generous giver.
It said he had donated $130m over the last five years to projects involved in health-care
column2: disaster relief and education.

column1: But the Giving Pledge campaign started by Mr Gates and Mr Buffett has pushed Mr Chen to donate even more money.

If you have only a glass of water then one person can drink. If you have a bucket a whole family can benefit.""

column1: It is one of many hospitals

The massage ensures that his skin remains elastic - so it will shrink along with his waistline.

column5: already uncomfortable allies that are pursuing competing interests in the Afghan war.

column1: The C.I.A. carried out a record number of drone attacks inside Pakistan last month
column2: and new reports surfaced this week of unlawful executions by the Pakistani Army in areas where it has opened operations against Taliban forces threatening the government.

column1: The Pakistani offensives have not extended to North Waziristan
column2: the prime stronghold of the insurgents who infiltrate Afghanistan
column3: a growing source of frustration for American officials who face a deadline this year to show progress in the Afghan war.

column1: “We are clearly in the phase of our relationship where we’re trying to tell them we’re being diddled
column2: ” said Teresita C. Schaffer
column3: director of the South Asia program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.

column1: But
column2: she added: “We have been trying for a couple of years to decrease our logistical dependence on Pakistan
column3: and have only managed to get it to 80 percent from 90 percent. So
column4: no
column5: we clearly don’t have anyplace else to go.”

column1: The border closing was a clear demonstration of the leverage Pakistan holds over the American war effort. It coincided with a previously scheduled visit by the C.I.A. director
column2: Leon E. Panetta
column3: who met Thursday with the Pakistani military chief
column4: Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani
column5: part of a stream of American officials who have come to alternately cajole and coerce Pakistani cooperation.

column1: On Friday
column2: unidentified assailants in Pakistan attacked and set fire to tankers carrying supplies for NATO troops in Afghanistan
column3: officials told Reuters
column4: apparently in retaliation for the incursions into Pakistani territory. No one was wounded
column5: an official said.

column1: After the border closing on Thursday
column2: Senator John Kerry
column3: the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column4: spoke with Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani
column5: trying to calm the tensions. That conversation followed a telephone call several days ago between Adm. Mike Mullen
column6: the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
column7: and General Kayani

column1: The border closing signaled the limits of Pakistan’s tolerance for intrusions on its sovereignty and for the pressure it was willing to absorb from American officials on any range of issues
column2: despite receiving nearly $2 billion a year in military aid from Washington.

column1: The Pakistani government indicated Thursday that the cross-border strikes were more than it could bear without protest. “We will have to see whether we are allies or enemies
column2: ” said the Pakistani interior minister
column3: Rehman Malik.

column1: At the same time
column2: Pakistani officials tried to contain the damage from a video that came to the attention of American officials in recent days showing the execution of six young men
column3: bound and blindfolded
column4: by Pakistani Army soldiers.

column1: Responding to questions from American officials
column2: Pakistani officials acknowledged Thursday that the video had not been faked
column3: as they had first contended
column4: an American official said
column5: and that they had identified the soldiers and would take appropriate measures.

column1: It is in both the American and the Pakistani interests to keep the relationship going
column2: the official said. The Pakistanis
column3: facing economic collapse after the devastating floods of the summer
column4: need American military aid — some $10 billion since 2001 — which could be cut off from units committing atrocities
column5: the official said.

column1: American commanders are eager to continue C.I.A. drone attacks in Pakistan’s tribal areas that have focused on militants from the Taliban and Al Qaeda who cross the border to attack NATO and American troops. The Pakistani government has agreed to the drone campaign
column2: but could always suspend its permission or shrink the area in which the strikes are allowed.

column1: The country is also the prime supply route for the Afghan war
column2: a fact Pakistani and American officials are both keenly aware of. The vast majority of nonlethal supplies — water
column3: food
column4: vehicles — for the coalition forces in landlocked Afghanistan must travel the length of Pakistan
column5: from the southern port of Karachi to the Afghan border.

column1: Along that route
column2: trucks and fuel tankers have at times been hijacked and attacked by Taliban forces. Pakistani authorities have closed the border crossings only occasionally
column3: however
column4: usually citing security concerns.

column1: But they have rarely appeared to hold up supplies in retaliation for NATO or American actions. In 2008
column2: the Pakistanis closed the border crossing for several days after American aircraft bombed a Pakistani paramilitary post in Mohmand
column3: another tribal area. Eleven Pakistanis were killed in the attack.

column1: American commanders in Afghanistan
column2: long fearful that Pakistan could choke off the supply route more permanently
column3: have been seeking alternate paths through Central Asia
column4: but with little success.

column1: On Thursday
column2: Pakistani officials gave them a glimpse of how much harder they could make the Afghan war. Trucks and oil tankers bound for coalition forces sat idle at the border post of Torkham
column3: just north of Peshawar
column4: with no word on when the post
column5: one of two major land crossings to Afghanistan
column6: would reopen
column7: a Pakistani security official said.

column1: But American officials noted that Pakistan had shut only one of several supply routes to Afghanistan
column2: a sign that the Pakistani government wanted to minimize the episode’s fallout.

column1: “We have many different capabilities
column2: routes
column3: ways to resupply
column4: so there’s no immediate impact
column5: ” Col. Dave Lapan told reporters in Washington. The blocked route
column6: the Khyber Pass
column7: connects the frontier city of Peshawar to Jalalabad

column1: Colonel Lapan said American military officials were also looking into whether all procedures had been followed properly in the cross-border incidents. The Pakistani government took no similar action and made no such public protest after the earlier coalition airstrikes
column2: even though they killed an estimated 55 people inside Pakistan.

column1: Those strikes
column2: on Sept. 24 and Sept. 25
column3: took place on the border separating Khost Province in Afghanistan from North Waziristan. Coalition helicopters fired into Pakistan three times
column4: with one helicopter briefly breaching Pakistani airspace
column5: according to Maj. Sunset Belinsky
column6: a NATO spokeswoman.

column1: In the airstrike on Thursday
column2: a NATO helicopter attacked a border post at Mandati Kandaw
column3: a town close to Parachinar
column4: in the Kurram tribal area
column5: the Pakistani security official said. Three soldiers of Pakistan’s Frontier Corps were killed and three were wounded
column6: he said.

column1: Another border post
column2: at Kharlachi
column3: also in Kurram
column4: was struck a few hours later
column5: the official added. The two posts are about 15 miles apart and border Paktia Province
column6: in Afghanistan.

column1: Jane Perlez reported from Islamabad
column2: Pakistan
column3: and Helene Cooper from Washington. Ismail Khan contributed reporting from Peshawar
column4: Pakistan; Eric Schmitt from Washington; and Alissa J. Rubin from Kabul
column5: Afghanistan.

column1: 146;"Generals in Pakistan Push for Shake-Up of Government (September 29
The authenticity of the five-and-a-half-minute video
column2: which shows the killing of the six men — some of whom appear to be teenagers
column3: blindfolded
column4: with their hands bound behind their backs — has not been formally verified by the American government. The Pakistani military said it was faked by militants.

column1: But American officials
column2: who did not want to be identified because of the explosive nature of the video
column3: said it appeared to be credible
column4: as did retired American military officers and intelligence analysts who have viewed it.

column1: After viewing the graphic video on Wednesday
column2: an administration official said: “There are things you can fake
column3: and things you can’t fake. You can’t fake this.”

column1: The director of the Central Intelligence Agency
column2: Leon E. Panetta
column3: who was in Islamabad on Wednesday on a previously scheduled visit
column4: was expected to raise the subject of the video with the chief of the Pakistani Army
column5: Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani
column6: and the head of the Pakistani spy agency
column7: Lt. Gen. Ahmed Shuja Pasha

column1: The video adds to reports under review at the State Department and the Pentagon that Pakistani Army units have summarily executed prisoners and civilians in areas where they have opened offensives against the Taliban
column2: administration officials said.

column1: The video appears to have been taken in the Swat Valley
column2: where the Pakistani military opened a campaign last year to push back Taliban insurgents. The effort was widely praised by American officials and financed in large part by the United States.

column1: The reports could have serious implications for relations between the militaries. American law requires that the United States cut off financing to units of foreign militaries that are found to have committed gross violations of human rights.
But never has that law been applied to so strategic a partner as Pakistan
column2: whose military has received more than $10 billion in American support since 2001 for its cooperation in fighting militants from the Taliban and Al Qaeda based inside the country.

column1: The State Department spokesman
column2: Philip J. Crowley
column3: called the images “horrifying.” He said the American ambassador
column4: Anne W. Patterson
column5: had raised the issue with the Pakistani government and was awaiting a response. “We are determined to investigate it
column6: ” he said.

column1: The spokesman for the Pakistani Army
column2: Maj. Gen. Athar Abbas
column3: dismissed the video as part of a propaganda campaign by jihadists to defame the Pakistani Army. “No Pakistan Army soldier or officer has been involved in activity of this sort
column4: ” he said.

column1: A senior Pakistani intelligence officer
column2: who declined to be named
column3: dismissed the video as a staged “drama.”

column1: The Pakistani military came under strong pressure from the United States to make the drive into the Swat region. Having since expanded operations to South Waziristan
column2: the military has found itself in a counterinsurgency campaign in which it has struggled to maintain local support and weed out insurgents and their sympathizers from the population.

column1: The video
column2: apparently taken surreptitiously with a cellphone
column3: shows six young men being lined up near an abandoned building surrounded by  foliage. As the soldiers prepare to shoot
column4: one soldier asks the commander
column5: a heavily bearded man with the short hair typical of a military haircut: “One by one
column6: or together?” He replies
column7: “Together.”

column1: A burst of gunfire erupts. The young men crumple to the ground. Some
column2: still alive and wounded
column3: groan. Then a soldier approaches the heap of bodies
column4: and fires rounds into each man at short range to finish the job.

column1: The men doing the shooting wear Pakistani Army uniforms and appear to be using G-3 rifles
column2: standard issue for the Pakistani Army and rarely used by insurgents
column3: according to several Pakistanis who watched the video.

column1: The soldiers also speak Urdu
column2: the language of the Pakistani Army
column3: and use the word “Sahib” when addressing their commander
column4: a polite form for Mr.
column5: which is uncommon among the Taliban.

column1: The question of extrajudicial killings is particularly sensitive for Pentagon officials
column2: who have tried in visits to Pakistan and through increased financing to improve their often-tense relationship with the Pakistani Army.

column1: But growing word of such incidents in recent months has led to an internal debate at the State Department and the Pentagon over whether the reports are credible enough to warrant cutting off funds to Pakistani Army units
column2: American officials said.
