column1: 147;"The Lede Blog: Indian Judges Rule on a Matter of Faith (September 30
Rajanish Kakade/Associated Press

Indian soldiers in front of a mosque in Mumbai on Thursday after a court ruled that a disputed holy site in Ayodhya that has set off bloody communal riots across the country in the past should be divided between the Hindu and Muslim communities. More Photos ¬ª
Rajesh Kumar Singh/Associated Press
An Indian Muslim walked past security personnel in Ayodhya
column2: India
column3: on Thursday More Photos ¬ª

column1: The unorthodox decision by a three-judge panel in the state of Uttar Pradesh provided a Solomonic resolution — if one likely to be appealed to India’s Supreme Court — to a case the authorities had feared might unleash religious violence across India.
Nearly 200
column2: 000 state and federal officers were deployed across Uttar Pradesh as a precaution
column3: as almost every major political figure in the nation
column4: led by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh
column5: appealed for calm and harmony.

column1: The case was considered especially combustible because the contested site
column2: in the city of Ayodhya
column3: was the scene of a searing act of religious violence in 1992 when Hindu extremists tore down an ancient mosque known as the Babri Masjid on the property. The destruction sparked riots that spilled into the following year and have been blamed for about 2
column4: 000 deaths.

column1: Yet that violence did not repeat itself on Thursday evening
column2: as the Indian public absorbed the ruling with a calm that leaders framed as evidence of the nation’s maturation and commitment to religious tolerance.

column1: “I have full faith in the people of India
column2: ” Mr. Singh said in a statement issued after the decision
column3: even as he cautioned against “mischief makers.” “I also have full confidence in the traditions of secularism
column4: brotherhood and tolerance of our great country.”

column1: The opposition Bharatiya Janata Party
column2: or B.J.P.
column3: which rose to national prominence in the 1990s partly because of its advocacy of rebuilding a Hindu temple on the contested site
column4: issued a statement Thursday praising the public’s controlled response as “a new chapter for national integration and a new era for intercommunity relations.”

column1: “The B.J.P. is gratified that the nation has received the verdict with maturity
column2: ” the statement added.

column1: The unexpected decision to divide the property initially suggested a political solution as much as a legal one. But Harish Salve
column2: a former solicitor general of India
column3: said the court had apparently based its decision on historical accounts suggesting that for centuries Hindus and Muslims had worshiped together at the site before they were segregated during British rule in the 1850s.

column1: With this legacy
column2: the court concluded that the entire property should be considered jointly held by Muslims and Hindus and distributed under relevant Indian property statutes
column3: Mr. Salve said
column4: which divide contested properties on the principle of fairness.

column1: “It looks pretty good
column2: ” Mr. Salve said
column3: rating the decision as “9 points out of 10.”

column1: Under the court’s ruling
column2: two-thirds of the land will go to Hindu groups while the remaining third will be awarded to Muslims. Lawyers for Hindus and for Muslims expressed dissatisfaction and promised to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court.

column1: “There is no reason of any loss of hope
column2: ” said Zafaryab Jilana
column3: a lawyer representing one of the Muslim parties to the case
column4: speaking on national television. “We do not agree with the formula of giving one-third of the land to Muslims.”

column1: The case required the judicial panel to wade deeply into India’s contested religious history. Lawyers for Hindu groups had argued that the Ayodhya site was the birthplace of one of Hinduism’s most revered deities
column2: Ram. They contended that a temple to Ram had existed on the site until it was demolished to make way for the Babri Masjid
column3: constructed in the 16th century by India’s first Mughal ruler.

column1: Soon after the judges read the decision in a closed hearing
column2: lawyers rushed to hundreds of reporters waiting outside the courthouse in Lucknow
column3: the capital of Uttar Pradesh. “The judgment is in favor of Hindus
column4: ” said H. S. Jain
column5: a lawyer for one of the Hindu groups in the case. “The belief of Hindus that this is the birthplace of Ram is upheld.”

column1: But each of the three judges issued a separate opinion
column2: diverging in interpretation of certain facts
column3: including over whether Ram was born precisely on the contested site. Yet the court did hand a significant victory to Hindus
column4: who had argued that Ram was born beneath the central dome of the destroyed structure. That portion of the contested property was granted to Hindus as part of their two-thirds share
column5: presumably to erect a new temple to Ram.

column1: The original case was filed in 1950 and then expanded over the years as more parties claimed title to the property. The Indian government now controls the property
column2: and the court ordered that the status quo remain intact for the next three months. Assuming both sides follow through with filing appeals to the Supreme Court
column3: the case could continue indefinitely.

column1: The initial quiet public response was a relief to Indian officials. Earlier
column2: Palaniappan Chidambaram
column3: the home minister
column4: had predicted that the public would respect the court’s finding.

column1: “I think India has moved on
column2: young people have moved on
column3: ” he told the Indian news media.

column1: The oldest plaintiff
column2: Hashim Ansari
column4: a Muslim tailor who had prayed at the Babri Masjid as a boy
column5: said he would not take part in any appeal. He  joined the case in 1961 and had looked forward to a ruling as a matter of closure. He called Thursday’s decision a good judgment and hoped that efforts could soon begin to rebuild a mosque on the  land granted to Muslims.

column1: Of course
column2: he added
column3: the timing will depend on appeals.

column1: “It took 60 years to get this decision
column2: ” he said by telephone. “I do not know how many years the Supreme Court will take. At least I could hear this judgment on my own. Will I hear the Supreme Court judgment in my grave?”

column1: Hari Kumar contributed reporting.
A version of this article appeared in print on October 1
column3: on page A4 of the New York edition.

column1: 148;"Reprints
KABUL
column2: Afghanistan — With extraordinary effort
column3: the Afghan government and Western aid programs have modestly reduced poppy cultivation in the country’s largest opium -producing province in the past year
column4: but cultivation nationwide remained at last year’s levels and in two provinces increased sharply
column5: according to the annual report released Thursday by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime .

column1: Cultivation is a leading measure of farmers’ openness to growing alternative crops. Production
column2: the other measure most frequently cited
column3: was down sharply in the past year because of a blight that decreased the yield by 48 percent. Over all
column4: that meant that Afghanistan produced almost 4
column5: 000 tons.  The information in the United Nations report is gathered by a combination of aerial surveillance and  on-the-ground interviews with farmers
column6: security force members
column7: prosecutors and others who track narcotics.

column1: In Helmand Province
column2: cultivation dropped 7 percent. In a swath of land along the Helmand River Valley
column3: where there has been an enormous focus by NATO troops and international reconstruction workers
column4: the acreage open for cultivation of vegetables and staple crops increased somewhat
column5: according to a counternarcotics expert from the British Embassy
column6: who was not authorized to speak publicly on the subject.

column1: Yury Fedotov
column2: executive director of the United Nations agency
column3: said
column4: “This is good news
column5: but there is no room for false optimism.”

column1: The decrease in production appeared to be primarily the result of the blight
column2: but it was a positive sign that the overall area under cultivation at least did not expand in the past year
column3: according to Afghan and United Nations narcotics experts.

column1: However
column2: experts said they were worried that skyrocketing poppy prices could undercut the efforts to reduce cultivation in the coming year. The price farmers were paid by traffickers rose to about $58 per pound in 2010 from $22 per pound in 2009
column3: making opium poppy a more attractive crop financially than alternatives like wheat in the impoverished rural areas of the country.

column1: “The market may again become lucrative for poppy crop growers
column2: ” Mr. Fedotov said.

column1: Helmand was the brightest spot in the main southern and western poppy-growing regions. In neighboring Kandahar Province
column2: cultivation rose 30 percent
column3: and in Farah Province cultivation was up 17 percent.

column1: Almost all cultivation took place in nine provinces in the southern and western region
column2: which are among Afghanistan’s least secure. Twenty of the country’s 34 provinces are poppy free
column3: and that number has now held steady for two years.

column1: “Ninety-eight percent of poppy cultivation takes place in the provinces where security is not good
column2: ” said Zarar Ahmad Muqbil
column3: the Afghan minister for counternarcotics.

column1: Diplomats who track poppy production attribute the decrease in Helmand’s cultivation levels despite the increased price of poppy in part to the efforts of the provincial governor
column2: Gulab Mangal
column3: who has been among the most active of Afghanistan’s leaders in trying to reduce poppy cultivation. They also credit an array of international programs that spent hundreds of millions of dollars on seed and fertilizer subsidies
column4: irrigation canal cleaning and market reconstruction.

column1: In the past few years
column2: many markets had been closed or sharply constrained by insurgent activity. With more than 10
column3: 000 coalition troops in Helmand
column4: though
column5: the area has become somewhat more secure. It is still one of the most unstable and deadly parts of Afghanistan.

column1: Governor Mangal eradicated about 10
column2: 000 acres of poppies
column3: more than in any other province
column4: and while eradication is widely viewed as useful only if it is paired with other support programs
column5: in some areas of Helmand it has been. By contrast
column6: in Kandahar
column7: just under 160 acres were eradicated in 2010
column10: has not pursued a comprehensive program to reduce poppy cultivation.

column1: In Kandahar on Thursday
column2: a suicide bomber attacked a NATO convoy
column3: killing three Afghan civilians and wounding nine others on the main highway near the vast coalition base at the Kandahar airfield
column4: according to Zalmai Ayoubi
column5: a spokesman for Governor Torylai.  A coalition spokesman said there was no information yet on whether there were NATO casualties.

column1: Five NATO service members were killed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday
column2: according to a NATO spokesman who said that four of them  died when roadside bombs exploded. NATO also said that it inadvertently killed four Afghan civilians and injured three others in a strike in Ghazni Province on Wednesday.

column1: Taimoor Shah contributed reporting from Kandahar
column2: Afghanistan
column3: and Sharifullah Sahak from Kabul.

column1: 149;"Enlarge This Image
Reuters Television
Kim Jong-un
column2: center
column3: the youngest son of North Korean leader Kim Jong-il
column4: attended a meeting of the ruling Workers’ Party in Pyongyang on Tuesday.

column1: The photo was published in the Thursday issue of North Korea’s main newspaper
column2: Rodong Shinmun
column3: and showed him in a dark suit with his father and a large group of senior Workers’ Party officials. He bears a strong resemblance to his father and
column4: some thought
column5: his grandfather
column6: Kim Il-sung
column7: North Korea’s founder.

column1: Video broadcast on television showed Kim Jong-un sitting in the front row of the Workers Party meeting this week
column2: among a group of senior leaders.

column1: This week
column2: at a landmark meeting of the Workers’ Party in the capital
column3: Pyongyang
column4: the younger Mr. Kim
column5: who is believed to be 27 or 28
column6: was given the rank of four-star general in the People’s Army and was named a deputy chairman of the party’s military commission. He also became a member of the party’s Central Committee
column7: an ideological and policy-making post.

column1: In the photograph
column2: Kim Jong-un
column3: chubby and looking somewhat older than his years
column4: was seated two spots to his father’s right and next to another rising star
column5: Vice Marshal Ri Yong-ho
column6: seated between them.

column1: Mr. Ri
column3: whose military rank as vice marshal places him over Kim Jong-un
column4: was named to the country’s powerful Politburo this week and also was made a deputy chairman of the party’s military commission. The vice marshal
column5: who has served as chief of the army general staff
column6: is seen as a seasoned officer with substantial field experience. South Korean news media reports have suggested that he guided Kim Jong-un in his fast-track military training over the last year and he is expected to be Mr. Kim’s tutor and guide in political and military matters.

column1: Analysts and diplomats in Washington will be watching for “the gradual insertion of the Young General into the policy and decision-making apparatus
column2: ” said Evans J. R. Revere
column3: a longtime United States diplomat in South Korea and Asia who is diplomat in residence and lecturer at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton. Young General is a title used by North Korean news media to refer to the younger Mr. Kim.

column1: “There have been several reports that he had been given a lower-level position in the National Defense Commission some months back
column2: ” Mr. Revere said
column3: “and I expect that there have been similar efforts to expose him to the government
column4: military and party decision-making process over the past two years.”

column1: The new North Korean appointments seemed not to have any immediate effect on North-South relations
column2: which have been strained by the sinking in March of the South Korean warship Cheonan . While the two sides’ militaries met for the first time in two years on Thursday
column3: the talks ended with no apparent progress and no new meetings scheduled
column4: according to an official with South Korea’s Defense Ministry.

column1: The talks began at 10 a.m. in the border village of Panmunjom and adjourned at 11:45 a.m.
column2: said the Defense Ministry official
column3: who was not authorized to speak publicly on the matter. He declined to discuss the mood of the meeting.

column1: He said South Korea demanded an apology for the Cheonan sinking
column2: which Seoul has attributed to a North Korean torpedo attack. The sinking
column3: which occurred along the two Koreas’ disputed western sea border
column4: killed 46 South Korean sailors.

column1: The North has denied any involvement in the Cheonan sinking and on Thursday proposed that South Korea accept a team of investigators from the North. The South refused the request
column2: the defense official said.

column1: A statement by the United Nations Security Council in July expressed “deep concern” over the Cheonan sinking
column2: but did not find North Korea culpable. The North Korean ambassador to the United Nations told reporters at the time that the finding was “a great diplomatic victory.”

column1: Lee Sung-yoon
column2: a professor at the Fletcher School at Tufts University
column3: said North Korea “has closed the chapter on the Cheonan
column4: ” citing the United Nations statement. “They’re saying
column5: ‘Let’s move on
column6: ’¬†” he said.

column1: The renewal of working-level military talks was proposed this month by the North Koreans
column2: apparently to focus on preventing naval clashes along the disputed sea border
column3: known as the Northern Limit Line. The North has also been angered by airborne leaflets sent across the border by South Korean activists. The leaflets
column4: which criticize and ridicule Kim Jong-il
column5: call on North Koreans to rise up against his government.

column1: Political analysts in Seoul were reluctant to connect the sudden resumption of military negotiations to what appeared to be the emergence of Kim Jong-un as the eventual successor to his father.
The North’s official Korean Central News Agency also on Thursday released a new list of the rosters of various party organizations
column2: along with the appointments made at the Workers’ Party meeting this week in Pyongyang.

column1: 150;"Reprints
BEIJING — After a night of wining and dining 50 of China’s richest people in the name of promoting philanthropy
column2: Warren Buffett and Bill Gates told a horde of journalists on Thursday that the biggest difference between eating with Chinese tycoons and Western ones was the food.

column1: Enlarge This Image
How Hwee Young/European Pressphoto Agency
Berkshire Hathaway C.E.O. Warren Buffett
column2: left
column3: with Microsoft founder Bill Gates during a press conference in Beijing on Thursday.

column1: Related
Thus ended the two billionaires’ mission to promote charity in China
column2: a journey that provoked weeks of breathless speculation here about whether this nation’s much resented class of superrich was too miserly to measure up to Western philanthropic standards.

column1: At a news conference
column2: Mr. Buffett and Mr. Gates said the answer was an emphatic “no.”

column1: “I was amazed last night
column2: really
column3: at how similar the questions and discussions and all that was to the dinners we had in the U.S.
column4: ” said Mr. Buffett
column5: who had wisecracked about the food. “The same motivations tend to exist. The mechanism for manifesting those motivations may differ from country to country.”

column1: Mr. Buffett and Mr. Gates
column2: two of the best known and most admired Westerners here
column3: announced last month that they planned to invite 50 wealthy Chinese entrepreneurs to dinner in Beijing to encourage philanthropy among China’s new rich. The mission became the subject of feverish news coverage — and something of a litmus test of Chinese generosity — after it was reported that some tycoons were turning down the invitation because they feared they would be pressed to donate money.

column1: The two men have made headlines worldwide for enlisting Western tycoons in a public promise to give away their fortunes either during their lifetimes or in bequests after their deaths. To date
column2: 40 people have taken the pledge
column3: and at least one Chinese multimillionaire has said he will join them.

column1: On Thursday
column2: the two men pronounced the dinner an unqualified success
column3: saying that two-thirds of those who were invited had shown up
column4: and that more than half of them had offered their own ideas on how Chinese philanthropy should work.

column1: The guest list was not made public
column2: but the Chinese news media reported that it included Jet Li
column3: the movie star; Niu Gensheng
column4: the founder of a Chinese dairy business; and Pan Shiyi and Zhang Xin
column5: who control the SOHO China real estate empire.

column1: As with four earlier dinners held in the United States
column2: Mr. Buffett and Mr. Gates said
column3: no one at the Beijing event was asked to donate money or to promise to engage in charity. While they have made follow-up telephone calls to some previous guests
column4: Mr. Buffett said: “Bill and I will not be calling anybody. What happens in China will depend on what the Chinese people feel about a project of this sort.”

column1: China is widely reported to be second only to the United States in the number of dollar billionaires. Mr. Gates and Mr. Buffett said the nation was unique in that its wealthy class had arisen almost wholly in the past 30 years
column2: so philanthropic practices that are entrenched among European and American dynasties are new here
column3: and open to change.

column1: “What you have is a first generation of fortune
column2: ” Mr. Gates said
column3: “and it’s natural that they’re thinking through
column4: in this society in particular
column5: ‘What do you do?’¬†”

column1: The two said the dinner was not a long planned matter
column2: but an offshoot of a trip that Mr. Buffett had already scheduled to Guangdong and Hunan Provinces
column3: where BYD Company
column4: a maker of clean-energy automobiles
column5: has factories. Mr. Buffett’s investment conglomerate
column6: Berkshire Hathaway
column7: holds a 10 percent stake in the company.

column1: “Bill and I did not sit down
column2: take a map of the world
column3: and say
column4: ‘We’re going to go to that one and that one and that one
column5: ’¬†” Mr. Buffett said.

column1: But Mr. Gates suggested that their philanthropic globetrotting was not yet over. “We may do an event in India
column2: ” he said.

column1: 151;"Reprints
BEIJING — Chinese authorities have released three of four Japanese citizens who were accused last week of videotaping at a military installation in northern China
column2: state media reported on Thursday.

column1: Although one of the detained men remains in custody
column2: the releases are likely to be construed as a modest attempt by China to reduce tensions that have been mounting since Sept. 7
column3: when a collision between a Chinese fishing trawler and Japanese coast guard vessels in disputed waters prompted an ugly diplomatic row between the countries.

column1: In announcing the releases
column2: the official news service
column3: Xinhua
column4: said the three men had admitted that they had violated Chinese law and “showed regret for their mistake.”

column1: But it said that the fourth man
column2: Sada Takahashi
column3: would remain under “house arrest” while the authorities continued their investigation. Xinhua described the accusations against him as “illegally videotaping military targets.” The men
column4: who were arrested on  Sept. 23
column5: were detained at a military installation in Shijiazhuang
column6: a city in Hebei Province
column7: not far from Beijing.

column1: The Japanese foreign minister
column2: Seiji Maehara
column3: called on China to free Mr. Takahashi and explain the reasons behind the detentions
column4: which came on the same day that Japan
column5: under immense pressure from China
column6: released the  captain of the trawler
column7: who was accused of deliberately ramming Japanese boats.

column1: “I want to seek a quick resolution
column2: ” Mr. Maehara said
column3: referring to the remaining detainee.

column1: Yutaka Banno
column2: the state secretary for foreign affairs
column3: told reporters that a Japanese Embassy official had spoken by telephone with the three men who were freed and confirmed their safety.

column1: “We will ask China to ensure the safety of the remaining one
column2: our continued access to him and a quick settlement of the case from a humanitarian standpoint
column3: ” Mr. Banno said.

column1: Officials at Fujita
column2: the construction company that employed the men
column3: said that at the time of their arrest they were inspecting a potential construction site for a plant that would process abandoned chemical weapons. Fujita built a similar plant in Nanjing that disposes of munitions abandoned by Japanese forces  during its occupation of China
column4: the company said in a news release.

column1: The release of the three men came  amid signs that the diplomatic standoff between Japan and China may be easing
column2: although neither side has made any broad gestures of reconciliation.

column1: The dispute between the countries stems from conflicting territorial claims over a chain of uninhabited islands in the East China Sea that Japan controls.
On Thursday
column2: Prime Minister Naoto Kan reiterated Japan’s claim over the islands
column3: known as the Senkaku in Japan and the Diaoyu in China.

column1: “Territorial problems don’t exist between Japan and China
column2: ” he told Parliament.

column1: Later in the day
column2: a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman urged Tokyo to stop making “irresponsible remarks.” “We are willing to resolve our disputes through friendly negotiations
column3: but the Chinese government’s and people’s will and resolve are unswerving on issues involving China’s territorial integrity and sovereignty
column4: ” Jiang Yu
column5: the spokeswoman
column6: said during a regular news conference.

column1: In the meantime
column2: Chinese shipments of rare earths to Japan have yet to resume
column3: although some industry officials said the refusal of Chinese customs officials to process export applications had eased slightly since they were halted last week. The Chinese Commerce Ministry has denied that there is even an export ban on the minerals
column4: which are crucial to Japanese manufacturers.

column1: Martin Fackler contributed reporting from Tokyo.

column2: a gesture likely to be seen as a way to ease tensions between the two countries.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: 152;"Enlarge This Image
Diego Azubel/European Pressphoto Agency
Construction sites dot Beijing
column2: a sign of China's robust economy. China's leaders will soon unveil a new Five-Year Plan.

column1: The Chinese Communist Party’s annual plenum
column2: a chance for top officials across the country to hash out strategy
column3: will meet from Oct. 15 to 18
column4: according to a government statement on Tuesday.

column1: But already
column2: the country’s political classes are chattering about what may or may not happen at this secretive gathering.

column1: The only firm piece of business known to be on the agenda is the country’s Five-Year Plan
column2: which could move China toward a less export-oriented economic model — with implications for issues like the United States trade deficit. It is also likely that officials will begin to determine the succession to the leadership duo of President Hu Jintao and Prime Minister Wen Jiabao
column3: both of whom are to retire in two years.

column1: But it is the talk about political reform that makes this year’s meeting intriguing. Some officials have been calling for an overhaul of the country’s political system
column2: saying it is dominated by powerful interest groups that are shutting out innovation and hurting the Chinese people. Others at the top have been silent or have explicitly rejected such talk.

column1: “Some in the leadership are concerned with rising tensions due to inequality of wealth
column2: the demolition of people’s homes
column3: the petitioners — there is a sense that something needs to be done
column4: ” said Victor Shih
column5: a professor of political science at Northwestern University .

column1: “At the same time they know it’s a dangerous game; in the past when the party signaled some loosening
column2: protests have coalesced that went beyond the ruling party’s control.”

column1: To many
column2: China hardly seems in need of a system overhaul. The country weathered the global financial crisis with robust economic growth
column3: overtaking Japan this year as the world’s second largest economy. For several years
column4: some foreign pundits have praised a “Beijing consensus” of market reforms and a strong central government that can make tough but unpopular decisions as a model for other developing countries.

column1: But on the ground
column2: the situation is far messier. Recent growth has been bolstered by a large stimulus package
column3: not the bold changes that characterized China’s economic takeoff in the 1980s and ’90s. The last serious reform push took place early last decade when the country was joining the World Trade Organization . Since then
column4: the pendulum has swung back to strong state involvement
column5: with quasi-monopolistic state enterprises crowding out private enterprise.

column1: Liberal economists in Beijing have been warning about the long-term dangers of this trend. One of the chief economic thinkers
column2: Yao Yang
column3: a Peking University professor
column4: published an article earlier this year that encapsulated their views. Writing in the journal Foreign Affairs
column5: he argued that in decades past the Communist Party took relatively unbiased positions on economic matters
column6: allowing it to defy vested interests and choose pro-growth policies.

column1: Now
column2: the party has become closely intertwined with China’s biggest businesses — which are mostly state owned and directly managed by the party. At the same time
column3: it remains atop a one-party state with few checks and balances
column4: giving those businesses insurmountable advantages over private enterprises and citizens. Critics say that that power structure worsens China’s inequality and cannot be easily rectified without systematic changes. Professor Yao’s concluded that “ultimately there is no alternative to greater democratization.”

column1: In August
column2: speaking in Shenzhen
column3: the Chinese city that pioneered many economic changes
column4: Prime Minister Wen echoed these arguments in a speech carried by the party’s flagship daily
column5: People’s Daily .

column1: “Without the guarantee of political system reform
column2: the successes of restructuring the economic system will be lost and the goal of modernization cannot be realized
column3: ” Mr. Wen said
column4: according to the article on his speech.

column1: When Chinese leaders talk about political reform they often mean making the administrative system more efficient or open
column2: but not democratic in a Western sense. Some analysts
column3: like Russell Leigh Moses
column4: who is based in Beijing
column5: think Mr. Wen’s speech was meant to be an attempt to advocate more sweeping changes.

column1: “There are forces within the government that believe administrative reform has run its course
column2: ” Mr. Moses said. “And now it’s time to get into the nub of the challenge facing China
column3: which is
column4: what sort of polity do you want?”

column1: What does seem clear is that Mr. Wen’s call has exposed differing priorities among senior leaders. Also speaking in Shenzhen
column2: which was celebrating the 30th anniversary of its creation as a Special Economic Zone
column3: President Hu did not mention political reform. More pointedly
column4: the country’s head of security
column5: Zhou Yongkang
column6: rejected political reform. In an article carried in the party’s main theoretical journal
column7: Qiushi
column8: Mr. Zhou wrote that some party members had been influenced by “erroneous Western political and legal ideas.”

column1: Mr. Wen
column2: however
column3: reiterated his support for political reform last week
column4: albeit in a less influential setting. Speaking to Chinese-American business people in New York
column5: Mr. Wen said political reform would lead to “a relaxed political environment
column6: so people can better express their independent spirit and creativity.”

column1: The link between these arguments and this year’s economic plan is that few observers can see substantive economic changes taking place without curbing the party’s power.
“Wen’s speech is part of a discussion on the structure of growth
column2: ” said Arthur Kroeber
column3: the managing director of the Beijing-based economic research group Dragonomics. “China needs a little less of growth at all costs.”

column1: That could be reflected in the main topic of discussion at the plenum
column2: the country’s Five-Year Plan. In years past
column3: the plan has set firm targets for economic growth
column4: usually 8 percent
column5: which Mr. Kroeber said was a signal to local leaders that all that mattered was growth — regardless of the social or political costs. This led to large-scale land expropriations in Chinese cities
column6: rampant pollution and a preference for state monopolies.  Now
column7: he said
column8: the hope among many economists in Beijing is that the party will back off its growth target
column9: signaling that it will accept slower growth in exchange for real changes.

column1: During the plenum
column2: the country’s future leader
column3: Xi Jinping
column4: is likely to be appointed to the Central Military Commission. A position overseeing military affairs is the last major appointment Mr. Xi needs to round out his r√©sum√© and cement his position as heir to President Hu
column5: who currently leads the military commission.

column1: Last year
column2: Mr. Xi was also expected to have been appointed to the slot
column3: but he was not. Political analysts are unsure of how to interpret this
column4: but the consensus among China watchers is that Mr. Xi’s position is secure
column5: and he is likely to receive the military post soon.

column1: Michael Wines contributed reporting.
A version of this article appeared in print on September 30
column3: on page A14 of the New York edition.

column1: 153;"Chinese Developers Tap Into Japanese Insecurity
Hiro Komae for The New York Times
A community hot spring in Misasa
column2: a resort town in Japan. Chinese investors are planning to build vacation homes nearby.

column1: MISASA
column2: Japan — A plan by Chinese real estate developers to invest in this little mountain town has opened a window onto a Japanese crisis of confidence.

column1: Add to Portfolio
Hiro Komae for The New York Times
Kiyomi Kawakami
column2: left
column3: is working with Chinese partners to build 47 luxury homes in Misasa.

column1: For locals here
column2: the planned development — vacation homes for rich Chinese — is a welcome infusion of capital into a town that has been in decline since its heyday in the 1980s as a hot spring resort.

column1: But seen from elsewhere in Japan — there have been news accounts in the national media
column2: not all of them accurate — the investment is a menace to the area’s pristine forests and streams
column3: a land grab that threatens the country’s natural resources and a chilling reminder of the expanding shadow cast by China
column4: which recently surpassed Japan to become the world’s second-largest economy after the United States.

column1: “Targeted by Foreign Money? Japan’s Forests for Sale
column2: ” was the warning title of a news program this month by the public broadcaster
column3: NHK.

column1: A fear that “China money” is buying up the Japanese homeland is spreading across this nation
column2: fanned by news reports and a general anxiety over Tokyo’s fading economic prowess and an increasingly hostile wealthy neighbor. The amount of money invested is still small by China’s standards
column3: but seems to be setting off an outsize reaction among the Japanese.

column1: Tokyo’s recent retreat from the diplomatic face-off over the arrest of a Chinese trawler captain
column2: and China’s suspension of shipments of vital industrial metals and minerals to Japan
column3: have also put many Japanese on edge.

column1: “I’m all for closer ties with China
column2: but we need to be on our guard
column3: ” said Hideki Hirano
column4: author of the book “Japan’s Forests Under Siege: How Foreign Capital Threatens Our Water Source
column5: ” which was published in March. “We need to be more vigilant about who’s buying what.”

column1: Here in Misasa
column2: however
column3: nationalist rhetoric is often tempered by pragmatism.

column1: “Rich Chinese spend money in ways that no longer exist in Japan
column2: ” said Kiyomi Kawakami
column3: a local developer who plans to build 47 luxury homes in Misasa with partners from Shanghai.

column1: “People warn me not to sell land to the Chinese
column2: ” he said. “But I run a business. If somebody’s buying
column3: I’m selling.”

column1: Whether in far-flung corners of Japan like Misasa or in corporate boardrooms
column2: there is a realization that as the Chinese economy booms
column3: Japan needs — even as it remains wary of — China’s money.

column1: The sentiment is reminiscent of the way Americans feared Japanese economic imperialism in the 1980s
column2: alarmed by the acquisition of United States icons like Rockefeller Center by Mitsubishi and Columbia Pictures by Sony .

column1: Chinese companies spent $120 million in the first half of this year to acquire various small and midsize Japanese enterprises
column2: taking advantage of depressed asset prices
column3: according to a recent report from Goldman Sachs . The figure represents a sixfold increase from the comparable period last year. China is also now Japan’s biggest trading partner
column4: with overall trade surging by a third
column5: to 12.6 trillion yen ($151 billion) in the first half of the year
column6: compared with the same period last year.

column1: “We shouldn’t think it a bad thing that foreign investors are recognizing value in Japan
column2: ” said Kazuhiko Masumoto
column3: an analyst at the Mitsubishi Research Institute in Tokyo.

column1: But Japan’s finance ministry has seemed slow to agree.
This month
column2: Japan’s finance minister
column3: Yoshihiko Noda
column4: asked Chinese policy makers to “clarify their objectives” after recent bulk purchases of Japanese government bonds. Tokyo was concerned that the buying was helping to drive up the yen’s value — making Japan’s exports less competitive with China’s.

column1: Bowing to economic realities
column2: and Japan’s already high levels of public debt
column3: Finance Ministry officials have since then played down the conflict
column4: saying Japan was happy to find foreign takers of its government bonds.

column1: Until the trawler dispute prompted some tour groups to at least temporarily cancel trips to Japan
column2: waves of newly rich Chinese tourists
column3: with pocketbooks open
column4: had been welcomed in Japan — even while heightening a sense that the country is at the mercy of rich Chinese.

column1: Reports of Chinese snapping up Japan’s mountains and forests have struck a raw nerve
column2: however. Although Japan is known for its big cities
column3: about 70 percent of its landmass is mountainous forest
column4: and the purchases raise the specter of China’s gaining control of the cherished hinterlands.

column1: Japan’s logging industry is in decline
column2: as the country has been flooded with cheap imported timber. As a result
column3: forest real estate now sells for rock-bottom prices
column4: and many plots have been abandoned by absentee or aged owners and have fallen into a state of neglect.

column1: In January
column2: the Tokyo Foundation
column3: a respected independent research organization where Mr. Hirano
column4: the author
column5: is an analyst
column6: issued a widely read report warning that foreign brokers could extract natural resources like timber and water and threaten Japan’s national security.

column1: “If we wait until the exploitation of Japan’s natural resources by global interests is well under way
column2: ” the report said
column3: “it may be too late.”

column2: especially land deals.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: 154;"Firdia Lisnawati/Associated Press
A Balinese volunteer prepares to give rabies vaccination to a dog in Pararean
column2: Bali.

column1: But since the first recorded human death from rabies in Bali in late 2008
column2: that nuisance has become a mounting public danger as the virus — believed to have arrived with an infected dog from another part of the Indonesian archipelago — has spread with increasing speed. Forty-one rabies deaths have been confirmed
column3: and dozens more are suspected.

column1: No foreigners have died from the disease
column2: but the outbreak is causing concern abroad
column3: and countries including the United States and Australia have issued travel warnings this year because of it.

column1: This week
column2: the Balinese authorities and a nonprofit group
column3: the Bali Animal Welfare Association
column4: began a mass dog vaccination campaign
column5: funded largely with foreign assistance. Moving from village to village
column6: the teams’ goal is to vaccinate 400
column7: 000 animals
column8: roughly 70 percent of the island’s dog population
column9: by the end of the year. Rabies is present in dogs in more than 200 of Bali’s 700 or so villages
column11: the head of the provincial animal husbandry department.

column1: Officials hope that the campaign
column2: along with follow-up rounds in the next two years
column3: will curb the disease by 2012. Still
column4: experts and officials acknowledge that an earlier
column5: failed approach; funding shortfalls; bureaucratic inflexibility; and Bali’s own culture delayed concerted action.

column1: The death of Made Cawi
column2: a 70-year-old grandmother from Mambal
column3: a rice-farming village
column4: illustrates the problem. Coming home one day in July
column5: she complained of a stiff jaw
column6: a fever and difficulty swallowing. By the next day she had been hospitalized
column7: and within three days she was dead

column1: “She was always getting fevers
column2: ” Mr. Kasna said. “I thought it was just something mild. I didn’t think it would turn out like this.”

column1: Like many Balinese
column2: Ms. Cawi lived cheek by jowl with pigs
column3: ducks
column4: chickens and dogs
column5: which freely wander the island’s streets. Dog bites have long been a fact of life on Bali
column6: regarded as little more than an inconvenience.

column1: But earlier in the year
column2: after Ms. Cawi was bitten by a dog
column3: her son took her to a hospital for post-exposure treatment. She was administered just two doses of a three-injection vaccine course and sent home early with assurances that she was healthy
column4: her son said.

column1: Months later
column2: rabies killed her. Dr. Dwi Tresnaningsih
column3: head of disease surveillance at the local community health center
column4: said it was common practice to end post-exposure treatment if the animal suspected of causing the infection did not die within two weeks. She said it was likely that Ms. Cawi was later bitten by a different animal but did not report it.

column1: One obstacle to controlling the rabies problem has been that Bali’s majority Hindu population is extremely fond of dogs
column2: unlike Indonesians from other parts of the country
column3: whose adherence to Islam means that many see dogs as unclean animals. On Bali
column4: an island with a population of 3.5 million people
column5: there are about 600
column6: 000 dogs.

column1: “We’re very close to dogs because in our religion
column2: dogs accompany people to heaven
column3: ” said Mr. Sumantra
column4: the animal husbandry department chief.

column1: Balinese tend to mingle freely with stray dogs
column2: and even most dogs that have owners are allowed to run between homes and streets as semi-strays.

column1: The island’s first attempt to combat the outbreak was an unsuccessful culling campaign in which 100
column2: 000 dogs were killed. Particularly in the early days of the outbreak
column3: Balinese were loath to hand over dogs for culling
column4: said Nyoman Sutedja
column5: the head of Bali’s health department. Workers were faced with angry locals; in one case
column6: in the tourist region of Sanur
column7: a government worker was attacked

column1: With Bali having long been rabies-free
column2: and with dog bites such a common part of life
column3: most people were unaware of the dangers
column4: Mr. Sutedja said. “People in the villages just think
column5: ‘No one has ever died from dog bites
column6: so why is there rabies now?”’

column1: Local sensitivities aside
column2: culling was bound to have failed
column3: said Fran√ßois-Xavier Meslin
column4: leader of the World Health Organization ’s Neglected Zoonotic Diseases team in Geneva.

column1: 155;"Koreas Plan to Hold Talks on Military
column2: South Says

column1: Korea Central News Agency
column2: via Reuters

column1: North Korea on Wednesday released a photo of soldiers attending an event to congratulate leader Kim Jong-il on his re-election as general secretary of the Workers’ Party of Korea at the Jeonseung Plaza in Pyongyang.
By MARK McDONALD
Reprints
SEOUL
column2: South Korea — Just a day after a new leadership structure had taken shape  in North Korea
column3: with the youngest son of the nation’s leader being awarded major military and political posts
column4: the South Korean Defense Ministry said that the two Koreas held military talks on Thursday at the border village of Panmunjom.

column1: Related
Enlarge This Image
Korea Central News Agency
column2: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

column1: North Korea on Wednesday released a photo taken Tuesday of leader Kim Jong-Il
column2: center
column3: sitting in front of a statue of his father
column4: Kim Il-Sung
column5: as he attended the Conference of the Workers’ Party of Korea in Pyongyang.

column1: The two sides had not held such talks in two years.
A South Korean defense official
column2: speaking on the condition of anonymity
column3: declined to discuss the agenda of the working-level meeting. But it was widely expected that South Korea would raise the issue of the sinking of one of its warships in March.

column1: The renewal of military talks with the South was proposed this month by the North Koreans
column2: apparently to focus on preventing naval clashes along their disputed western sea border.

column1: Political analysts in Seoul were reluctant to connect the sudden resumption of military negotiations to what appeared to be the emergence of the son
column2: Kim Jong-un
column3: as the eventual successor to his father
column4: Kim Jong-il
column5: as the supreme North Korean leader. The younger Mr. Kim
column6: who is believed to be 27 or 28
column7: was given the rank of four-star general in the People’s Army and was named a deputy chairman of the military commission of the Workers’ Party.

column1: A senior military post for Kim Jong-un was a prerequisite for his ascendancy to power. His father’s “military first” doctrine  has given the armed forces the leading role in the political life of the country
column2: even ahead of the Workers’ Party. Any future leader of North Korea would need a substantial military paragraph on his or her r√©sum√©.

column1: Kim Jong-un’s other significant new positions — he now has a seat on the party’s Central Committee and is one of two deputy chairmen of the party’s military commission — are seen as more purely political and policy-making posts. The military commission’s other new deputy chairman is Vice Marshal Ri Yong-ho. A seasoned military officer
column2: Marshal Ri
column4: has been chief of the army’s general staff. He was also given a seat on the party’s Politburo
column5: making him a superior of the younger Mr. Kim
column6: whom he is expected to tutor and guide.

column1: “Ri should be seen as the right-hand man for the inexperienced Kim Jong-un in the military
column2: ” Cheong Seong-chang
column3: a North Korea expert at Sejong Institute near Seoul
column4: told the Yonhap News Agency.  He will “play a crucial role in the transfer of power from Kim Jong-il to Kim Jong-un
column5: ” Mr. Cheong said.

column1: But other analysts said the changes were not likely to be well received by North Koreans who see the dynastic succession as a contradiction of the state’s Communist ideology.
“This kind of succession is very rare
column2: and the ordinary North Korean people won’t like it
column3: ” said Yun Duk-kim
column4: a North Korea expert and a professor at the Institute of Foreign Affairs and National Security in Seoul. But
column5: he added: “It’s difficult for people to show their displeasure
column6: of course. It’s a totalitarian system. They just obey.”

column1: The North was also thought to have objected to propaganda leaflets that were dropped over the border by South Korean activists. The leaflets talked about Kim Jong-il’s frailty and his lavish lifestyle in the face of widespread hunger. They called on North Koreans to rise up against the regime.
South Korea and the United States have blamed a North Korean torpedo attack for the sinking of its ship
column2: the Cheonan
column3: which killed 46 sailors. Seoul has demanded an apology from the North
column4: which has denied any involvement.

column1: A statement by the United Nations Security Council in July expressed “deep concern” over the Cheonan’s sinking
column2: but did not find North Korea culpable. The North Korean ambassador told reporters that the statement was “a great diplomatic victory.”

column1: Lee Sung-yoon
column2: a professor at the Fletcher School at Tufts University
column3: said Wednesday that North Korea “has closed the chapter on the Cheonan” since the United Nations statement. “They’re saying
column4: ‘Let’s move on
column5: ’¬†” he said.

column1: Analysts in Seoul said that North Korea was unlikely to apologize — at least not officially or publicly. But others did not rule it out.
A version of this article appeared in print on September 30
column3: on page A20 of the New York edition.

column1: 157;"Divided Parliament Opens in Australia
By MERAIAH FOLEY
Reprints
SYDNEY
column2: Australia — Australia ’s most bitterly divided Parliament in recent history convened for the first time on Tuesday as Prime Minister Julia Gillard urged legislators  to engage in “consensus
column3: not confrontation.”

column1: Ms. Gillard
column2: whose hold on power hinges on the continued support of three independent lawmakers and a legislator from the left-leaning Greens Party
column3: is facing  a conservative opposition that has pledged to topple her before her three-year term is over.

column1: Leading Australia’s first minority government in 70 years
column2: she  has vowed to press ahead with an ambitious agenda
column3: including plans to put a price on greenhouse gas emissions and impose a 30-percent tax on the profits from mining coal and iron ore
column4: Australia’s two main exports. These battles are not expected until next year
column5: at the earliest
column6: but Ms. Gillard has said that the government will introduce at least 30 other bills to Parliament this week.

column1: Tony Abbott
column2: the leader of the conservative Liberal Party
column3: has repeatedly questioned the legitimacy of Ms. Gillard’s government after the inconclusive national election on Aug. 21 failed to deliver a clear victory to either side. Ms. Gillard’s supporters have accused him of trying to destabilize the government and force an early election.

column1: “This term of Parliament is not an opportunity to refight the election
column2: vote after vote
column3: bill after bill
column4: ” Ms. Gillard said  at a ceremonial opening of Australia’s 43rd Parliament in the capital
column5: Canberra. “This is a time for consensus
column6: not confrontation; debate
column7: not destruction.”

column1: Ms. Gillard scored her first parliamentary victory on Tuesday when her nominee for speaker of the 150-member House of Representatives
column2: Harry Jenkins
column3: was elected unopposed. Under Australian conventions
column4: the speaker is not allowed to cast a vote except in the event of a tie
column5: effectively giving Ms. Gillard a one-vote majority in the lower house.

column1: With such a razor-thin advantage
column2: Ms. Gillard cannot afford to have a single member of Parliament
column3: including herself
column4: absent for any major vote.

column1: Moreover
column2: Mr. Abbott has threatened to restrict the traditional practice of “pairing
column3: ” in which the opposition party agrees to remove one of its lawmakers from the floor when the prime minister or a senior minister is absent from a parliamentary vote.

column1: The opposition leader has said he will only grant pairings in some medical cases or when the government lawmaker is engaged in business vital to the national interest
column2: a position that could severely hamper the ability of the prime minister and other senior legislators  to travel while  Parliament is  sitting.

column1: “This is an opposition that will hold this government to account
column2: ” Mr. Abbott said on Tuesday. “This will be a Parliament of robust debate.”

column1: Under such rancorous conditions
column2: many analysts believe that the success of Ms. Gillard’s minority government will depend on her ability to keep the independents and the Greens happy. However
column3: having joined  with Labor
column4: the four nonparty members of Ms. Gillard’s minority government now have a vested interest in ensuring the government’s success.

column1: “I would be surprised if the government did not last its full term
column2: ” said Geoff Robinson
column3: an expert in Australian politics at Deakin University in Victoria State. “In terms of keeping the Greens and the independents on side
column4: that is going to require some work.”

column1: The four coalition members have not given their unqualified support to Labor. While they have agreed to support the government’s annual budgets and oppose  no-confidence motions from the opposition
column2: they have retained the right to judge each Labor policy on its merits.

column1: Ms. Gillard has already given a number of concessions to her coalition partners. She has appointed a new cabinet-level minister for rural affairs
column2: in response to concerns raised by two of the independents
column3: who represent country areas
column4: and has reversed her previous opposition to the idea of a carbon tax to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

column1: “Clearly
column2: we are in a very different environment than we were during the election campaign
column3: ” Ms. Gillard said  on Monday at the announcement of a new parliamentary committee to assess the best way of putting a price on carbon dioxide emissions. “If you’re going to have this work
column4: then you’ve got to have options on the table.”

column1: 158;"Reprints
TOKYO — Kim Jong-il
column2: North Korea ’s supreme leader
column3: took new steps on Tuesday to ensure that his family remains in charge after his death
column4: but the biggest leadership shuffling in a generation has so far produced more political intrigue than signs of real change in North Korea
column5: one of the world’s most isolated nations.

column1: Mr. Kim elevated his sister and a close friend to a high military ranking and had his youngest son and heir apparent
column2: Kim Jong-un
column3: made a member of the Central Committee of the ruling Workers’ Party.

column1: The promotions came a day after the younger Mr. Kim was also made a four-star general and seemed aimed at ensuring a dynastic succession that would give Mr. Kim
column2: thought to be in his late 20s
column3: time to solidify his power.

column1: The elevation of the completely unknown Mr. Kim
column2: and hints that other members of the extended Kim clan will exercise power behind the scenes in a kind of Communist regency
column3: add to the uncertainty about North Korea. It appears to have mostly abandoned its incipient economic reforms and has declined to enter new international talks about its nuclear weapons program
column4: leaving its neighbors and the United States alarmed about its intentions.

column1: Few analysts claim to fully understand the inner workings of the North Korean military or the Kim dynasty. But many who watch the country closely say they see few signs that succession will produce a stable
column2: credible leadership that is
column3: at least initially
column4: confident enough to engage with the outside world or to steer resources to economic development rather than the military.

column1: “We worry about Pakistan
column2: but this is potentially every bit as destabilizing as Pakistan
column3: ” said William R. Keylor
column4: a professor of international relations at Boston University . “Succession in North Korea would just be an oddity if it were not for the fact that we are dealing with a country with nuclear weapons and delivery systems. That is what makes this serious.”

column1: Fear of instability also followed the death of Kim Il-sung
column2: North Korea’s founder
column3: and the rise of his son
column4: Kim Jong-il
column5: in 1994. The country did not collapse then
column6: though its economic performance deteriorated sharply and millions of North Koreans are thought to have starved to death during Kim Jong-il’s erratic tenure.

column1: This time
column2: the country appears less well prepared for a transition. Kim Jong-il had 14 years between his political introduction in 1980 and his father’s death
column3: time he used to build support internally. There are few signs that a succession process had even begun when Kim Jong-il
column5: apparently suffered a stroke two years ago.

column1: Some analysts predict that new leaders may feel compelled to prove their nationalist credentials by engaging in provocative actions that could worsen tensions with South Korea and Japan and their main ally
column2: the United States. In March
column3: South Korea accused the North of sinking one of its warships
column4: the Cheonan
column5: which some analysts say appears to have been a display of force meant to persuade the military to respect the younger Mr. Kim.

column1: “The question now is whether they will do dangerous things like the Cheonan or something else to hold the regime together
column2: ” said Victor Cha
column3: director of Asian studies at Georgetown University . “They were already unstable as it was
column4: and this succession issue makes them even more unpredictable.”

column1: In the most destabilizing situation
column2: an internal power struggle could also lead to the collapse of the government. But many observers discount that possibility
column3: largely because of the support of another neighbor
column4: China.

column1: Beijing has made it clear that it is determined to avoid a political eruption on its borders. It has consistently taken steps to aid North Korea when the North has had severe shortages of food and energy
column2: and it has tried to ensure that international sanctions intended to punish the North for its development of nuclear weapons are not crippling.

column1: Kim Jong-il has made two visits to China in recent months to shore up its support. China has said that the younger Mr. Kim was not a member of his father’s delegation in China a month ago
column2: but American officials say they believe the son indeed was on the trip and may have met Chinese officials informally.

column1: “What China is most concerned about is stability
column2: namely stability in North Korea
column3: the Korean Peninsula and Northeast Asia
column4: ” said Xu Wenji
column5: an expert on North Korea at the Northeast Asia Institute at Jilin University. “So the concern for stability overrides everything else on this matter for the Chinese government.”

column1: The reasons behind the elevation of Kim Jong-il’s sister
column2: Kim Kyong-hui
column3: and Choe Ryong-hae
column4: a lifelong friend of the Korean leader and a member of his inner circle
column5: along with the promotion of Kim Jong-un
column6: are uncertain.

column1: Experts suggested that the three
column2: along with the sister’s husband
column3: Jang Song-taek
column4: might end up forming a new ruling group that could have the power to keep the military in check and continue the  dynasty
column5: at least until the son can fully replace his father.

column1: The promotion of the sister caught some analysts by surprise. Mr. Cha at Georgetown said it represented public recognition for someone who was already the power behind the throne in the Kim dynasty. He said that she was the confidante and the woman closest to Kim Jong-il
column2: whose wives and mother are dead
column3: and that she even took care of the leader when he was ill.

column1: Next Page ¬ª
Martin Fackler reported from Tokyo
column2: and Mark McDonald from Seoul
column3: South Korea. Andrew Jacobs contributed reporting from Beijing
column4: Choe Sang-hun from Palo Alto
column5: Calif.
column6: and David E. Sanger from Washington.

column3: on page A1 of the New York edition.

column1: 159;"Reprints
BEIJING — After weeks of escalating diplomatic tension over Japan ’s detention of a Chinese fishing captain
column2: China on Tuesday called on Tokyo to cooperate in resolving the messy dispute involving territorial sovereignty
column3: compensation for damaged boats and such intangibles as wounded national pride.

column1: Related
Block on Minerals Called Threat to Japan’s Economy (September 29
“China highly values China-Japan relations
column2: ” Jiang Yu
column3: a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman
column4: said during a regular news conference. “But safeguarding bilateral relations requires that the two sides meet halfway and requires Japan to take candid and practical actions.”

column1: The comments were less strident than previous admonishments and threats by Chinese officials
column2: including a warning of “full consequences” by the normally taciturn premier
column3: Wen Jiabao
column4: should Japan fail to acquiesce to their demands.

column1: The latest comments came hours after the Japanese foreign minister insisted that there was nothing to discuss regarding sovereignty over the string of islands in the East China Sea that both sides claim.
“No territorial issue exists
column2: ” the foreign minister
column3: Seiji Maehara
column4: told Parliament
column5: the Kyodo News Agency reported  Tuesday.

column1: China has made its displeasure known beyond its verbal sparring by halting top-level political contacts
column2: canceling tour groups
column3: and stopping the shipment of minerals crucial to Japanese automakers and other manufacturers
column4: although the Chinese commerce minister has denied the existence of an export ban.

column1: The imbroglio has been raging since Sept. 8
column2: when Japanese sailors arrested the captain of a Chinese trawler during a confrontation that may or may not have involved the captain intentionally ramming his ship into two Japanese Coast Guard patrol vessels. Known as the Diaoyu to the Chinese and Senkaku to the Japanese
column3: the uninhabited islets northeast of Taiwan are claimed by both countries and Taiwan but are administered by Japan.

column1: After angry protests by the Chinese government — and a modest rally in front of the Japanese Embassy in Beijing — prosecutors released the captain on Friday
column2: a move that was widely interpreted as a diplomatic victory for China and an affirmation of its growing economic might.

column1: But the release
column2: apparently
column3: was not enough to soothe China’s fury. Hours later
column4: Beijing demanded an apology and compensation for the fisherman’s damaged ship as the state-run media celebrated the return of the captain
column5: Zhan Qixiong . (After savoring an official celebration with fireworks and pounding drums
column6: Mr. Zhan
column8: promptly vowed to return to the disputed waters.)

column1: Prime Minister Naoto Kan of Japan
column2: feeling the heat for his perceived bow to a longtime rival
column3: has since rejected Chinese demands for money and an apology. For good measure
column4: the Japanese chief cabinet secretary is asking China to pay for repairs to the damaged coast guard vessels.

column1: “Naturally
column2: we will be asking for the boats to be returned to their original condition
column3: ” he said earlier in the week.

column1: It has not helped the diplomatic efforts that China continues to hold four Japanese citizens who were arrested last Friday after being accused of videotaping at a military installation not far from Beijing.
On Tuesday
column2: Japan’s economics minister warned that the ban on rare-earth mineral exports could pose a significant threat to the Japanese economy.

column1: “We need to restore Japan-China ties
column2: especially economic exchanges
column3: as soon as possible
column4: ” Banri Kaieda
column5: the minister of economic and fiscal policy
column6: said at a news conference
column7: The Associated Press reported.

column1: Wei Zhijiang
column2: an expert on Sino-Japanese relations at Sun Yat-sen University in Guangzhou
column3: said that while the Foreign Ministry’s latest comments could be viewed as an olive branch
column4: he doubted that the Chinese side would be able to say much more
column5: given how emotional the issue is in China — where anti-Japanese sentiment is always just beneath the surface — and the approach of the holiday on Friday  commemorating the founding of the People’s Republic of China.

column1: Zhang Jing contributed research.
A version of this article appeared in print on September 29
column3: on page A12 of the New York edition.

column1: 160;"Asim Tanveer/Reuters
Pakistan’s Prime Minister Yusuf Raza Gilani
column2: right
column3: shakes hands with Pakistani Army Chief Ashfaq Parvez Kayani.

column1: The military
column2: preoccupied by a war against militants and reluctant to assume direct responsibility for the economic crisis
column3: has made clear it is not eager to take over the government
column4: as it has many times before
column5: military officials and politicians said.

column1: But the government’s performance since the floods
column2: which have left 20 million people homeless and the nation dependent on handouts from skeptical foreign donors
column3: has laid bare the deep underlying tensions between military and civilian leaders.

column1: American officials
column2: too
column3: say it has left them increasingly disillusioned with Mr. Zardari
column4: a deeply unpopular president who was elected two and a half years ago on a wave of sympathy after the assassination of his wife
column5: former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto .

column1: In a meeting on Monday that was played on the front page of Pakistan ’s newspapers
column2: the army chief
column3: Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani
column4: confronted the president and his prime minister
column5: Yousaf Raza Gilani
column6: over incompetence and corruption in the government.

column1: According to the press and Pakistani officials familiar with the conversation
column2: the general demanded that they dismiss at least some ministers in the oversized 60-member cabinet
column3: many of whom face corruption charges.

column1: The civilian government has so far resisted the general’s demand. But the meeting was widely interpreted by the Pakistani news media
column2: which has grown increasingly hostile to the president
column3: as a rebuke to the civilian politicians and as having pushed the government to the brink.

column1: After the meeting
column2: the president’s office issued a statement
column3: approved by all the men
column4: saying they had agreed “to protect the democratic process and to resolve all issues in accordance with the constitution.”

column1: A Pakistani official close to the president who was familiar with the conversation but did not want to be identified
column2: said
column3: “The president made it clear that he would not leave
column4: come what may.”

column1: “Sanity had prevailed
column2: ” the official added.

column1: Since the floods
column2: the government has defended its handling of the crisis
column3: arguing that any government would have been overwhelmed by its scale.

column1: Still
column2: it is clear that General Kayani
column3: head of the country’s most powerful institution
column4: and the one that has taken the lead in the flood crisis
column5: has ratcheted up the pressure on the government.

column1: Having secured an exceptional three-year extension in his post from Mr. Zardari in July
column2: General Kayani appears determined to prevent the economy from bankruptcy. Military officers in the main cities have been talking openly and expansively about their contempt for the Zardari government and what they term the economic calamity
column3: an unusual candor
column4: reporters and politicians said.

column1: “The gross economic mismanagement by the government is at the heart of it
column2: ” said Rifaat Hussain
column3: a professor of international relations at Islamabad University and a confidant of the military. “And there is the rising public disaffection with the Pakistani Peoples Party under Zardari and Gilani.”

column1: As the military demands the overhaul
column2: the Supreme Court is also pushing the government on the issue of corruption by threatening to remove the president’s immunity from prosecution
column3: a move that would expose him to charges of corruption in an old money-laundering case in Switzerland.

column1: The government has defied the court’s demand to write a letter to the Swiss government requesting a reopening of the case against Mr. Zardari
column2: who  served 11 years in prison in Pakistan on unproved corruption charges. On Monday
column3: the court granted an extension of two weeks for the government to reconsider its position.

column1: Much of the rising disdain for the government has to do with the perception among the media and the public of the callous and inept handling of the floods by the nation’s wealthy ruling class.

Mr. Gilani drew public ire for appearing at an ersatz camp for flood victims set up just for television cameras. It also did not help that newspapers reported that scores of cartons from the London luxury store Harrods had arrived at his residence in Lahore at the height of the flooding.
Mr. Zardari
column2: meanwhile
column3: was vilified for visiting his chateau in France as torrents of water wiped out millions of villagers in his home province
column4: Sindh.

column1: In his most recent visit to Pakistan
column2: Richard C. Holbrooke
column3: the American special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan
column4: said the international community could not be expected to provide all the billions of dollars needed to repair the flood damage
column5: a warning interpreted here as a rebuke of the civilian government and its mismanagement.

column1: But Washington
column2: not unlike Pakistan’s military
column3: is caught
column4: American officials say
column5: because there is no appetite for a return of military rule. Nor is there desire to see the opposition politician and former prime minister
column6: Nawaz Sharif
column7: resume power.

column1: Next Page ¬ª
Ismail Khan contributed reporting from Peshawar
column2: Pakistan.

column3: on page A1 of the New York edition.

column1: 161;"Reprints
KABUL
column2: Afghanistan — Repeating his determination to find a peaceful solution to the war
column3: President Hamid Karzai named a 70-member peace council on Tuesday
column4: a long-awaited announcement that was the government’s first concrete step to open formal contacts with the Taliban .

column1: Enlarge This Image
Shah Marai/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
President Hamid Karzai is seen through the screen of a video camera as he cries while delivering a speech about the peace process.
The American commander in Afghanistan
column2: Gen. David H. Petraeus
column3: indicated support for the reconciliation process on Monday and said high-level members of the Taliban had already reached out to the government.

column1: But some immediately dismissed Mr. Karzai’s council as unworkable
column2: given that its membership was dominated largely by anti-Taliban figures.

column1: While a handful of influential people from the former Taliban government have been included
column2: the council is heavily weighted with many of the same factional leaders who have dominated the wars and politics of the past 30 years
column3: and who have been fighting the Taliban for half that time.

column1: Mr. Karzai also named at least eight women. Their appointment signaled the government’s intention to preserve the women’s rights guaranteed in the Constitution
column2: but they are unlikely to have any influence with the Taliban.

column1: The government defended the nominations
column2: saying the council needed a broad range of powerful people. The council will have the authority to develop existing contacts and open direct negotiations with the Taliban and other armed foes
column3: said the presidential spokesman
column4: Waheed Omer.

column1: “They will keep the president in the picture — it is his initiative — but they are very powerful people and will proceed as they see fit
column2: ” Mr. Omer said. The council will choose its own leader and way of operating. “The structure is such that in many ways they will have the authority and mandate to act
column3: ” he said.

column1: Mr. Karzai has been calling for talks with the Taliban for months
column2: and has gradually won the support of the United States and NATO for his plan. People close to the president say he has largely lost confidence in the ability of coalition forces to defeat the insurgency and is tentatively seeking his own course.

column1: The extent of his concern about the failing war effort was displayed on national television on Tuesday when he burst into convulsive sobs during a speech to mark national literacy day at a Kabul high school.
He said he feared that the war would force his 3-year-old son
column2: Mirwais
column3: to leave the country and grow up a refugee. “I want him to go to school here
column4: ” Mr. Karzai said. “I swear to God I’m worried
column5: I’m worried
column6: oh people
column7: I’m worried. God forbid Mirwais should be forced to leave Afghanistan

column1: Supporters of peace talks welcomed the formation of the council as a first step and said it could work despite the preponderance of people opposed to the Taliban.
“These are faces from the jihad
column2: the resistance
column3: and from the Taliban
column4: and they will have to resolve it
column5: ” said Hajji Abdul Baqi Raghbat
column6: leader of the tribal affairs department in Kandahar Province
column7: homeland of the Taliban. “These are the most famous people
column9: I don’t know who else there is.”

column1: “The most important thing is that there is willingness and freedom from both sides to move towards peace talks
column2: ” Hajji Raghbat said. “The Taliban are outside the country
column3: and they have to show their willingness
column4: ” he said
column5: a reference to the Taliban leadership who are widely believed to live in Pakistan.

column1: The council members would not do the actual negotiation
column2: but would appoint smaller commissions of neutral mediators to approach the Taliban and bring back their answers
column3: according to a lawmaker
column4: Hajji Musa Khan Hotak
column5: who has long supported talks with the Taliban.

column1: Government officials say there has been an increase in contacts with Taliban members and signals from them since the government held a peace gathering in Kabul in June. A Western diplomat confirmed that some people had approached the government claiming to represent Taliban leaders
column2: but said that it was not yet clear if they were genuine.

column1: Former members of the Taliban government
column2: including Maulavi Arsala Rahmani
column3: who was the Taliban minister of higher education and is now a senator
column4: say that Taliban leaders know that they cannot win the war and that the time is ripe for negotiation. “No one will win this war
column5: ” Mr. Rahmani said. “When the Taliban were in power they still could not control the whole country
column6: and they know that.”

column1: Yet others close to members of the Taliban leadership council say their stance remains resolutely opposed to negotiations while they are increasingly confident that the foreign troops will tire and leave in the coming years
column2: handing them a victory.

column1: Some also question whether Mr. Karzai and the people around him are really prepared to make the necessary concessions to make peace with the Taliban. Ministers interviewed in recent months supported the peace process publicly but privately said the Taliban had to be defeated.
Referring to Mr. Karzai
column2: Martine van Bijlert
column3: a director of the independent Afghan Analysts Network
column4: said: “He is not interested in substantial talks. His position towards the Taliban is
column5: ‘You can join me
column6: you can surrender to our side.’ This means there is little appetite to listen to and address some of the real grievances. At the same time there is a real danger that the process will just be a gathering of yet more commanders.”

column1: In Ghazni
column2: a province south of Kabul
column3: the deputy governor
column4: Khazim Allayar
column5: was killed by a suicide car bomber on Tuesday
column6: along with four others
column7: the Interior Ministry said.

column1: Ruhullah Khapalwak and Sharifullah Sahak contributed reporting.
