column1: 162;"Test of India Verdict Will Lie in Public Reaction
Rajesh Kumar Singh/Associated Press
Pillars have been made for a Hindu temple dedicated to Ram in Ayodhya
column2: India
column3: where Hindu extremists destroyed a 16th-century mosque in 1992.

column1: Reprints
NEW DELHI — The case has existed almost as long as independent India itself. Dating from 1950
column2: the legal battle between Hindus and Muslims over a religious site in the city of Ayodhya began as a little-noticed title dispute. With a ruling finally expected on Thursday
column3: the case has become something altogether different: a test of India’s secular soul.

column1: Related
Enlarge This Image
Adnan Abidi/Reuters
A police officer patrolled last week outside a temple in Ayodhya. Thousands of security officers have been deployed to the city.
The test is not so much in the verdict
column2: which will deal with a handful of issues
column3: including the central question of which side controls the site of a 16th-century mosque known as the Babri Masjid. Rather
column4: the test will come in the public reaction. In 1992
column5: an enraged mob of Hindu extremists destroyed the mosque
column6: asserting that the site was the birthplace of the Hindu deity
column7: Ram. Riots erupted
column11: and horrifying a nation founded on the ideal of religious tolerance.

column1: For the past month
column2: the Indian government and leaders of major political parties
column3: including right-wing Hindu leaders who stoked the 1992 violence
column4: have asked people to remain calm and refrain from violence. Thousands of security officers have been deployed to Ayodhya
column5: though the authorities concede that riots could occur anywhere. The verdict is considered so politically combustible that an emergency appeal to delay the verdict until after the Commonwealth Games in October was sent to India’s Supreme Court last week — and rejected on Tuesday.

column1: Later on Tuesday
column2: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh called on the nation to “maintain peace
column3: harmony and tranquillity.” Perhaps the only person eager for the verdict is Hashim Ansari
column4: a Muslim tailor in Ayodhya who is the case’s oldest surviving plaintiff. He is 90 and tired of waiting. Mr. Ansari
column5: who joined the case as a plaintiff in 1961
column6: said in a telephone interview that he did not want any tumult or violence
column7: just closure.

column1: “It has taken on a political color
column2: ” Mr. Ansari said of the case. “We are just waiting for a verdict. Whatever judgment comes
column3: all of us Muslims will agree
column4: whether it is in our favor or not.”

column1: The verdict could determine whether the mosque is rebuilt on the site or if a Hindu temple is erected there instead. Yet despite the official concern
column2: many analysts believe that India has matured since the violence in 1992. Hindu nationalism
column3: a potent political force in the 1990s that fueled the campaign to tear down the Babri Masjid
column4: is now far less potent. Last year
column5: when the government released the findings of a long-awaited investigation into the violence
column6: the public response was largely a shrug.

column1: “Urban India is not so closely tied with the Hindu nationalists today
column2: ” said Ashutosh Varshney
column3: a professor at Brown University who has written extensively about Hindu-Muslim relations in India.

column1: Ayodhya is located in the state of Uttar Pradesh. India’s first Mughal ruler
column2: Babur
column3: constructed a domed mosque on the contested property
column4: which became famous for its acoustics and for a drinking well whose waters were said to have curative powers. Uttar Pradesh is also considered the birthplace of Hinduism
column5: and many Hindus believe that a temple originally existed on the site to commemorate the birthplace of Ram. Some historical accounts suggest that for many years Hindus and Muslims both worshiped inside the mosque complex.

column1: But when the British took control of India
column2: they eventually erected a barrier to divide religious worship at the site. Muslims were allowed inside to pray; Hindus worshiped on platforms outside the enclosure. There were periodic squabbles
column3: but this arrangement remained intact until after India’s independence in 1947. In December 1949
column4: someone slipped in the mosque and left idols of Ram and another Hindu deity.

column1: The authorities closed the building and the matter soon went to court. A local Hindu filed for title in 1950. Mr. Ansari was a regular in the courtroom
column2: monitoring proceedings
column3: and his name was later included among the plaintiffs when a Muslim group filed its own lawsuit in 1961. In all
column4: there are four title suits to be decided.

column1: “What is at stake here is whether the Hindus have any right to this particular place
column2: ” said Prashant Bhushan
column3: a prominent legal advocate in India. “They are going to decide whether there was a temple there before the mosque
column4: and whether it gives them any rights.”

column1: Mr. Bhushan said the verdict should not be delayed any longer
column2: regardless of concerns about violence. “Public reaction
column3: whatever it will be
column4: has to be faced one day or the other
column5: ” he said. “This can’t be delayed because of fear.”

column1: A three-judge panel in the capital of Uttar Pradesh is scheduled to hand down the verdict on Thursday afternoon. Speculation about the outcome varies widely
column2: with some analysts hypothesizing that the judges may try to render the equivalent of a split decision. In Ayodhya
column3: local residents are weary of the case
column4: and the way it has come to define their city. Should his side lose
column5: Mr. Ansari said he did not plan to appeal
column6: but other parties may ultimately choose to take the case to India’s Supreme Court.

column1: Mr. Ansari said he got involved so many years ago because he and his father had once prayed at the mosque. He said he remained on good terms with local Hindus who were involved on the other side of the case.
“I expect it will go in our favor
column2: ” he said of the verdict
column3: “but it is up to the court.”

column1: Hari Kumar contributed reporting.
A version of this article appeared in print on September 29
column3: on page A6 of the New York edition.

column2: and the case has become a test of India’s secular soul.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: 163;"Reprints
WASHINGTON — The House is expected to give the Obama administration another tool in its diplomatic pouch to pressure China to let its currency rise in value
column2: reflecting growing concern around the country over the loss of manufacturing jobs
column3: persistently high unemployment and a rising trade deficit.

column1: Enlarge This Image
Doug Mills/The New York Times
President Obama met with Wen Jiabao
column2: China’s premier
column3: at the United Nations General Assembly in New York last week.

column1: Multimedia
Under Pressure
In what is likely to be one of Congress’s last significant measures before the election
column2: the House will vote Wednesday on a symbolic but not insignificant measure threatening China with punitive tariffs on its imports to the United States.

column1: In the past
column2: Beijing has responded to such tactics by allowing its currency to rise gradually in relation to the dollar . Lately
column3: though
column4: efforts at cajoling the Chinese to revalue their currency have met with little
column5: if any
column6: response.

column1: But it is unclear whether the legislation
column2: which faces cloudy prospects in the Senate
column3: will succeed this time in prodding  a China  that has become more self-confident  on the world stage. Some economists believe that Beijing has undervalued the currency
column4: the renminbi
column5: for about a decade to promote Chinese exports by making them cheaper.

column1: “The legislation will strengthen the administration’s hand in its negotiations with China
column2: but also risks provoking a strong backlash
column3: ” said Eswar S. Prasad
column4: a professor of trade policy at Cornell and a former head of the International Monetary Fund ’s China division. “Ultimately its short-term effect is likely to be more symbolic than substantive.”

column1: The strategy has borne fruit before. In July 2005
column2: under pressure from a Republican-controlled Congress and the Bush administration
column3: Chinese officials agreed to end the fixed peg of the renminbi to the dollar
column4: allowing it to appreciate by more than 20 percent until July 2008
column5: when they re-established the peg in response to global economic turmoil.

column1: Now
column2: with Democrats struggling to maintain their Congressional majorities
column3: a Democratic president is pressing China on the issue. But so far the efforts have yielded little.

column1: Lawrence H. Summers
column2: one of President Obama ’s top economic advisers
column3: and Thomas E. Donilon
column4: deputy national security adviser
column5: traveled to Beijing this month for three days of meetings with Chinese leaders but returned empty-handed on the currency issue.

column1: Last Friday
column2: Mr. Obama personally raised the issue with the Chinese premier
column3: Wen Jiabao
column4: on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly meetings in New York.

column1: Since June
column2: when China announced that it would permit greater exchange-rate flexibility
column3: the renminbi has risen less than 2 percent against the dollar
column4: with much of the increase occurring this month
column5: amid rising Congressional anger and tough new rhetoric from the Treasury secretary
column6: Timothy F. Geithner .

column1: A weaker renminbi — estimates of the extent of the undervaluation range as high as 40 percent — makes Chinese exports cheaper and foreign imports more expensive.
But in both countries
column2: there are constituencies for and against currency revaluation.

column1: In the United States
column2: smaller manufacturers
column3: labor unions and agricultural producers have been pressing the government to take a tough stance
column4: saying that the currency policy has contributed to soaring trade deficits and the continued erosion of domestic industry.

column1: But large multinational corporations
column2: especially those with production plants in China
column3: and Wall Street banks
column4: are comfortable with a weak renminbi because they export goods from China or are trying to promote investment there.

column1: In China
column2: consumers would benefit from cheaper imports
column3: and a stronger renminbi would help correct global economic imbalances that some economists say could lead to soaring inflation and asset bubbles. But export-oriented businesses and state-owned companies
column4: which wield tremendous clout within the Communist regime
column5: say the weak currency is vital for economic growth.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: the Obama administration
column3: which had favored quiet diplomacy
column4: has signaled to Congress that it was open to new measures.

column1: Though he did not endorse the legislation
column2: Mr. Geithner said at a House hearing this month that “it is very important that China hear from the Congress
column3: from Republicans and from Democrats
column4: ” about the effect of China’s policies on American economic interests.

column1: The Ways and Means Committee passed the bill on a voice vote on Friday.
Sponsored by Representatives Tim Ryan
column2: Democrat of Ohio
column3: and Tim Murphy
column4: Republican of Pennsylvania
column5: the legislation would expand the Commerce Department’s ability to impose punitive duties on countries that undervalue their currencies to promote exports.

column1: Experts expressed skepticism about the move; some believe it will merely antagonize the Chinese.
“Many people don’t think the multilateral steps have worked
column2: that they’ve been tried
column3: the talk has gone on
column4: and nothing has happened
column5: ” Ira S. Shapiro
column6: a lawyer at Greenberg Traurig and a top trade negotiator during the Clinton administration
column7: told House members this month. “I think it’s too early to reach that conclusion.”

column1: Mr. Shapiro urged American officials to make the upcoming Group of 20 summit meeting in Seoul
column2: South Korea
column3: in November the focal point of multinational efforts to persuade China to move. If those talks fail
column4: he said
column5: the United States should pursue remedies at the World Trade Organization
column6: which China joined in 2001.

column1: Professor Prasad of Cornell  warned that if the Congressional proposal went forward
column2: China could retaliate by limiting American imports or denying American manufacturers and financial institutions “the coveted prize of access to rapidly growing Chinese markets.”

column1: Framing the issue as a dispute between the two countries
column2: he added
column3: “suits the Chinese well as it deflects attention from the global consequences of Chinese currency policy.”

column1: Many economists believe that China is unlikely to budge without a concerted demonstration of international resolve. But such coordination is difficult when all countries are struggling to bolster their recoveries.
Two weeks ago
column2: Japan devalued the yen
column3: its first intervention in currency markets since 2004. The finance minister of Brazil
column4: whose currency has soared in value
column5: warned Tuesday that an “international currency war” was under way.

column1: The International Monetary Fund has affirmed that China undervalues its currency
column2: but lacks enforcement powers to give teeth to its reports. And the process for resolving disputes through the World Trade Organization is lengthy and uncertain.

column1: All of those factors have made action by the House increasingly likely.
A version of this article appeared in print on September 29
column3: on page B3 of the New York edition.

BANGKOK — The Web site of The Irrawaddy
column2: a magazine based in Thailand that is a leading source of news and criticism of the junta in Myanmar
column3: has come under attack and been blocked by hackers
column4: its editor
column5: Aung Zaw
column6: said on Monday.

column1: The “distributed denial of service” attack just after midnight was similar but more sophisticated than an attack that forced the temporary closing of the site two years ago. Mr. Aung Zaw said it was not clear whether the attack came from inside Myanmar or from China
column2: a close ally. Visitors to the Web site
column3: www.irrawaddy.org
column4: have been redirected to a mirror site while technicians seek to restore it.

column1: “This is a new game
column2: a new frontier” in the government’s struggle against its opponents
column3: Mr. Aung Zaw said. “It shows how vulnerable we are.”

column1: 165;"Reprints
SEOUL
column2: South Korea — The youngest son of Kim Jong-il
column3: North Korea ’s reclusive leader
column4: has been promoted to a military general
column5: that country’s official Korean Central News Agency reported early Tuesday
column6: the clearest sign yet that he is in line to succeed his father as the country’s leader.

column1: Enlarge This Image
A photo by Kenji Fujimoto
column2: a Japanese who said he was a cook for Kim Jong-il
column3: North Korea's leader
column4: is said to show Kim Jong-un as a boy.

column1: A brief dispatch by KCNA said the son
column2: Kim Jong-un
column3: and five others had been made generals in the Korea People’s Army. It was the first time that KCNA or any North Korean news outlet had mentioned the son
column4: who is either 27 or 28
column5: by name.

column1: “This promotion of Kim Jong-un to four-star general carries a lot of weight in North Korea
column2: and it has the connotation of very senior ‘top brass
column3: ’¬†” said Lee Sung-yoon
column4: a North Korea expert at the Fletcher School at Tufts University . “This is a very big deal.”

column1: The new generals’ roster also included Kim Kyong-hui
column2: the elder Mr. Kim’s sister. She is the wife of Jang Seong-taek
column3: often regarded by outside analysts as the No. 2 man in the North and a potential caretaker for the government should Kim Jong-il
column5: who is in failing health
column6: suddenly become incapacitated.

column1: The news came hours after delegates to a rare gathering of the ruling Workers’ Party arrived in the North Korean capital
column2: Pyongyang
column3: on Monday as the party began final preparations for a meeting that could provide further signals about Kim Jong-un’s debut. Photographs from Pyongyang showed banners and posters announcing the meeting
column4: and there has been heavy speculation in the South Korean news media about the possible anointing of the younger Mr. Kim .

column1: Kurt M. Campbell
column2: an assistant secretary of state
column3: told reporters on Monday that the United States was “watching developments in North Korea carefully” and was talking to allies in the region “as we try to assess the meaning of what’s transpiring there.”

column1: “But frankly
column2: it’s still too early to tell in terms of next steps
column3: or in fact
column4: what’s going on inside the country’s leadership
column5: ” he said.

column1: Little is known about Kim Jong-un
column2: and most of what is has been culled from defectors and Web sites that collect information from sources in the North. In the North Korean news media he has been referred to as the “Young General
column3: ” “Youth Captain Kim” and even “C.N.C.
column4: ” short for computer numerical control
column5: to demonstrate his bona fides as a leader for the 21st century. He is said to have attended boarding or military school in Switzerland and spent several years in the military.

column1: Korea experts had long tapped his brother
column2: Kim Jong-nam
column4: as the most likely heir
column5: until he took an ill-fated trip to Tokyo Disneyland using a fake passport. All the same
column6: Kim Jong-un might have remained an obscure figure
column7: but his father had a stroke in 2008
column8: quickening the timetable for the succession.

column1: In a conservative Confucian society that reveres age
column2: selling the public and
column3: more important
column4: the elite on a leader in his 20s is not easy. State-controlled media seem to be making a virtue of necessity
column5: emphasizing not only Kim Jong-un’s computer expertise but also his freshness and youth
column6: circulating songs
column7: poems and posters singing his praises. He has lately accompanied his father on factory tours
column8: and was said to have joined him on a recent trip to China.

column1: The campaign may convince some of the people
column2: experts say
column3: but it is likely to have little impact on the elite
column4: who will be testing his willingness to exercise power. Some in the West
column5: including Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates
column6: have ascribed the sinking of a South Korean warship by a North Korean torpedo attack in March to the succession struggle and Kim Jong-un’s efforts to establish credibility with the military brass.

column1: Others
column2: however
column3: contend that the elite are quite comfortable with the idea of an inexperienced leader. “I think he is chosen exactly because he is young
column4: ” Andrei Lankov
column5: a North Korean expert at Kookmin University in Seoul
column6: said in an interview this month. “He will be a dictator
column7: but merely a rubber-stamping dictator. This is what the people in the positions of power want.”

column1: The party meeting was due to begin later Tuesday. Although the secretive government has said a new supreme leadership body will be elected
column2: very little has been disclosed about the agenda.  The current gathering was originally announced by KCNA as scheduled for “early September
column3: ” and the slight delay touched off speculation about cutthroat internal wrangling over the presumed dynastic succession
column4: Kim Jong-il’s health
column5: and flooded roads and washed-out bridges that made travel difficult.

column1: John Delury
column2: a professor of international relations at Yonsei University in Seoul
column3: was in Pyongyang last week for meetings with North Korean officials and said speculation was clearly starting to build around the meeting.

column1: “This is a party meeting
column2: and these are very rare in North Korean history
column3: ” he said in an interview on Monday.

column1: Some analysts said they believed that Kim Jong-un was almost certain to be named his father’s successor and would perhaps be given one of eight Politburo seats. Others were more cautious
column2: suggesting his ascendancy could still be undone by political infighting.

column1: Kim Jong-il’s health has been the subject of much speculation. Some who have seen him in person say he appears wan and diminished
column2: while others say he appears active and alert
column3: despite a slight limp.

column1: Daniel C. Sneider
column2: associate director for research of the Shorenstein Asia-Pacific Research Center at Stanford
column3: said
column4: “At the very least
column5: the last year tells us that Kim Jong-il knows he doesn’t have the kind of time to prepare his son for succession that he enjoyed.”

column1: At the last Workers’ Party meeting in 1980
column2: Kim Jong-il
column3: then 38
column4: was named to several party posts and confirmed as the sole successor to his father. All told
column5: he had spent more than two decades learning the ropes when he finally took control upon the death of his father
column6: Kim Il-sung

column1: Choe Sang-hun contributed reporting from Palo Alto
column2: Calif.

column1: A version of this article appeared in print on September 28
column3: on page A4 of the New York edition.

column1: 166;"Reprints
KABUL
column2: Afghanistan — NATO forces in Afghanistan launched two airstrikes against Taliban insurgents on the Pakistani side of the border
column3: killing more than 30 people
column4: military spokesmen confirmed on Monday.

column1: Notes from Afghanistan
column2: Pakistan
column3: Iraq and other areas of conflict in the post-9/11 era. Go to the Blog ¬ª

column1: Related
C.I.A. Steps Up Drone Attacks Within Pakistan (September 28
The airstrikes
column2: which took place last Friday and Saturday
column3: were unusual because they involved piloted aircraft rather than drones
column4: which are more commonly used to attack insurgents on the Pakistani side of the border
column5: and which are normally operated by the Central Intelligence Agency .

column1: Spokesmen for the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force initially denied any of its forces had launched the airstrikes
column2: although they were confirmed by Afghan police officials.

column1: On Monday
column2: however
column3: a statement from the international force confirmed the attacks and put the death toll at more than 30. Initially
column4: a base close to the border in Khost Province
column5: known as Combat Outpost Narizah
column6: came under fire from insurgents on Friday. When what the military described as an “air weapons team” responded
column7: they came under fire from the insurgents on the Pakistani side of the frontier and returned fire

column1: When two  helicopters from the international force returned to the area the next day
column2: they were fired on again from the Pakistani side of the border
column3: and again returned fire
column4: killing several more insurgents
column5: spokesmen said.

column1: The Khost Provincial Police Chief
column2: Gen. Abdul Hakim Isahqzai
column3: put the death toll among the insurgents at 82 or higher. There have been no complaints of civilian casualties.

column1: Coalition officials said the cross-border attacks fell within its rules of engagement because the insurgents had attacked them from across the border. The Associated Press reported that a third strike inside Pakistani territory was carried out by two NATO helicopters on Monday. Pakistani intelligence officials told The A.P. that the attack killed five militants and wounded nine others. Pakistan was reported on Monday to have criticized the strikes
column2: denying American assertions that the United States has an agreement with Pakistan authorizing so-called “hot pursuit” raids a few miles across the border. In a press statement
column3: the Pakistan Foreign Ministry said the mandate of NATO forces in Afghanistan did not extend beyond the border
column4: The A.P. said.

column1: The United States does carry out remotely-piloted drone strikes against militants on Pakistan’s border. The strikes
column2: though unpopular with many Pakistanis
column3: have had the tacit blessing of the Pakistani government since the end of the Bush administration. The latest such attack took place on Monday
column4: killing two people near the Afghan border
column5: The A.P. said.

column1: Farooq Jan Mangal contributed reporting from Khost Province
column2: Afghanistan.

BEIJING — The authorities are investigating a security company that helps local officials illegally detain desperate citizens who come to the capital to file complaints against them
column2: the state news media reported Monday.

column1: According to China Daily
column2: an official English-language newspaper
column3: the company’s employees posed as police officers and dragooned petitioners into “black jails
column4: ” where they were held and sometimes beaten until they could be hauled back to their homes in other provinces.

column1: The Chinese government has repeatedly denied that such extralegal detention centers exist.
News about the company
column2: Anyuanding Security Technology Service
column3: was published by Caijing and Southern Metropolis Daily
column4: two publications that often push beyond the boundaries that constrain much of China ’s official news media. According to their reports
column5: the company
column6: which earned $3.1 million in 2008
column7: employs 3
column8: 000 “interceptors” whose job is to ensnare petitioners before they can reach the central government bureaus where grievances are filed.

column1: According to Southern Metropolis Daily
column2: the Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau detained two of Anyuanding’s executives and charged them with “illegally detaining people and illegally operating a business.” The police did not immediately respond to calls for comment on Monday. The company
column3: whose Web site was taken down over the weekend
column4: could not be reached.

column1: The system of interceptors and black jails has flourished in recent years as Chinese citizens
column2: frustrated by official malfeasance or illegal land seizures in their hometowns
column3: come to the capital in the belief that their problems might be solved if they could gain the ear of senior leaders. Studies have shown
column4: however
column5: that problems are resolved for fewer than 2 percent of those who file petitions in Beijing.

column1: Petitioning
column2: allowed by Chinese law
column3: has become a barometer of civic harmony — one that can affect the careers of local officials.

column1: Because the central government rewards or punishes officials based on their ability to maintain social stability
column2: those officials are eager to catch petitioners before they can lodge their complaints.

column1: The interception efforts have apparently been successful. In its official report on human rights released Monday
column2: the Chinese government cited a 3 percent drop in petition filings as proof that things had improved. It was the fifth consecutive decrease
column3: the report said.

column1: Human rights groups said they were encouraged by the detention of Anyuanding’s executives
column2: but suggested that the system had become so entrenched that the changes would have to come from on high.

column1: “The fact is that the problem of black jails goes far beyond one company
column2: ” Phelim Kine
column3: an Asia researcher at Human Rights Watch
column4: said in an e-mail. “It involves a web of government officials
column5: security forces
column6: huge numbers of plainclothes thugs and dozens of facilities in Beijing alone.”

column1: According to the reports on Anyuanding
column2: the kidnapped petitioners were taken to abandoned guesthouses
column3: dank basements or rural compounds
column4: where their cellphones and identity cards were confiscated until officials from their hometowns could come to fetch them. Some prisoners reported waiting more than a month.

column1: The decision by Beijing’s public security bureau to take on the matter is significant given its first response. Last week
column2: after Caijing published its investigation
column3: several unidentified police officers pressed the magazine to reveal its sources
column4: saying the article threatened “stability and unity
column5: ” according to the editors.

column1: But after Caijing publicized the incident
column2: Beijing’s new police chief
column3: Fu Zhenghua
column4: personally apologized to the deputy editor and assured him that no one on the staff would be punished.

column1: Shortly afterward
column2: the Anyuanding executives were detained.

column1: Xu Zhiyong
column2: a public interest lawyer whose organization has investigated black jails
column3: said that although it was too early to say whether the police investigation signaled a change in official policy
column4: it showed the effect that the media could have when given some latitude.

column1: “The Anyuanding affair is so sinister and damaging
column2: it appears that the public security authorities were left with little choice but to intervene and investigate
column3: ” Mr. Xu said.

column1: Jonathan Ansfield contributed reporting. Li Bibo contributed research.

column3: on page A8 of the New York edition.

NEW DELHI — The Indian government on Monday began the slow
column2: uncertain process of trying to restore normalcy to the violence-racked region of Kashmir . Authorities reopened schools and universities
column3: even as many students stayed away
column4: some out of protest
column5: others out of fear.

column1: Related
Times Topic: Kashmir

Monday marked the first test of the new political initiative announced by the Indian government over the weekend after more than three months of angry confrontation between stone-throwing protesters and Indian security officers. The demonstrations have left at least 108 people dead and coalesced into an angry rebuke of government policies in Indian-controlled Kashmir.
The package aimed at calming the situation includes economic aid
column2: a call for easing security strictures and a new political dialogue.

column1: Kashmir is a longtime source of dispute between India and Pakistan
column2: with both countries controlling different parts of the region and claiming all of it. The latest unrest in the Indian portion
column3: the state of Jammu and Kashmir
column4: has been fueled by a rising call from students and others for political self-determination.

column1: Since June
column2: most educational institutions have remained closed in Kashmir
column3: whether because of strikes called by separatist leaders or because of strict government curfews that had closed shops and cleared traffic off streets.

column1: Reopening the schools was considered critical
column2: and the state government announced that teachers with work cards and students in school uniforms would be allowed to pass through the myriad security checkpoints in the region’s summer capital of Srinagar. Bus schedules also were announced.

column1: But on Monday there was an uneven response
column2: with government officials estimating that 30 percent to 80 percent of students showed up for class throughout the Kashmir Valley.

column1: Several students interviewed by telephone said they failed to attend because security officers refused to lift the curfew. At the University of Kashmir in Srinagar
column2: Muhammad Ibrahim
column4: arrived at 10 a.m. for his first day back in 14 weeks. Yet he was the only student in his class of 38 who navigated the checkpoints and made it to school.

column1: Showkat Shafi
column2: spokesman for the university
column3: said most classes on the main campus were closed Monday
column4: while the curfew impeded other students from reaching satellite locations throughout the valley. He said students at the off-campus locations were supposed to begin taking examinations on Monday.

column1: “Students are complaining that they are trying to reach examination centers across the valley
column2: but very few have made it
column3: ” he said.

column1: Many students also stayed away as a means of protest over their demands that India make good on promises to allow a referendum on self-rule in Kashmir. Some may have been following the separatist leader Syed Ali Shah Geelani
column2: who belittled the new government package and announced that families should not send their children back to school. Yet it is unclear how much control leaders like Mr. Geelani have over a protest movement fueled largely by college students.

column1: “The government insists that we go to classes because they want to show the international community that things are normal here in Kashmir
column2: ” said Saliq Abbas
column3: a postgraduate student at the University of Kashmir
column4: who refused to return to classes. “But things are not normal.”

column1: The impact of the new political package is likely to become clear only after several more weeks. Last Monday
column2: Home Minister Palaniappan Chidambaram led a parliamentary delegation on a two-day visit to the region and then announced the new policies from New Delhi late on Saturday afternoon.

column1: On Monday
column2: Mr. Chidambaram framed the efforts to reopen the schools in a positive light
column3: noting that most had opened
column4: while also criticizing a few minor reported episodes of stone throwing at school buses that resulted in no injuries.

column1: “How can any right-thinking person pelt stones on school buses?” he asked in a statement.
Omar Abdullah
column2: the chief minister of Jammu and Kashmir
column3: called on all political groups — including separatists like Mr. Geelani — to support the resumption of education. “Let us keep education neutral to all conflicts
column4: ” he said in a statement.

column1: One of the most pressing questions is when
column2: and to what degree
column3: the authorities will ease the security lockdown that many residents in Srinagar describe as “collective punishment.”

column1: Mr. Chidambaram’s package included a directive for state leaders to reassess the security presence and consider scaling back — a step previously promoted by Mr. Abdullah. Many Kashmiris want India to repeal emergency laws that have given broad powers of arrest and immunity to soldiers
column2: paramilitary officers and police officers in many parts of the region.

column1: Kuldeep Khoda
column2: director of the state police
column3: said decisions on security would be made after a meeting of the Unified Command
column4: consisting of civilian leaders and leaders of security and military agencies.

column1: He said the police had maintained a curfew in Srinagar on Monday as a protective measure against the threat of violence against schools or buses presented by Mr. Geelani’s call for a strike. The police did relax the curfew on Sunday to allow residents to rush out to buy food and other provisions.
The recent political attention on Kashmir has coincided with an almost complete absence of violence during the past week. Taj Mohi-ud-Din
column2: a senior minister in the state government
column3: predicted that more students would attend classes in the coming days
column4: as the situation stabilized and parents became more comfortable with sending out their children. He also said that security would be eased in the future
column5: as long as violence did not return.

column1: “It has to be gradual
column2: ” he said. “We have to be certain the withdrawal will not affect the security position.”

column1: Hari Kumar contributed reporting from New Delhi.
A version of this article appeared in print on September 28
column3: on page A10 of the New York edition.

PARWAN
column2: Afghanistan — The top American commander in Afghanistan said Monday that high-level Taliban leaders had reached out to senior Afghan government officials in the context of starting reconciliation discussions that could pave the way to end the fighting in Afghanistan.

column1: For months
column2: efforts at reconciliation have been stalled at every level
column3: and this is the first explicit public suggestion that there is extensive behind-the-scenes contact between insurgents and the Afghan government.

column1: Gen. David H. Petraeus
column2: in a meeting with reporters after a tour of the largely United States-run detention facility here
column3: where American forces detain Afghans they suspect of supporting the insurgency
column4: said the Taliban were making efforts to establish contact with senior members of the Afghan government.

column1: “There are very high-level Taliban leaders who have sought to reach out to the highest levels of the Afghan government and
column2: indeed
column3: have done that
column4: ” General Petraeus said.

column1: The conditions of President Hamid Karzai “are very clear
column2: very established
column3: and
column4: certainly
column5: we support them as we did in Iraq
column6: as the U.K. did in Northern Ireland; this is how you end these kinds of insurgencies
column7: ” General Petraeus said
column8: referring to the conditions among others that the Taliban respect the country’s Constitution and lay down arms.

column1: He added that any strategy had to be comprehensive and also include traditional elements of counterinsurgency strategy
column2: like training Afghan security forces
column3: and also “coming to grips with the situation in which there are sanctuaries for the insurgents outside the borders of the country in which we are located
column4: and it involves
column5: in a sense
column6: a war of words
column7: of information.”

column1: American support for the process is in part a recognition that “Oh
column2: by the way
column3: you are not going to kill or capture your way out of an industrial-strength insurgency
column4: ” General Petraeus said
column5: underscoring the scale of Taliban activity.

column1: The talks are continuous
column2: according to people knowledgeable about them.

column1: General Petraeus’s embrace of talks comes at a difficult moment in the war and at a time when many politicians in the United States are searching for a way to bring the troops home as soon as possible. Popular support has ebbed amid a steady drumbeat of reports documenting the Taliban’s persistence despite the killing of large numbers.
Although on its face a peace deal with the Taliban appears to be a necessary ingredient for the withdrawal of international troops
column2: a reconciliation with the insurgents is also so controversial among many Afghans that the United States is in a delicate position in supporting it. At this point it seems there is an acknowledgment that it would not be possible to win against an insurgency of this scale and that a peace deal might be a major part of any exit strategy.

column1: A spokesman for Mr. Karzai confirmed that there had been contacts with the Taliban at every level
column2: but he cautioned that the contacts could not be characterized as even the beginning of negotiations. “In the last few months
column3: there have been signs and signals from different levels of Afghan Taliban
column4: ” said Waheed Omer
column5: the spokesman.

column1: “There have been different levels of contact — sometimes direct and sometimes indirect
column2: ” Mr. Omer said.

column1: The outreach began shortly after the peace jirga
column2: or assembly
column3: in early June when Mr. Karzai announced his plans for a program of reintegration and reconciliation
column4: but no formal negotiations or discussions have begun
column5: he said.

column1: Mr. Omer said Taliban figures had made numerous efforts to reach out
column2: and that once the High Peace Council was appointed
column3: which Mr. Karzai was expected to do this week
column4: the efforts would proceed.  Similar efforts by emissaries of Mr. Karzai stalled after the capture of senior Taliban leaders by Pakistan in February. On a parallel track
column5: but still in a formative stage
column6: are efforts to reintegrate lower-level Taliban into Afghan society

column1: “We’re on the cusp of beginning
column2: of supporting
column3: the Afghan beginning of reintegration
column4: ” General Petraeus said.

column1: Sharifullah Sahak contributed reporting from Kabul.

column3: on page A4 of the New York edition.

column1: The National Security Agency’s wiretapping of Mahmoud Karzai
column2: an older brother of President Karzai
column3: appears to be part of a larger criminal investigation now under way by federal prosecutors in New York
column4: according to the officials
column5: who declined to be identified by name discussing a criminal inquiry.

column1: Mahmoud Karzai
column2: who ran restaurants in the United States before the attacks of Sept. 11
column4: is widely seen as one of the most powerful and well-connected business leaders in Kabul . He has been criticized in Afghanistan for taking advantage of his status as the brother of the president to engage in insider dealing in real estate
column5: cement and other industries
column6: and he has angered powerful officials in the Afghan Army by developing a lucrative residential real estate project on thousands of acres of valuable land in Kandahar that the army claims to own.

column1: His role as an investor in Kabul Bank
column2: Afghanistan’s largest commercial bank — which  was taken over by the country’s central bank in late August because of concerns about heavy losses — has brought increased scrutiny to his activities in both Washington and Kabul.

column1: The N.S.A. wiretapping of Mr. Karzai in Afghanistan has been under way for at least several months
column2: during a time when the crisis at the Kabul Bank was worsening.

column1: The United States has created investigative teams with the Afghan government to fight corruption in the country
column2: but the investigation of Mr. Karzai by federal prosecutors in New York appears to have been kept separate from that joint effort.

column1: While the new joint anticorruption unit in Kabul has its own wiretapping capability
column2: the fact that the N.S.A. has been involved in conducting surveillance of Mr. Karzai underscores the secrecy and sensitivity surrounding the investigation.

column1: Gerald Posner
column2: a lawyer for Mahmoud Karzai
column3: said Monday that Mr. Karzai had not been contacted or interviewed by the F.B.I. or the Justice Department
column4: and had not been told that he was the subject of an investigation.

column1: A spokeswoman for the Justice Department declined to comment. The Wall Street Journal first reported Monday that prosecutors had opened an inquiry into Mr. Karzai. Mr. Posner said that Mr. Karzai had canceled a planned trip to the United States.
The inquiry comes at an awkward time in the relationship between the Obama administration and the government of President Karzai. For months
column2: the White House openly criticized President Karzai for tolerating widespread corruption that undermined the credibility of his government at a time when the United States was pouring more troops into the fight against the Taliban . But recently
column3: the administration has begun to back off its anticorruption campaign out of a growing sense in Washington that it was having little effect other than to antagonize President Karzai and his political circle.

column1: Until recently
column2: another of President Karzai’s brothers
column3: Ahmed Wali Karzai
column4: received far more public scrutiny than Mahmoud Karzai. Ahmed Wali Karzai
column5: the chairman of the provincial council of Kandahar who is widely considered to be the political boss of southern Afghanistan
column6: has been accused of benefiting from narcotics trafficking
column7: and United States officials have said that he also has had a longstanding relationship with the Central Intelligence Agency .

column1: Mahmoud Karzai
column2: by contrast
column3: did not go into the Afghan government and has immersed himself in business. But several Karzai relatives have said that Mahmoud has been planning to form a new political party in Afghanistan and has been thinking about running for president when his brother’s term ends.

column1: But as he has gained prominence
column2: accusations of corrupt dealings have plagued  Mahmoud  Karzai. According to a person close to Mr.  Karzai
column3: Senator John Kerry
column4: the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column5: privately confronted President Karzai over Mr. Karzai’s business dealings in a recent meeting in Kabul. After the meeting
column6: President Karzai called Mr. Karzai and questioned him
column7: according to the person close to Mr. Karzai.

column1: Mr. Karzai could not be reached for comment on Monday
column2: but in an interview last week
column3: he denied any wrongdoing
column4: and said that all of his business dealings in Afghanistan were honest and that he was investing in Afghanistan’s future growth.

column1: But even some of his relatives are critical of Mr.  Karzai’s aggressive style in Afghanistan.
“I have told him that he should have handled his business exactly the way we did in the U.S.
column2: ” said another Karzai brother
column3: Qayum Karzai. Both Qayum and Mahmoud Karzai have owned and operated restaurants in the United States.

column1: “He should not have had so much of a gray area around his business dealings
column2: ” Qayum Karzai said. “I personally have told him he should have had experts and lawyers look at his deals
column3: and not just do it on handshakes and friendships
column4: and make sure it doesn’t smell fishy
column5: because you are the president’s brother.”

column1: As part of its covert war in the region
column2: the C.I.A. has launched 20 attacks with armed drone aircraft thus far in September
column3: the most ever during a single month
column4: and more than twice the number in a typical month. This expanded air campaign comes as top officials are racing to stem the rise of American casualties before the Obama administration’s comprehensive review of its Afghanistan strategy set for December. American and European officials are also evaluating reports of possible terrorist plots in the West from militants based in Pakistan.

column1: The strikes also reflect mounting frustration both in Afghanistan and the United States that Pakistan’s government has not been aggressive enough in dislodging militants from their bases in the country’s western mountains. In particular
column2: the officials said
column3: the Americans believe the Pakistanis are unlikely to launch military operations inside North Waziristan
column4: a haven for Taliban and Qaeda operatives that has long been used as a base for attacks against troops in Afghanistan. Some Pakistani troops have also been diverted from counterinsurgency missions to help provide relief to victims of the country’s massive flooding.

column1: Beyond the C.I.A. drone strikes
column2: the war in the region is escalating in other ways. In recent days
column3: American military helicopters have launched three airstrikes into Pakistan that military officials estimate killed more than 50 people suspected of being members of the militant group known as the Haqqani network
column4: which is responsible for a spate of deadly attacks against American troops.

column1: Such air raids by the military remain rare
column2: and officials in Kabul said Monday that the helicopters entered Pakistani airspace on only one of the three raids
column3: and acted in self-defense after militants fired rockets at an allied base just across the border in Afghanistan. At the same time
column4: the strikes point to a new willingness by military officials to expand the boundaries of the campaign against the Taliban and Haqqani network — and to an acute concern in military and intelligence circles about the limited time to attack Taliban strongholds while American “surge” forces are in Afghanistan.

column1: Pakistani officials have angrily criticized the helicopter attacks
column2: saying that NATO ’s mandate in Afghanistan does not extend across the border in Pakistan.

column1: As evidence of the growing frustration of American officials
column2: Gen. David H. Petraeus
column3: the top American commander in Afghanistan
column4: has recently issued veiled warnings to top Pakistani commanders that the United States could launch unilateral ground operations in the tribal areas should Pakistan refuse to dismantle the militant networks in North Waziristan
column5: according to American officials.

column1: “Petraeus wants to turn up the heat on the safe havens
column2: ” said one senior administration official
column3: explaining the sharp increase in drone strikes. “He has pointed out to the Pakistanis that they could do more.”

column1: Special Operations commanders have also been updating plans for cross-border raids
column2: which would require approval from President Obama . For now
column3: officials said
column4: it remains unlikely that the United States would make good on such threats to send American troops over the border
column5: given the potential blowback inside Pakistan
column6: an ally.

column1: But that could change
column2: they said
column3: if Pakistan-based militants were successful in carrying out a terrorist attack on American soil. American and European intelligence officials in recent days have spoken publicly about growing evidence that militants may be planning a large-scale attack in Europe
column4: and have bolstered security at a number of European airports and railway stations.

column1: “We are all seeing increased activity by a more diverse set of groups and a more diverse set of threats
column2: ” said Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano before a Senate panel last week.

column1: The senior administration official said the strikes were intended not only to attack Taliban and Haqqani fighters
column2: but also to disrupt any plots directed from or supported by extremists in Pakistan’s tribal areas that were aimed at targets in Europe. “The goal is to suppress or disrupt that activity
column3: ” the official said.

column1: The 20 C.I.A. drone attacks in September represent the most intense bombardment by the spy agency since January
column2: when the C.I.A. carried out 11 strikes after a suicide bomber killed seven agency operatives at a remote base in eastern Afghanistan.

column1: According to one Pakistani intelligence official
column2: the recent drone attacks have not killed any senior Taliban or Qaeda leaders. Many senior operatives have already fled North Waziristan
column3: he said
column4: to escape the C.I.A. drone campaign.

column1: Over all the spy agency has carried out 74 drone attacks this year
column2: according to the Web site The Long War Journal
column3: which tracks the strikes. A vast majority of the attacks — which usually involve several drones firing multiple missiles or bombs — have taken place in North Waziristan.

column1: The Obama administration has enthusiastically embraced the C.I.A.’s drone program
column2: an ambitious and historically unusual war campaign by American spies. According to The Long War Journal
column3: the spy agency in 2009 and 2010 has launched nearly four times as many attacks as it did during the final year of the Bush administration.

column1: One American official said that the recent strikes had been aimed at several groups
column2: including the Haqqani network
column3: Al Qaeda and the Pakistani Taliban. The United States
column4: he said
column5: hopes to “keep the pressure on as long as we can.”

column1: But the C.I.A.’s campaign has also raised concerns that the drone strikes are fueling anger in the Muslim world. The man who attempted to detonate a truck filled with explosives in Times Square told a judge that the C.I.A. drone campaign was one of the factors that led him to attack the United States.
In a meeting with reporters on Monday
column2: General Petraeus indicated that it was new intelligence gathering technology that helped NATO forces locate the militants killed by the helicopter raids against militants in Pakistan.

column1: In particular
column2: he said
column3: the military has expanded its fleet of reconnaissance blimps that can hover over hide-outs thought to belong to the Taliban in eastern and southern Afghanistan.

column1: The intelligence technology
column2: General Petraeus said
column3: has also enabled the expanded campaign of raids by Special Operations commandos against Taliban operatives in those areas.

column3: and Ismail Khan from Peshawar

column3: says it is willing to meet “the lawful access needs of law enforcement agencies.”

column1: But here in India
column2: government authorities are well beyond the proposal stage. Prompted by fears of digital-era plotters
column3: officials are already demanding that network operators give them the ability to monitor and decrypt digital messages
column4: whenever the Home Ministry deems the eavesdropping to be vital to national security.

column1: Critics
column2: though
column3: say India’s campaign to monitor data transmission within its borders will hurt other important national goals: attracting global businesses and becoming a hub for technology innovation.

column1: The most inflammatory part of the effort  has been India’s threat to block encrypted BlackBerry services
column2: widely used by corporations
column3: unless phone companies provide access to the data in a readable format. But Indian officials have also said they will seek greater access to encrypted data sent over popular Internet services like Gmail
column4: Skype and virtual private networks that enable users to bypass traditional telephone links or log in remotely to corporate computer systems.

column1: Critics say such a threat could make foreigners think twice about doing business here. Especially vulnerable could be outsourcing for Western clients
column2: like processing medical records or handling confidential research projects
column3: information that is typically transmitted as encrypted data.

column1: “If there is any risk to that data
column2: those companies will look elsewhere
column3: ” said Peter Sutherland
column4: a former Canadian ambassador to India who is now a consultant to North American companies doing business there.

column1: S. Ramadorai
column2: vice chairman of India’s largest outsourcing company
column3: Tata Consultancy Services
column4: echoed that sentiment in a newspaper column on Wednesday. “Bans and calls for bans aren’t a solution
column5: ” he wrote . “They’ll disconnect India from the rest of the world.”

column1: Few doubt that India has valid security concerns. In recent years
column2: attacks against India have included the use of sophisticated communications technology — as when the terrorists who stormed Mumbai two years ago communicated with their Pakistani handlers by satellite phone and the Internet. Or when Chinese hackers infiltrated India’s military computer networks this year.

column1: But  critics say that India’s security efforts
column2: which they describe as clumsy
column3: may  do little to protect the country
column4: even as they intrude on the privacy of companies and citizens alike.

column1: “They will do damage by blocking highly visible systems like BlackBerry or Skype
column2: ” said Ajay Shah
column3: a Mumbai-based economist who writes extensively about technology. “This will shift users to less visible and known platforms. Terrorists will make merry doing crypto anyway. A zillion tools for this are freely available.”

column1: Senior Indian officials
column2: though
column3: argue that they have no choice but to demand the data that could help thwart and investigate terrorist attacks.

column1: “All communications which is done by Indians or coming to and fro into India — and where we have a concern about national security — we should have access to it
column2: ” said Gopal Krishna Pillai
column3: the secretary of India’s Home Ministry
column4: which oversees domestic security.

column1: During the Mumbai attacks
column2: he said
column3: officials could not gain access to some of the communications between the terrorists and their handlers.

column1: Some legal experts indicate that Indian law — which has few explicit protections for personal privacy — is on the government’s side. But they also say India is trying to enforce the law in unnerving ways.
“The concern of corporate users and general users of BlackBerry is that if this is allowed
column2: the government will become the single biggest repository of information
column3: ” said Pavan Duggal
column4: a technology lawyer who practices before India’s Supreme Court . “And we have no idea how this information will be used and misused in the future.”

column1: The Indian government has also clamped down on the importation of foreign telecommunications equipment
column2: saying it wants to ensure that the technology does not contain malicious software or secret trap doors that could be used by foreign spies.

column1: The technology and security debates playing out here are not new or unique to India.
During the 1990s
column2: for instance
column3: American security officials tried unsuccessfully to restrict the use of encryption because of worries that law enforcement would not be able to monitor communications. Now
column4: in legislation the Obama administration plans to introduce next year
column5: officials want Congress to require all services that enable communications — including encrypted e-mail systems like BlackBerry
column6: social networking Web sites like Facebook and software that allows direct “peer to peer” messaging like Skype — to be technically able to comply if served with a wiretap order.

column1: Currently
column2: other countries including the United Arab Emirates and Indonesia are trying to impose various measures similar to India’s.

column1: The debate here
column2: though
column3: is complicated by the fact that despite private industry’s technology prowess in this country
column4: in technologies like cryptography Indian law enforcement agencies still lag significantly behind their counterparts in the United States and other advanced countries.

column1: The Indian government says it is intent on improving its code-cracking skills. But “in the interim
column2: it has this very blunt instrument
column3: ” said Rajan S. Mathews
column4: the director general of the Cellular Operators Association of India
column5: a trade group. “It comes to the operators and says: ‘I’m going to make you responsible for giving me access
column6: ’¬†” he said.

column1: Mr. Pillai
column2: the Home Ministry secretary
column3: said the government was not opposed to the use of encryption to protect the privacy of legitimate electronic communications. But he said that as government-licensed entities
column4: network operators were obliged to give law enforcement officials a way to decode messages when required or to block communications that they cannot decipher.

column1: But network providers say they may not always have the technical ability to do that. In much of the world — including for business users in India — companies and individuals now often use encryption systems that generate new code keys for each message and lack a convenient master key that could unlock everything for government viewing.
Google
column2: for its part
column3: has enhanced the encryption for its Gmail service
column4: making it harder for hackers and the Indian government to read messages. Mr. Pillai said his ministry had begun conversations with Google and Skype
column5: the Internet phone company
column6: which also uses strong encryption
column7: to provide access to decoded data.

column1: Representatives for Google and Skype said that they could not comment because they had not yet received formal demands from the Indian government.
Meanwhile
column2: government officials have demanded that the maker of BlackBerry
column3: Research In Motion of Canada
column4: set up a server computer in India from which law enforcement agencies can gain access to unencrypted versions of messages when they need to. The government has given R.I.M. until the end of October to comply.

column1: The company has said that it is willing to meet “the lawful access needs of law enforcement agencies.” But the company says it cannot provide unencrypted copies of messages of corporate users because of how the BlackBerry system is designed
column2: noting that even R.I.M. cannot decode them.

column1: “Strong encryption has become a mandatory requirement for all enterprise-class wireless e-mail services today
column2: ” R.I.M. said in a statement in late August
column3: “and is also a fundamental commercial requirement for any country to attract and maintain international business.”

column1: Vikas Bajas reported from New Delhi
column2: and Ian Austen from Ottawa. Heather Timmons contributed reporting from New Delhi.

column1: A version of this article appeared in print on September 28
column3: on page B1 of the New York edition.

column1: 175;"I.H.T. Special Report: Business of Food
Singapore Looks to China for Food Security
Reuters
Piglets in Suining
column2: in Sichuan Province in China. The joint food zone project of China and Singapore will explore the feasi- bility of setting up a disease-free zone for producing pork for export to the city-state.

column1: By SONIA KOLESNIKOV-JESSOP
Reprints
SINGAPORE — Singapore is eyeing a gigantic farming project in northeast China that could help the small
column2: densely populated city-state diversify its food supplies
column3: while offering export opportunities for its expertise in food safety and investment opportunities for its businesses.

column1: One company
column2: Singapore Food Industries
column3: has already announced a joint venture to set up an integrated pig farm as part of the project. Another
column4: Singbridge International Singapore
column5: is studying the commercial feasibility of a joint venture in developing a giant food production zone jointly with the Jilin municipality.

column1: The China Jilin (Singapore) Modern Agricultural Cooperation Food Zone is an ambitious project covering 1
column2: 450 square kilometers
column3: or 560 square miles
column4: twice the area of Singapore. It is envisioned as a major food production center integrating farming with food processing
column5: storage and logistics.

column1: “There are similar large-scale projects now being worked on around the world
column2: but this is a world’s first in terms of joint regional private-public sector partnership
column3: ” said Veiverne Yuen
column4: associate director in the Food & Agribusiness Research and Advisory Asia team at Rabobank. Mr. Yuen was project manager of a conceptual feasibility study conducted by Rabobank for the food zone.

column1: In May
column2: the Jilin Provincial People’s Government announced the inauguration of the food zone
column3: which it described as a “major collaborative project” to improve food security and food safety for both Singapore and China.

column1: For a start
column2: the project will explore the feasibility of setting up a disease-free zone for producing pork for export to Singapore
column3: said Goh Shih Yong
column4: spokesman for Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority
column5: or A.V.A.
column6: the Singapore food regulator.

column1: Singapore currently imports more than 90 percent of the food it needs to feed its five million residents and the more than nine million tourists who visit every year.
According to A.V.A. data
column2: Singapore imports 96
column3: 200 tons of pork a year
column4: mainly from Brazil
column5: Indonesia and Australia. It also relies heavily on Australia for mutton and beef. It is looking to the Chinese venture both to diversify its food supplies and to increase their security.

column1: The pig farm is a joint venture of Singapore Food Industries; the DaChan Food (Asia) Co.
column2: based in Hong Kong
column3: one of the largest chicken meat products and feed suppliers in China; and the state-owned Jilin China-Singapore Food Zone Development Construction Investment Co.
column4: or J.C.S.

column1: Ground-breaking started this month
column2: and when the farm is completed over the next six years
column3: it is intended to incorporate a supply sequence starting with feed production and breeding and running through slaughtering and meat processing
column4: that could process a million pigs each year.

column1: “Pork is one of the main sources of protein
column2: especially for the majority of the Chinese population in Singapore. The project will leverage on the geographical and resource advantages of Jilin City to secure a safe
column3: reliable and sustainable supply of pork for the Singapore market
column4: ” said Poon Choon Liang
column5: chief operating officer of Singapore Food Industries.

column1: “Diversification helps us tackle the food challenges that affect global food supply and demand in the future. It is a key strategy in ensuring a resilient supply as it enables our traders to quickly switch to alternative sources and at the most competitive prices
column2: ” he said.

column1: Singapore has always tried to diversify its food sources as part of a strategy to stabilize local food prices .
It intensified those diversification efforts in 2008
column2: establishing new sources for pork in a number of countries
column3: including Poland
column4: Mexico and Spain. It also brought in live fish from Namibia and processed poultry from Turkey
column5: China and other countries.

column1: Mr. Yuen said that the availability of pig feed near the Jilin farm should enable it to produce pork at a lower cost.
More important
column2: the pig farm will be surrounded by a zone free of foot and mouth disease
column3: to be established and monitored by the A.V.A. following guidelines set out by the World Organization for Animal Health.

column1: “The A.V.A. is recognized as one of the world’s top institutions with regards to control of animal health and safety in food manufacturing. That’s because
column2: as a single entity
column3: it can streamline controls
column4: unlike most other countries where these different aspects of food safety are spread across different government organizations
column5: ” Mr. Yuen said.

column1: To establish and maintain the disease-free zone
column2: bio-security checkpoints will be set up to ensure that people disinfect their hands
column3: clothes and footwear when entering or leaving farms.

column1: Disease surveillance procedures will also have to be put in place
column2: involving the collection of samples from livestock for testing
column3: to check for contamination by circulating infections
column4: Mr. Ong said.

column1: Under the agreement
column2: the disease-free zone is expected to be established at the end of 2011. The zone is to be officially recognized by the Ministry of Agriculture in China and endorsed by the A.V.A.

column1: Jilin
column2: which lies in the central part of northeast China
column3: bordering Russia to the east and North Korea to the southeast
column4: is one of the world’s most productive corn-growing regions
column5: currently producing 20 percent of the corn grown in China.

column1: Yet the corn-belt region is producing well below its capacity.
“Agronomically
column2: the climatic and the soil characteristics are very similar to what you have in the corn belt in the Midwest in the United States
column3: so it’s very fertile black soil with optimal climatic conditions in terms of temperature and rainfall to grow feed grains
column4: ” Mr. Yuen said. “But on the ground
column5: the level of applied technology is still lagging what you have in the developed world
column6: so there is a lot of room to improve.”

column1: Harvests could be substantially raised by building more infrastructure
column2: including irrigation systems; by introducing modern farm management methods; and by using industrialized farm machinery
column3: he said.

column1: “We believe you could actually increase the corn yield in that region by anywhere from 50 to 80 percent.”

column1: 176;"Rabies deaths are on the rise in Vietnam
column2: according to the country’s National Institute of Hygiene and Epidemiology
column3: whose director blamed slack management by provincial health authorities and public ignorance of the threat.

column1: Related
Health Guide: Rabies
But subscribers to ProMED
column2: a disease-outbreak Web site
column3: have pointed out another contributing factor: in the mountainous rural northern provinces where the problem is worst
column4: many people are fond of eating dogs.

column1: Most rabies is transmitted by bites from stray dogs. The disease kills about 55
column2: 000 people a year around the world
column3: mostly children under 15
column4: according to the World Health Organization .

column1: In parts of Vietnam
column2: according to the national government
column3: only one dog out of 25 is vaccinated
column4: and there is a regular cross-country trade in dogs for the table. (Raising dogs for meat is popular in many countries
column5: especially in southeast Asia and West Africa .)

column1: A study in the journal PLoS Medicine last year described the deaths of two rabies patients in Vietnamese hospitals . Neither had been bitten
column2: but one had cut up and cooked a dog killed in a traffic accident
column3: while the other had eaten a sick cat.

column1: Many Vietnamese refuse to eat vaccinated dogs
column2: said Merritt Clifton
column3: editor of Animal People
column4: an animal protection magazine
column5: because the only vaccines locally available are grown in sheep brains using an outdated method invented by Louis Pasteur. If improperly stored
column6: those vaccines can give rabies to the dog
column7: and in turn to the diner.

column1: A version of this article appeared in print on September 28
column3: on page D6 of the New York edition.

column1: 177;"The Lede Blog: U.S. Soldier Charged in Murder of Afghans Was a Whistleblower
column2: Father Says (September 10

column1: The testimony
column2: in a hearing to determine whether one of those soldiers
column3: Specialist Jeremy N. Morlock
column4: would face a court-martial and a possible death sentence
column5: came the same day that a videotape in the case was leaked showing Specialist Morlock talking to investigators about the killings in gruesome detail with no apparent emotion.

column1: Top Army officials worry that the case against Specialist Morlock and four other soldiers accused in the killings of three Afghan civilians will undermine efforts to build relationships with Afghans in the war against the Taliban .
The soldiers are accused of possessing dismembered body parts
column2: including fingers and a skull
column3: and collecting photographs of dead Afghans. Some images show soldiers posing with the dead. As many as 70 images are believed to be in evidence.

column1: Some of the soldiers have said in court documents that they were forced to participate in the killings by a supervisor
column2: Sgt. Calvin Gibbs
column3: who is also accused in the killings. All five defendants have said they are not guilty.

column1: In one incident
column2: Specialist Morlock recounted in the video
column3: he described Sergeant Gibbs identifying for no apparent reason an Afghan civilian in a village
column4: then directing Specialist Morlock and another soldier to fire on the man after Sergeant Gibbs lobbed a grenade in his direction.

column1: “He kind of placed me and Winfield off over here so we had a clean line of sight for this guy and
column2: you know
column3: he pulled out one of his grenades
column4: an American grenade
column5: popped it
column6: throws the grenade
column7: and tells me and Winfield: ‘All right
column8: wax this guy. Kill this guy
column10: ’¬†” Specialist Morlock said in the video.

column1: Referring to the Afghan
column2: the investigator asked: “Did you see him present any weapons? Was he aggressive toward you at all?”

column1: Specialist Morlock replied: “No
column2: not at all. Nothing. He wasn’t a threat.”

column1: As Monday’s hearing was getting under way
column2: CNN and ABC News broadcast the video. In the CNN clip and the ABC clip
column3: Specialist Morlock
column4: speaking in a near monotone
column5: looks like a teenager recounting a story to his parents.

column1: CNN also broadcast video of the interview of a soldier who is not accused in the killings but has been accused of lesser crimes
column2: Cpl. Emmitt R. Quintal.

column1: When asked by an investigator when and how often members of the unit used illegal drugs
column2: Corporal Quintal
column3: seated in camouflage fatigues
column4: said it occurred on “bad days
column5: stressful days
column6: days that we just needed to escape.”

column1: The interview with Specialist Morlock was conducted in Kandahar in May
column2: while he was en route to a medical evaluation for what his lawyers said was possibly a traumatic brain injury suffered during his deployment. They say he was taking medication prescribed by military doctors for sleep deprivation
column3: pain and muscle stress
column4: though they said they could not yet establish exactly when he had taken the medication and how it might have affected him.

column1: Specialist Morlock
column2: who grew up in Wasilla
column3: Alaska
column4: appeared in court on Monday but did not testify.

column1: Michael Waddington
column2: his lawyer
column3: questioned Army investigators by phone from their duty station in Afghanistan. Mr. Waddington repeatedly asked whether they found Specialist Morlock to be under the influence of medication in the interviews. Some investigators described Specialist Morlock as tired and sometimes slouching
column4: but they said he was coherent and had a strong recollection of details.

column1: The video
column2: provided to defense lawyers to help them prepare their cases
column3: was not intended by the military to be made public.

column1: “The disclosure of these video recordings is troubling because it could adversely affect the military justice process
column2: ” said Col. Tom Collins
column3: an Army spokesman.

column1: The power of images in the case was apparent last week
column2: when the commander of the Stryker brigade in which the soldiers serve ordered photographic evidence to be strictly controlled by investigators at Joint Base Lewis-McChord
column3: with access limited to lawyers.

column1: A memo circulated by a military defense lawyer the previous week described an inadvertent release of photographs
column2: including three that show American soldiers holding up the heads of dead Afghans. It was unclear whether all of the pictures showed soldiers in the cases
column3: though military prosecutors said Monday that Specialist Morlock was in at least one image
column4: apparently with a dead Afghan.

column1: Photographic evidence could play an important role in the Army’s case
column2: as will statements from soldiers. No bodies have been recovered
column3: and a military investigator testified on Monday that the nature of the areas where the crimes occurred
column4: including religious views of residents and potential danger to American soldiers
column5: prevented them from conducting crime scene investigations.

column1: “To exhume a body would cause a lot of issues
column2: even if it was for a good purpose
column3: ” said Special Agent Anderson D. Wagner.

column1: Mr. Wagner noted that at least two statements
column2: from Specialist Morlock and another soldier charged
column3: Pfc. Adam C. Winfield
column4: corroborated elements of each other’s story. He also said there was little physical evidence connecting the soldiers to the killings. “I don’t know the final thing that killed those guys
column5: whether it was a bullet or whose grenade it was
column6: ” Mr. Wagner said.

column1: The Army’s case is complicated by claims that it ignored warnings that there was trouble in the unit. Private Winfield’s father has said he repeatedly tried to alert military officials that his son had told him through Facebook in February that a murder was committed by members of his unit in January. The soldiers are accused of killings in January
column2: February and May.

column1: Mr. Waddington said in an interview that his client was present where the three crimes are said to have taken place
column2: but that he had not killed anyone.

column1: Mr. Wagner
column2: the investigator
column3: said that during his interview in May
column4: Specialist Morlock had feared retaliation for talking.

column1: Lawyers for Specialist Morlock told reporters during a break that the case reflected a “failed policy” in Afghanistan
column2: and that soldiers like Specialist Morlock should never have been allowed to continue with their unit given the medication they say he was on and the alleged widespread use of drugs in the unit. Seven other soldiers in the unit are accused of other crimes
column3: including hashish possession.

column1: It could be weeks before the military investigator presiding over the hearing
column2: Judge Thomas Molloy
column3: determines how to charge Specialist Morlock.

column1: Elisabeth Bumiller contributed reporting from Washington.
