column1: 178;"American and Afghan Troops Begin Combat for Kandahar
Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
Last week
column2: 2nd Lt. James Potter called for helicopter support as insurgents attacked in Kandahar Province
column3: where active combat had begun in an offensive. More Photos ¬ª

column1: ARGHANDAB
column2: Afghanistan — American and Afghan troops began active combat last week in an offensive to drive the Taliban out of their strongholds surrounding the city of Kandahar
column3: military officials said Sunday.

column1: Multimedia
Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
Smoke rose after helicopters struck an insurgent position during a firefight in the Zhari District. More Photos ¬ª
The New York Times
Active combat began last week in three districts. More Photos ¬ª
In the last several days
column2: soldiers shifted from guarding aid workers and sipping tea with village elders to actively hunting down Taliban fighters in marijuana fields and pomegranate orchards laced with booby traps.

column1: Sixteen Americans have died in the push so far
column2: including two killed by a roadside bomb on Sunday.

column1: The combat phase began five or six days ago in the Arghandab
column2: Zhari and Panjwai Districts
column3: Brig. Gen. Josef Blotz
column4: a NATO spokesman in Kabul
column5: said
column6: defining the current phase for the first time.

column1: “We expect hard fighting
column2: ” he said of the offensive
column3: whose objective is to clear the Taliban from three districts to the west and south of the city.

column1: Winning over Kandahar
column2: the birthplace of the Taliban
column3: is considered crucial to President Obama ’s efforts to shift the balance of power in Afghanistan after the militants’ comeback of recent years.

column1: “This is the most significant military operation ongoing in Afghanistan
column2: ” General Blotz
column3: who is with the International Security Assistance Force of NATO
column4: said
column5: calling it the “top operational priority now.”

column1: This is the first large-scale combat operation involving multiple objectives in Kandahar Province
column2: where a military offensive was originally expected to begin in June. That offensive was downgraded to more of a joint civil-military effort after the military encountered problems containing the Taliban in the much smaller city of Marja and because Afghan leaders feared high civilian casualties.

column1: During the last week of August
column2: at the instigation of Afghan authorities
column3: American troops supported a major push into the Mehlajat area on the southwest edge of Kandahar City
column4: driving the Taliban from that area with few casualties on either side.

column1: At the time
column2: military officials said that was the beginning of what would be an increase in active combat around Kandahar.

column1: Bismillah Khan
column2: the police chief in the Zhari District
column3: confirmed that the combat operation there began on Saturday
column4: but he declined to give further details. Some of the heaviest fighting has been in Zhari
column5: where troops have been told to avoid contact with local people because of widespread hostility toward foreign forces there.

column1: Zhari is the hometown of the Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar
column2: and it also sits astride the strategic Highway 1
column3: connecting Kandahar with Helmand Province to the west.

column1: Often the soldiers there run what are known as “move to contact” patrols that have no goal but to draw fire from the Taliban so aircraft can find and kill them.
Last Tuesday
column2: a United States Army platoon left Forward Operating Base Wilson early in the morning and within 10 minutes
column3: Taliban insurgents had opened fire with small arms
column4: machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades.

column1: Although helicopter gunships were soon overhead to support the ground forces
column2: the insurgents continued to fire on the patrol throughout the day as the troops made their way through vineyards and fields of marijuana plants 10 feet high.

column1: None of the Americans were wounded or killed on that patrol.
Journalists from The New York Times
column2: during a weeklong stay there
column3: observed that every time soldiers left their bases
column4: they were either shot at or hit with bombs
column5: often hidden or booby-trapped.

column1: Frequently
column2: the Taliban did not — as they normally would — stop shooting once air support arrived.

column1: Soldiers on a recent patrol
column2: clearing up after one bomb explosion
column3: discovered that a piece of debris lodged in a tree had itself been rigged with a tripwire
column4: practically under their noses.

column1: Here in Arghandab
column2: the flow of troops has made it possible to begin trying to take control of an area where thick vegetation
column3: irrigation canals and pomegranate orchards provide good cover for the Taliban
column4: according to Lt. Col. Joseph Krebs
column5: deputy commander for the Second Brigade Combat Team
column6: 101st Airborne Division
column7: but the results have been mixed.

column1: No sooner had the First Battalion of the 22nd Armored Regiment of the Army arrived here than five soldiers were killed on Aug. 30
column2: by a roadside bomb directed at their convoy. The dead included the first Army chaplain to be killed in active duty during the Afghan conflict.

column1: The chaplain
column2: Capt. Dale A. Goetz
column4: had been on a tour of some of the 18 combat outposts the military has established in the Arghandab District.

column1: Three days later
column2: rockets fired from orchards just outside the district center hit the dining tent at the main American base
column3: slightly wounding five soldiers.

column1: While no official casualty totals have been released for the recent operations in the Kandahar districts
column2: American military reports list 16 American fatalities in the Kandahar area since Aug. 30
column3: at least 10 of which were in the Arghandab or Zhari Districts.

column1: An effort to bring all of the heavily Pashtun south under coalition control began on Feb. 14 with an attempt to suppress the Taliban in and around Marja. Kandahar was to be the next target.
But the Taliban in Marja have still not been subdued
column2: so officials decided to concentrate first on bringing economic development to some districts around Kandahar city
column3: then on gradually stepping up military operations.

column1: “I look at each one of my 13 combat platoons as a development team
column2: ” said Lt. Col. Rodger Lemons
column3: commander of the First Battalion
column4: 66th Armored Regiment
column5: stationed at the district headquarters here.

column1: “I’m not going to tell you the population is fully in support
column2: but they are much more in support of the government and the coalition than they are of the Taliban
column3: ” he said.

column1: Along with the military buildup has come a similar effort to increase the presence of State Department employees
column2: along with aid contractors paid by the Americans
column3: who would serve as stabilization teams in those areas.

column1: Although some 300 American civilian staff members have arrived in Kandahar Province
column2: at the district levels there are only a few
column3: mainly because of security concerns.

column1: In Arghandab
column2: where the civilian effort is deemed to have been the most successful
column3: the district team consists of two Americans in addition to contractors and local employees.

column1: “It’s hard to get people to come here
column2: ” said Kevin Melton
column3: who is finishing up a yearlong tour running the State Department team in Arghandab.

column1: When Mr. Melton arrived
column2: the district government was not functioning.  Now
column3: there is an active shura or village council
column4: with people coming to the district government’s building regularly
column5: attracted by generous aid programs.

column1: “Five dead and that’s the news that gets out
column2: ” Mr. Melton said
column3: referring to the first fatalities in Arghandab. “Yeah
column4: we know what’s going wrong
column5: but look what’s going right. If we had done this eight years ago
column6: would we have been here now?”

column1: By comparison

column1: Zhan Qixiong

column5: China

column1: The Japanese request was effectively a retort to China’s demand that Japan apologize and offer compensation for the episode
column2: even after Japan had freed the captain last Friday in what was widely seen as a capitulation to placate an increasingly assertive China.

column1: On Sunday
column2: Japan’s prime minister
column3: Naoto Kan
column4: called China’s latest demands “unthinkable
column5: ” a sign of his sensitivity to criticism that Japan had shown timidity to Chinese bullying.

column1: “Naturally
column2: we will be asking for the boats to be returned to their original condition
column3: ” the chief cabinet secretary
column4: Yoshito Sengoku
column5: told a news conference here on Monday.

column1: The Japanese release of the captain seemed aimed at defusing a heated standoff in which China had imposed economic sanctions and even detained four Japanese.
But the Japanese were clearly surprised when China then said that Tokyo must offer an apology and unspecified compensation over the arrest
column2: which took place almost three weeks ago and aroused deep anger in China.

column1: The demands have forced Mr. Kan to decide once again whether Tokyo will stand up to Beijing
column2: which in recent years has appeared to be testing Japan’s resolve to back its territorial claims in the East China Sea.

column1: In the days leading up to the captain’s release
column2: the Chinese curtailed tourism to Japan
column3: suspended many political and cultural ties
column4: and took unannounced steps to restrict shipments to Japan of rare-earth minerals
column5: which are important components for a range of industrial products.

column1: But the move that Japan found most alarming was the detention in the northern city of Shijiazhuang of the four Japanese citizens
column2: accused of photographing military sites.

column1: The dispute illustrated the difficulty of overcoming nationalistic sentiments stirred up by the trawler episode
column2: which is affecting the deeply intertwined ties between the two neighbors
column3: the world’s second- and third-largest economies
column4: after that of the United States. It also raised concern across Asia about China’s willingness to use its growing economic clout for political gains.

column1: Japanese leaders had sought to minimize the episode
column2: saying that the Chinese captain’s release was a decision made by local prosecutors. Those assertions were met with broad skepticism
column3: with many here holding the view that Japan capitulated to aggressive Chinese pressure.

column1: This has led to growing criticism in Japan that Mr. Kan’s government showed weakness. “It looks like Japan caved in
column2: ” said Sadakazu Tanigaki
column3: the head of the largest opposition party
column4: the Liberal Democrats. “That sends the wrong signal to China.”

column1: 181;"China Rights Report Cites Improvements
column2: but Also Failings

column1: By IAN JOHNSON
BEIJING — China released a report on human rights on Sunday
column2: highlighting the country’s willingness to deal with the highly contentious issue but also the differences between its perceptions of human rights and those of many other countries.

column1: Related
Times Topic: China
The report acknowledged that China suffers from large inequalities in its practice of human rights
column2: and that “there is still much room for improvement in its human rights conditions.” But it said that the country had made large strides despite difficult economic times.

column1: Published on the Internet in Chinese and English
column2: the report lists achievements in a variety of fields
column3: including the growing role of the Internet. It noted that many government agencies now routinely use the Web to gauge public opinion
column4: and highlighted a new law passed this year to outlaw police brutality and torture after expos√©s in the local press about the abuse of detainees.

column1: Outside human rights groups said that these steps were real and that China deserved credit for them
column2: but they pointed to what they said was the country’s history of passing laws that are not enforced. “China deserves credit for taking that step of making new rules where they didn’t exist before
column3: ” said Joshua Rosenzweig of the Dui Hua Foundation
column4: a human rights group in Hong Kong. “But that can’t stand for actual results. The legislation itself needs to be enforced before you can measure its impact.”

column1: Assessing enforcement is difficult because the government outlaws independent human rights monitors.
Over all
column2: the report contrasts sharply with outside assessments. This year
column3: the United States State Department found in its annual review of human rights that the situation in China remained “poor and worsened in some areas.”

column1: Part of the reason for these widely divergent opinions has to do with China’s definitions of human rights. Much of its report was taken up with a detailed discussion on the economic rights of the Chinese people and how the growing economy was raising living standards and providing better education. Many international human rights organizations consider these rights
column2: while important
column3: to be a separate category. For China
column4: however
column5: they are at least on a par with rights like free speech and the right to assemble and to vote without intimidation.

column1: Despite those differing views
column2: some critics were encouraged.

column1: “It is positive because people will talk about it and it gets in the local media
column2: ” said Wan Yanhai
column3: a public health activist who recently left China because of harassment. “But it is publicized by the government for outsiders.”

column1: A version of this article appeared in print on September 27
column3: on page A7 of the New York edition.

column1: 182;"Reprints
KUALA LUMPUR — With the Islamic finance industry worth an estimated $1 trillion and growing rapidly
column2: it is perhaps no surprise that a number of Asia-Pacific nations are among a growing band of countries worldwide to signal their intention to carve out a larger share of the market.

column1: Related
M.I.T. Weighs Charges for Online Lectures (September 27
Countries like Malaysia
column2: Indonesia and Singapore
column3: along with Hong Kong
column4: have set their sights on becoming hubs for Islamic finance
column5: where investments are made according to Islamic principles. (Under Shariah
column6: or Islamic law
column7: charging interest and making investments in industries like gambling and alcohol are forbidden.)

column1: While their  sectors may be at varying stages of development
column2: they are facing a common predicament: a shortage of professionals skilled in Islamic finance.

column1: Education institutions around the Asia-Pacific region
column2: like their counterparts in the Middle East and Europe
column3: are increasingly seeking to fill that gap by adding Islamic finance specialization to their master’s programs in business administration and elsewhere.

column1: The number of such courses available in Kuala Lumpur
column2: home to the most developed Islamic finance sector in the region
column3: is growing rapidly. A number of business schools now offer Islamic finance components as part of their M.B.A. programs
column4: and the Universiti Tun Abdul Razak
column5: a private institution in Kuala Lumpur
column6: will offer a new M.B.A. in Global Islamic Finance for students enrolled for the semester starting in October.

column1: Malaysia’s International Center for Education in Islamic Finance
column2: which was established by the central bank in 2006
column3: is working with a growing number of universities around the region and elsewhere to help them start Islamic finance courses.

column1: The center
column2: which teaches its own programs
column3: including master’s and doctoral degrees
column4: has already worked with universities in Malaysia
column5: Indonesia and Britain
column6: and is fielding a growing number of inquiries from institutions around the world
column7: from South Korea and Hong Kong to France and Germany.

column1: The president and chief executive of the center
column2: Agil Natt
column3: said Islamic finance was now considered a viable alternative to conventional finance
column4: and business schools were responding to industry demand for skilled professionals.

column1: “People are beginning to clamor for more qualified people
column2: ” he said. “Suddenly it dawned on the universities that this is a growing market.”

column1: The new M.B.A. in Global Islamic Finance at the Universiti Tun Abdul Razak will be available to all students enrolled in the International Business School Alliance
column2: a grouping of universities from Germany
column3: Spain
column4: Russia
column5: the United States
column6: Britain and Malaysia.

column1: Students who choose the Islamic finance specialization will study core M.B.A. subjects for their first semester at the university of their choice
column2: followed by a semester of Islamic finance subjects like the application of Islamic commercial law and Islamic banking products
column3: at the Malaysian university. Students will conduct research into an aspect of Islamic finance
column4: like the sector’s regulatory systems
column5: in their third semester.

column1: Ong Fon Sim
column2: dean of the university’s Graduate School of Business
column3: said it decided to introduce the one-year
column4: full-time program to meet the growing demand for Islamic finance professionals.

column1: “It’s the government’s aspiration to make Malaysia into a global Islamic finance center
column2: ” she said. “Islamic finance and banking is here to stay. Everybody recognizes that. Because of that
column3: we think there should be demand.”

column1: In Indonesia
column2: home to the world’s largest Muslim population
column3: the University of Indonesia began offering a Master’s in Islamic Banking last year after the country’s central bank asked the school to develop courses to help prepare students for the industry
column4: said Professor Firmanzah
column5: dean of the Faculty of Economics and Business
column6: who like many Indonesians uses only one name.

column1: The school also offers an Islamic banking specialization for M.B.A. students and plans to offer a bachelor’s in Islamic banking and a doctoral program next year. “We are focusing on Islamic banking since the growth of Islamic banking in Indonesia is quite high compared to traditional banks
column2: ” he said.

column1: Islamic finance education is spreading beyond the region’s Muslim-majority countries. La Trobe University in Melbourne started Australia’s first Master’s in Islamic Banking and Finance this year
column2: and has begun offering Islamic finance as an M.B.A. elective.

column1: The Master’s program has attracted students from as far away as Vietnam
column2: Hong Kong
column3: the United States
column4: Pakistan
column5: India and Saudi Arabia
column6: said Ishaq Bhatti
column7: director of the program.

column1: The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology’s Business School introduced an Islamic finance elective as part of its M.B.A. program in April.
John Wei
column2: director of the program
column3: said the university decided to offer the elective after observing the increasing influence and economic potential of Islamic countries.

column1: The spread of Islamic finance education is a trend the industry hopes will continue to pick up speed to help meet the growing need for skilled professionals
column2: said Rithuan Mohamed Shamsudin
column3: executive director of the Association of Islamic Banking Institutions Malaysia.

column1: 183;"Reprints
TOKYO — In a country with a shrinking population
column2: the latest trend in Japan ’s higher education is something of a mystery: the number of universities and academic programs is rising. The growth is sharpest for professional graduate schools
column3: where the number has soared from practically zero in 2003
column4: when accreditation began
column5: to 130 now
column6: in fields ranging from law and business to clinical counseling and education.

column1: Enlarge This Image
Everett Kennedy Brown/European Pressphoto Agency
An instructor with his class in Kanagawa Prefecture. Universities have responded to dissatisfaction with primary and secondary teaching by setting up graduate education programs.
Related
M.I.T. Weighs Charges for Online Lectures (September 27
But there is one obvious problem: not enough students are signing up.
The Japanese government says that nearly half of professionally oriented programs
column2: aside from law schools
column3: have yet to fill their stated student capacity. And the problem has been especially acute in graduate programs in education.

column1: Interest in many professional schools has been less than overwhelming
column2: said Kenichi Yoshida
column3: an executive senior consultant at the Japan Research Institute in Tokyo
column4: which is affiliated with Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp.

column1: “Japanese universities tend to roll out programs without having a good grasp of the needs in the marketplace
column2: ” said Mr. Yoshida
column3: who watches Japan’s higher education. “When they start a program
column4: they assume there will be students.”

column1: In Japan
column2: the need for graduate programs seems undeniable: lifetime employment is crumbling
column3: employers are committing less time and money to training young workers
column4: and social problems are becoming more complex
column5: increasing the need for experts.

column1: Setting up graduate programs in education was the universities’ answer to a growing dissatisfaction with the primary and secondary school system.
“We are faced with a number of gripping issues in schools like bullying
column2: truancy
column3: and falling grades
column4: ” said Tetsuya Kajisa
column5: the president of Hyogo University of Teacher Education near Osaka. “As society and community change
column6: issues facing schools have become more complicated and the solutions require higher expertise.”

column2: with the blessing and the accreditation of the Ministry of Education
column3: 19 universities launched professionally oriented graduate programs in teacher education
column4: seeking approximately 700 students in total. Seven more schools introduced similar programs a year later.

column1: During the first year
column2: 8 of the 19 original institutions fell short of the target enrollment — some by far: two schools managed to recruit only half of the target numbers of students. A ministry assessment completed shortly afterward said the schools lacked proper marketing methods and had failed to clearly state the practical benefits of receiving graduate diplomas.

column1: Mr. Kajisa
column2: who also heads an association for professional schools for teacher education
column3: said the system for teachers needed to be revised so that people with graduate degrees would get recognition through promotions or through some sort of licensing system that required taking graduate courses to upgrade a license
column4: as is the case in the United States.

column1: “There have to be initiatives taken at the national level” to create benefits to those with graduate certificates
column2: he said
column3: “because these schools were envisioned by the national government.”

column1: Currently
column2: local school districts have different policies regarding promotions and benefits for teachers with graduate degrees.

column1: Some schools are taking their own measures to increase enrollment. “We have gone around visiting undergraduate departments giving explanatory sessions and did what we could to let people know about our programs
column2: ” said Hirokazu Hirose
column3: a professor in the graduate program at Joetsu University of Education in Niigata Prefecture.

column1: The graduate school has also been placing an emphasis on practical training
column2: for example
column3: sending students to teach at local primary and secondary schools.

column1: Students teach lessons at local schools
column2: videotape the classes and then bring the tapes back for evaluation with other students. “Then we feed the solutions back to the classes
column3: ” Mr. Hirose said. “Essentially
column4: what we do is identify issues
column5: find the solutions and resolve issues in the classroom.”

column1: Following the efforts by Mr. Hirose and 20 of his colleagues
column2: the number of students enrolled grew from 32 in 2008 to 51 in 2009 at his graduate program. In 2010
column3: the school enrolled 60 students.

column1: A number of graduate students interviewed
column2: many of whom have had years of teaching experience before coming to the graduate programs
column3: generally held positive views about the in-class training.

column1: “It allowed me to structure and organize my knowledge and experiences
column2: ” said Kazuhiko Nishimura
column4: a graduate student at Hyogo University of Teacher Education and a high school social studies teacher in the southern Yamaguchi Prefecture
column5: currently on leave.

column1: Mr. Nishimura said he liked his graduate school’s integrated approach to practice and theory
column2: something he said was often missing among front-line teachers. “You need to understand the latest studies and theories in order to understand and overcome latest problems
column3: ” he said.

column1: Mr. Nishimura
column2: who has another six months to complete his master’s degree
column3: is due to carry out 150 hours of work at a high school in his native Yamaguchi starting this autumn
column4: including management training with the principal and teaching classes.

column1: Takanori Matsuoka
column3: a student at Joetsu and an elementary school teacher on leave
column4: said that the mix of practice and theory worked well. “I have had few opportunities to think theoretically about issues before
column5: ” he said. “What was significant was that I got to learn about something I had direct experiences in at school from a fresh theoretical perspective.”

column1: Students said they thought more teachers would be interested in enrolling if they had been given the opportunity to know more about what these professional schools actually did.
But some say that egalitarian thinking
column2: typical of Japan’s group-oriented society
column3: might stand in the way. If there was one main reason keeping teachers from attending
column4: “it would be that teachers in Japanese schools have this notion that they tackle problems by working together
column5: not by creating a super elite that transcends everybody
column6: ” Mr. Matsuoka said.

column2: the number of universities and academic programs has risen sharply. But there is one problem: Not enough students are signing up.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: 184;"Asia Begins Embracing Solar Power
By BETTINA WASSENER
HONG KONG — Developing nations in Asia
column2: it seems
column3: are finally seeing the light.

column1: A blog about energy and the environment.
Go to Blog
In May
column2: the Asian Development Bank started a major drive to promote solar power across the region. Last year
column3: the Indian government approved an ambitious National Solar Mission
column4: which seeks a huge increase in the country’s solar-energy capabilities. Bangladesh
column5: with the support of the World Bank
column6: is aiming to have one million remote rural homes supplied with solar panels by the end of 2012.

column1: And in India
column2: where nearly 40 percent of households have no access to electricity
column3: companies like Selco Solar and Orb Energy have helped tens of thousands of families and small entrepreneurs purchase solar panels.

column1: All worthy causes. So worthy and sensible
column2: in fact
column3: that you may well ask why on earth they did not take off much earlier.

column1: The answer
column2: as is so often the case
column3: is political support — or
column4: until relatively recently
column5: the lack of it — and
column6: inevitably
column7: cost.

column1: “The upfront costs of installing solar-electricity-generating farms
column2: plus high borrowing costs and the fact that developing nations struggle to access long-term capital
column3: have inhibited the growth of solar energy until recently
column4: ” said Seethapathy Chander
column5: chairman of the committee on energy issues at the Asian Development Bank in Manila.

column1: “It takes a long time before investment costs are recouped
column2: and you need long-term financing until that stage is reached.”

column1: That also applies to small
column2: single-household roof panels that provide enough electricity for a few extra hours of lighting
column3: which can make a huge difference — adding study time for children and extra hours for making and selling goods.

column1: Rooftop solar energy can replace kerosene
column2: which generates smoke and poor-quality light and eats heavily into the scarce resources of the poor.

column1: “A street vendor in India might make 800 rupees a month — that’s about $16
column2: ” said Harish Hande
column3: founder of Selco Solar in Bangalore. “But he might have to spend as much as 210 rupees of that on kerosene or candles.”

column1: By contrast
column2: the modest electricity produced by rooftop panels is effectively free
column3: recouping the initial investment after a few years. But even a 15 percent down payment on a loan for a small solar home lighting system — which typically costs 8
column5: 000 rupees — is beyond the reach of many families
column6: Mr. Hande said.

column1: In developing nations like Sri Lanka or India
column2: said Damian Miller
column3: an American-British citizen who set up Orb Energy in 2006
column4: the cost of a panel can be 20 percent of the annual income of a poor off-grid household.

column1: In terms of the scale of the investment
column2: he said
column3: “it’s similar to a Western household buying a car.”

column1: Banks were long reluctant to lend to the poor. Increasingly
column2: however
column3: companies like Selco and Orb Energy have been able to convince some local banks that low-income earners are creditworthy and that solar-related credits bring in solid business in much the same way that car financing does.

column1: “The trick to making it work commercially is to make it affordable: To allow for bite-size financing that the poor can pay for
column2: on a monthly basis
column3: rather than in large chunks
column4: ” said Mr. Miller.

column1: On the large-scale level — big solar farms that feed the overall electricity grid — activity also is picking up.
“Many parts of Asia have three or four times the amount of sun that Germany gets
column2: ” said Mr. Chander of the Asian Development Bank. “It makes a lot of sense to deploy solar-based electricity generation facilities here.”

column1: At the same time
column2: governments have become more willing to promote alternative energies and
column3: because of falling costs
column4: more able to do so.

column1: Over the years
column2: technological advances have made panels cheaper and more efficient
column3: while the global financial crisis created a glut of panels as many projects in Western countries stalled. China has become a major manufacturer and exporter of solar energy equipment
column4: though it has yet to generate solar power on a large scale.

column1: Cheaper panels
column2: combined with lower interest rates since the financial crisis
column3: have helped put solar energy systems within the financial reach of poorer nations
column4: said Anil Cabraal
column5: an alternative energy expert who
column6: until his retirement from the World Bank in April
column7: got many of the bank’s solar projects in Asia and Africa under way over the past decade.

column1: Under the solar initiative it announced this year
column2: the Asian Development Bank hopes to help put in place solar power projects with a total capacity of 3
column3: 000 megawatts by 2013.

column1: The total operating capacity now is less than 500 megawatts. (One megawatt is enough to cover the power demand of about 200 homes
column2: or 1
column3: 000 people
column4: in developing Asia.)

column1: The solar mission in India aims to have 20
column2: 000 megawatts of grid-connected solar energy by 2022
column3: up from only about 2 megawatts now.

column1: It also wants to help increase off-grid solar energy
column2: currently at about 20 megawatts a year
column3: to 10 times that amount by 2013
column4: and to 2
column5: 000 megawatts by 2022.

column1: The government has committed $20 billion to the program and is hoping it will attract additional investments from the private and financial sectors
column2: said Gauri Singh
column3: a senior official at the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy in New Delhi.

column1: Vast as those numbers are
column2: the combined target will still make up only a tiny fraction of the overall energy mix in India
column3: Ms. Singh acknowledged. What is more important
column4: she said
column5: was that the initiative will help utility operators and manufacturers expand their knowledge of solar technology.

column1: Of course
column2: solar energy will never be able to wean the world fully from its reliance on fossil fuels. Right now
column3: solar energy accounts for less than a quarter of a percent of overall energy demand in Asia
column4: and only 1 percent or 2 percent in the United States
column5: according to Mr. Chander at the Asian Development Bank.

column1: Once the various solar initiatives start operating in Asia

column1: 185;"September 23
Yunnan Province in Three Dimensions
In order to view this feature
column2: you must download the latest version of flash player here .

column1: These aren’t your childhood pop-up books.
In June
column2: we invited the photographer and artist Colette Fu to  help Zach Wise
column3: a multimedia producer
column4: create   360-degree  portraits of her project
column5: “ We Are Tiger Dragon People .”

column1: The pop-up project was Ms. Fu’s effort to  photograph the 25 ethnic minorities of China’s Yunnan Province
column2: where her mother was born and where she developed an interest in photography while teaching English in the mid-1990s. She spent 2008 traveling the region on a Fulbright scholarship.

column1: Growing up in New Jersey
column2: Ms. Fu liked making things with her hands. So when she found herself tiring of photography
column3: it made sense to add a third dimension to her work.

column1: “My dad always wanted me to be an engineer
column2: ” said Ms. Fu
column3: who has  lived in Philadelphia on and off since 2004
column4: at one point squatting in a warehouse. “Now
column5: ironically
column6: I’m a paper engineer.”

column1: She earned her master of fine arts degree in photography at the Rochester Institute of Technology in 2003. But there was no school for pop-up photography. Learning the craft was a do-it-yourself process. Ms. Fu tackled it during an artist’s residency at the Alden B. Dow Center for Creativity in Michigan
column2: where she deconstructed pop-up books she had bought on eBay.

column1: Movable books — an umbrella term that includes pop-up books — have been around for hundreds of years
column2: according to Ann Montanaro
column3: a former Rutgers University librarian and director of the Movable Book Society . Until 20th-century England
column4: many  were used to illustrate the structure of the human body and the location of the planets
column5: among other — mostly scientific — things. (Ms. Fu has also done projects with a scientific bent
column6: exploring concepts like anxiety in pop-up form.)

column1: The photographer Bruce  Foster created a pop-up book on sports photography
column2: but Ms. Montanaro said Ms. Fu is the only artist she has heard of using photography so realistically in pop-up format.

column1: “Other than publishers who have used inexpensive photographs to do children’s books
column2: ” she said
column3: “I really am not aware of anybody who has done anything  like what Colette is doing.”

column1: There are
column2: of course
column3: photographic challenges associated with pop-up design. Ms. Fu must take pictures face-on
column4: ensuring that she captures full-body views. She shoots flat to avoid shadows. And she takes as many photographs as she can
column5: focusing on anything that could work well in three dimensions. Rarely does she plan her pop-up work in advance. Much of the creative challenge is making sense of the collection of images that results from her travels.

column1: Movable books tend to appeal to a broad range of viewers
column2: Ms. Fu said
column3: meaning they can be used as tools for education. Part of her goal is to encourage curiosity in Yunnan Province.

column1: “Everybody likes to look at them
column2: ” she said of the books. “Whatever the content is
column3: they’re more likely to inquire about it.”

column1: The three photographs in the interactive graphic show:
1. The Axi Fire Festival. The Axi
column2: one of the 27 branches of the Yi people
column3: has the festival to honor Mu Deng
column4: the man who brought them fire.

column1: 2. A Dulong Woman. Only about 4
column2: 600 Dulong people live near the Dulong River in northwest Yunnan
column3: along the borders of Tibet and Burma. Dulong women believe that their tattoos resemble butterflies
column4: because the souls of the dead were said to turn into butterflies. As of 2009
column5: only 40 tattooed Dulong women were left in the region.

column1: 3. Dai Food. The largest number of Dai people live in Xishuangbanna
column2: a lush
column3: subtropical land where the soil is very fertile. Their food is similar to Thai food in that it combines sour
column4: spicy
column5: salty and sweet flavors.

column3: she added a third dimension.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: 186;"September 29
Afghanistan: Aftermaths
By ADAM FERGUSON
Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
A former Afghan National Army soldier sits at an International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) Physical Rehabilitation Center in Kabul
column2: where he receives physiotherapy and prosthetic treatment
column3: on June 12
column4: 2010. Doctors amputated both his legs above the knees after he was wounded by a roadside bomb.

column1: KANDAHAR — We often read about acts of war and engage with the drama of immediate events. But our attention moves on
column2: and lost to our perceptions of war are the daily struggles and successes of people whose lives continue beyond the tragedy.

column1: This series of portraits explores the aftermath of war: a boy with shrapnel wounds in his cheek from a suicide bombing
column2: a fruit seller made paraplegic by a bullet fired from an American convoy
column3: a farmer who caught the wrath of a Taliban bomb intended for soldiers.

column1: As Afghanistan’s most recent war winds on into its 10th year
column2: such stories multiply. And the Afghans who got too close carry on.

column1: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
Wahida
column2: a 40-year-old mother of six
column3: stands for a portrait at her brother’s house in Afghanistan on June 7
column5: her husband and one of her sons were traveling in a vehicle near a military convoy on Jalalabad Road in Kabul in 2004 when the convoy was attacked with a roadside bomb.

column1: “I heard a big explosion
column2: and then I don’t remember anything
column3: ” she recalled. “I woke up and I had lost my arms
column4: my husband
column5: and my son had lost an eye”. Wahida is now a double amputee above the elbows and has severe facial scarring from the explosion. She lives in a tent at her brother’s house and is supported by an allowance from the International Committee of the Red Cross.

column1: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
An Afghan man
column2: wounded in what his family claims was a NATO airstrike
column3: lies in Mirwais Hospital in Kandahar
column4: Afghanistan
column5: June 25
column6: 2010. Mirwais Hospital provides treatment to Afghans from Kandahar Province
column7: as well as the surrounding provinces of Zabul
column9: Helmand and Nimruz. Mirwais is supported by the International Committee of the Red Cross
column10: although if patients can afford it
column11: they go to Pakistan to receive medical treatment at private hospitals with better facilities.

column1: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
Aktar Muhammad
column2: a 25-year-old from Oruzgan Province
column3: sits at the I.C.R.C. Orthopedic Center
column4: where he was receiving physiotherapy and prosthetic treatment in Kabul on June 10
column5: 2010. Mr. Muhammad
column6: who is married with four children
column7: was farming in a field in Oruzgan province when he set off an improvised explosive device that he believes was planted by insurgents and intended for  NATO forces. His leg was amputated below the knee
column8: and he has facial wounds from the explosion.

column1: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
A man with burn injuries from a roadside bomb lies on a table while his wounds are dressed in Mirwais Hospital in Kandahar on June 24
Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
Haji Gul
column2: a 20-year-old paraplegic
column3: stands for a portrait at his home in Kabul
column4: Afghanistan
column5: on June 21
column6: 2010. In 2006 he was selling fruit on the road when a shot was fired into the crowd from an American convoy
column7: hitting him in the head and causing him to lose the use of his legs. He receives home schooling as part of an I.C.R.C. education program.

column1: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
Hikmatullah
column3: recovers from injuries sustained in a suicide bombing that struck a wedding party in the Arghandab District of Kandahar. He was being treated in Mirwais Hospital in Kandahar on June 26
column4: 2010. At least 39 people were killed and 70 wounded when the bombers attacked a wedding party with ties to a militia that was thought to have cooperated with United States Special Forces.

column1: 187;"September 28
Drones as Occupational Hazard
By STEPHEN FARRELL
The C.I.A. is intensifying its campaign of using drones to bomb the mountains in western Pakistan
column2: The New York Times reported on Tuesday. Stephen Farrell
column3: a Times correspondent and blogger for At War
column4: recalls his experience with drones flying overhead when he was kidnapped by the Taliban on the Afghan side of the border a year ago.

column1: Kirsty Wigglesworth/Associated Press A U.S. drone flies over the moon above Kandahar Air Field
column2: southern Afghanistan.

column1: “Tony Blair
column2: George Bush
column3: ” grinned the shovel-bearded Taliban commander
column4: pointing up to the sky from which a drone was clearly audible
column5: right above our heads.

column1: Shovel Beard could hear it. His men could hear it. I could hear it. But still the Taliban continued to sit in the open air
column2: clearly visible to the electronic eyes above.

column1: It was September 2009 and my Afghan colleague Sultan Munadi and I were being held captive by this group of Taliban near Kunduz in northern
Afghanistan.
For an entire day they sat out in the open
column2: chatting about the Chinese motorcycles propped against the farmyard wall
column3: fiddling with their Nokia and Motorola cellphones
column4: aware
column5: but apparently unconcerned
column6: about the eavesdroppers thousands of feet above us.

column1: They even carried out weapons drills in the open air. During one session
column2: Shovel Beard held up his heavy
column3: tripod-mounted machine gun with a single hand and pointed it toward the sky
column4: boasting that he had used it to shoot down helicopters

column1: It seemed unlikely that he would have been able to hit the right cloud
column2: never mind a fast-moving dot
column3: but no one was going to argue
column4: captive or underling. He spent half an hour inviting the younger Taliban to imitate him
column5: and showed evident delight when none was able to lift it above the shoulder
column6: as he could. They tried again and again
column7: and all failed.

column1: All this in the noon daylight
column2: pointing his barrel straight into the electronic eyes of the drones that were plainly audible
column3: but invisible
column4: above.

column1: Of course the Taliban’s insouciance might have derived
column2: in part
column3: from the fact that it was by no means the first time in Afghan history that foreign powers had sought to crush Afghans with air power.

column1: The fathers and uncles of these Taliban
column2: indeed
column3: possibly Shovel Beard himself because he seemed old enough
column4: had fought rocket-armed Soviet helicopter gunships
column5: as contemporary New York Times accounts record.

column1: And the Afghans of their great-grandfathers’ generation would have looked up into the skies in 1919 to see bombs falling from British warplanes of World War I vintage.
But right here
column2: right now the Taliban’s failure to take even the most basic precautions was beyond careless. It was the opposite of furtive. And these men
column3: whatever their shortcomings
column4: knew how to do furtive.

column1: So what was behind their near-suicidal behavior? Even allowing for the fact that village Taliban are hardly the highest-educated warriors in
the world?
Over the days
column2: clues to their thinking began to emerge.

column1: From their behavior
column2: their movements around the countryside and their readiness even to dine together by the dozen in the open air
column3: they appeared to have come to the conclusion that there was very little that they could do about the drones. Their enemy had an overpowering aerial superiority. It was a fact in the sky. The choice before them was to worry
column4: or to accept it as an occupational hazard. They chose the latter.

column1: Secondly
column2: they had an entirely different perspective. To us the drone was a hugely significant presence. While the Taliban clearly controlled the countryside around — we had driven around for days
column3: and there was not a single NATO or Afghan government soldier in sight — the drone was the one sign of wider military realities outside this small pocket of Taliban hegemony.

column1: But to them it appeared to be a minor irritant compared with what they had gone through in the past. One young farmer/Taliban said that they had all spent years as fugitives in and around these farmlands during the years when government forces controlled the area. The government knew who was Taliban
column2: so these men spent 24 hours a day hiding from Afghan National Army and NATO forces
column3: skulking indoors
column4: away from the human and electronic eyes of drones
column5: helicopters and government spies.

column1: However
column2: now they were no longer the hunted amid these rice fields and orchards
column3: indeed they were the hunter. They could go almost anywhere
column4: do almost anything. The drones were one of the only serpents left in their garden
column5: and that was a reduced threat that they felt they could live with.

column1: “You think this is difficult for us
column2: you think this is hardship
column3: ” said one
column4: after the third or fourth change of location within 24 hours. “Only two or three years ago we had to spend weeks and months locked inside buildings in the dark. Now it is much easier for us to move around and assemble than it used to be. This is nothing for us.”

column1: Some of this account was probably bluster. But some of it seemed plausible
column2: or at least consistent with realities on the ground in the area over recent years.

column1: But there was also a psychological factor
column2: one common among militant groups in the Middle East. While the Taliban will take the best weapons they can from whichever outside agency wants to supply or sell them
column3: they also seek to portray themselves as the underdog against the mighty West.

column1: It is a refrain you heard constantly from these men
column2: as from militants in Iraq
column3: Gaza and the West Bank. Faced with an enemy who can wield overwhelming power they seek to invert it
column4: to redefine military weakness as moral superiority
column5: and survival as victory.

column1: The enemy may have their F16s
column2: their MRAPs
column3: Humvees or Merkavas
column4: they argue
column5: but without these shiny foreign toys they are nothing. Just wait until the American empire is gone and we are fighting on a level playing field. Maybe in 20 years
column6: 100 years
column7: 200 years. We can wait. Can they?

column1: As long-term strategies go
column2: Afghanistan’s history has much that can be cited in support of it. But forces of history for the next millennium are one thing. Force protection for the next week is another.

column1: Within days most of these men were likely dead
column2: killed by NATO forces who tracked their movements through the very drones about which they were so careless.

column1: So
column2: too
column3: was my Afghan colleague
column4: Sultan
column5: and Corporal John Harrison
column6: one of the British soldiers who carried out the raid. Civilians also.

column1: Probably not Shovel Beard. He had disappeared 24 hours earlier.
;Drones as Occupational Hazard";"A Times correspondent ponders why the Taliban seemed so unconcerned about the drones overhead.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: An Education Fund for Sultan Munadi's Children
The colleagues and friends of Sultan Munadi
column2: who was slain during a rescue operation in Afghanistan
column3: would like to thank readers for the many generous donations they made to help his family. Sultan’s family is extraordinarily grateful to them as well.

column1: 189;"Three Faces of the New China
Susan Walsh/Associated Press
UNITED NATIONS — In a blur of headlines over the past few days
column2: Americans have been surprised with  brief
column3: seemingly contradictory glimpses of how China is wielding  its newfound power.

column1: Related
Kyodo/Reuters
POWER PLAY Japan was forced to rescind the arrest of a trawler captain.
There was China the neighborhood bully
column2: cutting off Japan’s access to rare-earth minerals unless Tokyo folded in a minor
column3: but longstanding
column4: territorial dispute. (The Japanese folded.)

column1: There was China the schmoozer
column2: with its prime minister
column3: Wen Jiabao
column4: trying his hardest on Thursday to deflect President Obama ’s pressure over the value of China’s currency — really a battle over whether jobs go to workers in Seattle or Shenzhen. The two leaders talked for two hours at the United Nations .  The outcome was left unclear.

column1: And there was China the classic realist
column2: opting for convenient inconsistency on sanctions against North Korea and Iran in efforts to balance its competing national interests.  (The first is to engage the West on the Security Council. The others include  securing oil and protecting a client-state from collapse.)

column1: In one sense
column2: there’s nothing surprising about a rising power finding subtle ways to handle complex problems. But before China’s breakout  from poverty to arguably the world’s No. 2 economy
column3: its default position on foreign policy was to restate the principle of non-interference in other nations’ affairs and focus largely on its neighborhood.

column1: That was before it had the military resources and the incentive to start thinking of how to secure and defend interests around the globe. Today
column2: its interests include access to oil in places like Sudan and Iran
column3: safe shipping around the Horn of Africa
column4: the ability to manipulate its currency for its own gain.

column1: And for the first time
column2: the world is seeing a distinct range of behaviors
column3: from aggressive to passive-aggressive to diplomatic
column4: in places that 20 years ago China’s leaders rarely thought about.

column1: What American diplomats and analysts now have to figure out is what drives China’s actions and responses
column2: how to try to shape them and
column3: some would argue
column4: what limits to try to set.

column1: “The China that President Obama hoped he was getting a year ago
column2: the one that becomes this great cooperative global power on the biggest issues of the day — that’s not the China he’s dealing with today
column3: ” said David Shambaugh
column4: director of the China policy program at George Washington University .

column1: A senior administration official who often deals with the Chinese leadership said: “As they begin to manage their many constituencies
column2: their politics is looking more like ours.”

column1: Here’s a scouting report so far on China’s style of muscle-flexing:
THE NEIGHBORHOOD: TIME FOR THE BIG STICK
For decades countries around Asia have been wary of China’s resurgence — tracking how many ships and missiles it was acquiring
column2: and how it was using its influence as an investor. A decade ago
column3: as President Bush took power
column4: a number of neoconservatives urged him to “contain” China’s presumed ambitions.

column1: But containment would have probably been impossible and it proved
column2: at least in the past decade
column3: unnecessary. So far Beijing has not pressed new territorial claims; it has simply begun to defend old ones in sparsely inhabited places.

column1: The Japanese stepped into one of those when they arrested the captain of a Chinese trawler near a group of islands in the East China Sea
column2: called the Senkaku by the Japanese and the Diaoyu by China. The Japanese said the trawler rammed a Japanese coast guard vessel. A few years ago this might have been sorted out quietly  as a consular issue. Not this time.

column1: The Chinese — perhaps driven by the People’s Liberation Army
column2: perhaps eager to begin to declare their equivalent of the Monroe Doctrine — demanded the captain’s return. Japan refused. Pushed by a nationalistic groundswell
column3: China started blocking shipments of the rare earths
column4: an act that threatened Japan’s electronics industry.

column1: “This played to the Asia First crowd in China
column2: ” said Mr. Shambaugh
column3: referring to a faction in China’s establishment that says the wise course is to dominate the region while avoiding tussles with great powers. In recent months there have been disputes over American exercises in nearby waters and over the border with India.

column1: “We’ve begun pushing back
column2: ” said a senior administration official
column3: explaining why the United States is sending an aircraft carrier to the area.

column1: But the Japanese
column2: after 20 years of recession
column3: had no push left in them. The prosecutor dropped charges on Friday.

column1: WASHINGTON: THE ART OF DEFLECTION
If China’s strategy with Asia is all sharp elbows
column2: with the United States it is largely politeness and deflection — most of the time.

column1: ;Three Faces of the New China";"A rising power bullies
column2: cajoles or sidesteps. The pattern can confuse. Or it can reveal China’s real priorities.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: 190;"September 30
Indian Judges Rule on a Matter of Faith
By ROBERT MACKEY
Douglas E. Curran/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images In 1992
column2: Hindu fundamentalists broke through barricades and destroyed a 16th-century mosque at a disputed holy site in the Indian city of Ayodhya.

column1: Updated | 3:24 p.m. As my colleague Jim Yardley reports
column2: a three-judge panel in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh ruled Thursday that a plot of land in Ayodhya where a mosque was destroyed by Hindu fundamentalists in 1992
column3: sparking violence that left nearly 2
column4: 000 people dead
column5: should be divided between Muslims and Hindus.

column1: So far
column2: there have been no reports of violence in response to the court’s complex decision
column3: which lawyers representing both Muslim and Hindu groups said they would ask India’s Supreme Court to review. Documents containing what the court calls “the gist” of the three judges’ rulings were posted online (and are embedded at the end of this post).

column1: Before the verdict was issued
column2: Sopan Joshi wrote in the Indian newsweekly Tehelka
column3: “There is always agitation when a matter of faith is tested on scales of science and history.”

column1: Since they do make factual assertions about beliefs and faith traditions
column2: the rulings of the three judges make for remarkable reading. One judge
column3: Dharam Veer Sharma
column4: for instance
column5: ruled
column6: “The disputed site is the birth place of Lord Ram
column7: ” and then added this
column8: about the presence of the deity’s spirit at the site:

column1: Spirit of divine ever remains present everywhere at all times for anyone to invoke at any shape or form in accordance with his own aspirations
column2: and it can be shapeless and formless also.

column1: A video report of the ruling from Al Jazeera includes footage of the attack on the mosque in 1992.
In his article for  Tehelka
column2: Mr. Joshi anticipated the absence of violence in response to the verdict
column3: since
column4: he wrote
column5: both the national and local governments “want to maintain law and order to the point of an obsession.”

column1: He added
column2: “The administrative effort to that end is unprecedented. Anybody who has seen a riot at close quarters knows riots cannot happen when the government is committed to not letting them happen.”

column1: As Mr. Joshi explained
column2: the judges were asked to “tackle about 100 major and minor issues in the four suits that comprise the case
column3: ” delving into arcane issues of history
column4: religion and archaeology. Among other things
column5: the court was asked to consider whether the destroyed mosque
column6: built in the 16th century by India’s first Mughal ruler
column7: was
column9: constructed on the site of the birthplace of the Hindu deity Ram
column10: from stones of an older Hindu temple.

column1: The evidence presented to the judges included the results of excavations carried out by the Archaeological Survey of India in 2003
column2: which
column3: Mr. Joshi noted
column4: “found remains of structures with features indicating the existence of a north Indian Hindu temple underneath where the Babri Masjid stood. The question is: was it a temple of Ram? This is open to interpretation. Then
column5: the court has been asked to rule on whether this temple was demolished to build the mosque.”

column1: Also introduced into evidence were the observations of Joseph Tieffenthaler
column2: an Austrian Jesuit
column3: who arrived in India in 1740. The missionary recorded local accounts that held that two centuries earlier
column5: Babur
column6: India’s Muslim emperor
column7: had ordered the destruction of the house where Ram was said to have been born to “deprive the Gentiles of the opportunity to practice their superstitions.”

column2: posted on Scribd by India’s NDTV :

column2: the rulings of three Indian judges in a dispute with roots in the 16th century make for remarkable reading.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: November 19

column1: 193;"Reprints
When I used to ask my mother about her family village in China
column2: she always said it was three hours from Canton by bus. A hundred years ago
column3: when my great-grandfather left China for good
column4: that couldn’t have been far
column5: but it was certainly no help in locating it. So I was pleased — though still mystified — to read in Deborah Fallows’s charming and witty little book that in China
column6: “if you ask someone where their hometown is
column7: they’ll say it is seven hours by bus. Or four hours by train. They won’t tell you where it is.”

column1: DREAMING IN CHINESE
Mandarin Lessons in Life
column2: Love
column3: and Language

column1: By Deborah Fallows
Illustrated. 205 pp. Walker & Company. $22
Fallows spent three years living in China with her husband
column2: the journalist James Fallows . Since she’s a linguist by training
column3: her method of getting under the skin of the country was to immerse herself in its language. In “Dreaming in Chinese
column4: ” she uses key phrases and concepts to unlock aspects of the society that interested or surprised her
column5: casting light along the way on many idiosyncrasies of the Chinese view of the world.

column1: Fallows doesn’t arrive with many preconceptions. Instead
column2: she takes the Chinese as they see and present themselves. And she soon discovers that what the Chinese think is important isn’t always what we think is important. One thing they’re interested in is ensuring good luck. This explains why the Beijing Olympics began on Aug. 8
column4: at 8:08 p.m. Eight
column5: ba
column6: rhymes with fa
column7: “as in fa cai
column9: ’ ” making it a very auspicious number. And even though Aug. 8 was well into the rainy season

column1: Auspiciousness also enters into the choosing of names
column2: an art in itself. Most Chinese have three names: surname (there are just 100 common surnames in a population of 1.3 billion people)
column3: middle name (to identify your generation and connect you with your cousins) and personal name. Which yields the realization that — in a country where most people are allowed only one child — future generations will have no cousins.

column1: On matters that Westerners make a fuss about
column2: like human rights
column3: Fallows presents the common Chinese viewpoint. At a conference on censorship
column4: technology and commerce
column5: she recalls that “one exasperated Chinese participant finally blurted out that people
column6: the laobaixing
column7: aren’t as preoccupied as Westerners about free speech and an uncensored Internet: what laobaixing really want
column10: a refrigerator and a color TV.” For ordinary Chinese

column1: Fallows has an endearing affection for these laobaixing
column2: these common folk. Unlike conventional journalists
column3: she’s not very interested in press conferences
column4: in listening to what the politicians say. Little by little
column5: she finds herself becoming more like the laobaixing: learning to deal with the plethora of rules as the Chinese do — by finding ways around them.

column1: “Dreaming in Chinese” is chatty and colloquial
column2: with helpful photographs and drawings
column3: as well as a pronunciation guide. The eager student will learn a fair bit about the history of the language and how its array of characters and tones were systematized
column4: all the while gathering insights into the country’s customs and culture. Rather than draw sweeping conclusions
column5: Fallows sticks to her own experiences and observations
column6: which makes her book all the more valuable. China hands will have many moments of recognition. For others
column7: “Dreaming in Chinese” will be a fascinating introduction to a foreign culture.

column1: Lesley Downer is the author of “On the Narrow Road to the Deep North” and other nonfiction books on Asia. Her most recent book is a novel
column2: “The Courtesan and the Samurai.”

column1: A version of this review appeared in print on September 26
column3: on page BR16 of the Sunday Book Review.

column1: 194;"Chinese Writers Give a Warmer Take on U.S. Democracy
By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
Reprints
Shortly after Steven Shen’s parents joined him in Los Angeles in 2005
column2: his mother
column3: emboldened by an international dialing plan costing just $24.99 a month
column4: began making long telephone calls to relatives and friends back in Beijing. One day Mr. Shen asked: What did they talk about?

column1: “The main thing I tell them about is always the same
column2: how embarrassed I am about having criticized capitalism all my life
column3: and here I am now
column4: retired and appreciating it
column5: ” said the former high school teacher. She talked about receiving a free pair of eyeglasses for her failing vision; her husband
column6: a retired professor of Chinese
column7: got a hearing aid
column8: courtesy of what the family considers a generous welfare system for the elderly in the United States.

column1: “My parents worked all their lives for China
column2: and no one ever thought to take care of their eyes or ears
column3: ” Mr. Shen
column5: said in an interview.

column1: Mr. Shen’s book about his 21 years in the United States
column2: called “America Is Also Ridiculous
column3: ” went on sale  in Shanghai on Tuesday before an enthusiastic crowd of  students and scholars at Fudan University. Prepublication reviews have been overwhelmingly positive
column4: with endorsements from celebrities like the actor and film director Jiang Wen and the cult novelist Wang Shuo.

column1: Yet despite the seemingly critical title
column2: Mr. Shen’s book is no nationalist tract like “China Is Unhappy
column3: ” a 2009 book by five authors who accused the West of trying to keep China down. That book’s initial print run of 180
column4: 000 sold out quickly
column5: feeding off a potent mixture of dislike and envy that characterizes anti-Americanism in a country where
column6: for decades
column7: people campaigned against the evils of Western imperialism.

column1: “America Is Also Ridiculous ” is actually a paean to a country Mr. Shen loves and admires.
So why the provocative title? He grinned at the question.
“There are many things about America that strike our traditional mind-set
column2: me too
column3: as ridiculous
column4: ” he said. “For example
column5: sentencing a criminal to 180 years in jail. If he’s that bad
column6: why not just shoot him? Who’s going to pay to keep him in jail?” Many Chinese also disapprove of U.S. gun laws. “They say people own 300 million guns there. To us
column7: this is just crazy.”

column1: As China moves into its fourth decade of fast-paced economic reform
column2: much is changing here. “China is getting more and more integrated with the outside world. People are getting more critical. I would say their understanding of America is getting more and more real
column3: ” said Mr. Shen.

column1: A kind of subtle confluence is taking shape. Americans
column2: confidence badly shaken
column3: fret about China’s seemingly unstoppable economic growth and wonder when their country will be challenged as the global superpower. Here in China
column4: something else is happening: deeper understanding of democracy is producing greater admiration
column5: in some quarters.

column1: The reason is simple
column2: Mr. Shen said. “There is no perfect system. But if you have to choose between democracy and dictatorship
column3: you must choose democracy
column4: even with its many defects. Here we just don’t have the system to build up a modern civilization.”

column1: Over all
column2: however
column3: China’s attitude toward America is still polarized.

column1: “When we talk about the United States here in China
column2: there have always been two extremes
column3: ” Mr. Shen said. “One side is completely anti-American
column4: and the other is completely pro-American. These two sides have existed for a very long time and to get rid of them
column5: well
column6: there’s a long way to go. I don’t see any shortcuts to it.”

column1: Mr. Shen’s book is partly a story of personal transformation. A radio journalist
column2: he rejected the security of a state job for New York in 1989
column3: working his way up from restaurant jobs to his present position as film entrepreneur and chairman of the China-U.S. Business Summit
column4: based in Los Angeles.

column1: Mr. Shen’s is one of several recent Chinese books to capture this new phenomenon of what might be called critical admiration for America.
“Details of Democracy” is another
column2: a collection of columns by Liu Yu about politics and daily life in the United States
column3: drawing on the years she spent there between 2000 and 2007. She is now a politics lecturer at the University of Cambridge
column4: in England. Her book is intellectual as well as lively
column5: referencing writers like Alexis de Tocqueville. It hasn’t hurt sales.

column1: In fact
column2: the book is a hit. Published in June 2009
column3: it has sold nearly 120
column4: 000 copies and is in its 17th print run
column5: according to Shanghai Sanlian Shudian Press.

column1: Using vivid
column2: personal details
column3: Ms. Liu writes about a range of topics: disabled people in the United States winning fair treatment; how the legal system
column4: though prone to excesses
column5: regularly delivers justice; domestic opposition to the war in Iraq. She compares the individual stories to similar ones in China
column6: where the outcomes are usually far worse
column7: with civil society struggling for recognition
column8: the legal system weak and criticism of leaders or policies banned.

column1: As Mr. Shen and Ms. Liu know
column2: all of this closely relates to global politics and shifting power relations in this century
column3: because cultural values guide what we do
column4: even in the economy.

column1: Speaking in Geneva last month
column2: Henry A. Kissinger warned that the United States and China risked confrontation unless they created “a pattern of continuous cooperation.” At the same International Institute for Strategic Studies event
column3: the U.S. deputy secretary of state
column4: James B. Steinberg
column5: called on the two countries to build a relationship based on “strategic trust
column6: ” similar to the culturally based trust between Europe and the United States.

column1: Experts are skeptical. “I don’t see it developing
column2: simply because the U.S. and China do not share fundamental values in common
column3: either domestically or internationally
column4: ” said David Shambaugh
column5: a politics professor at George Washington University .

column1: In her afterword
column2: Ms. Liu writes
column3: “For so many years
column4: we spent so long judging the pros and cons of the ‘Western system
column5: ’ but we didn’t take the time to go and see what it really was.”

column1: By giving people a realistic picture of democracy that shows its merits to be greater than its flaws
column2: she and Mr. Shen are contributing to the shared cultural trust policy makers hope to see.

column2: in China
column3: something else is happening: deeper understanding of democracy is producing greater admiration
column4: in some quarters.<br clear=""both"" style=""clear: both;""/>

column1: 199;"China
Amid the media hoopla
column2: however
column3: some of China's super rich have stepped forward voluntarily.

column1: Chen Guangbiao
column2: a self-made millionaire and one of the few confirmed guests at the dinner
column3: told Gates and Buffett that he would donate his entire fortune
column4: an estimated $735 million
column5: to charity upon his death
column6: jokingly calling his decision a ""nice-to-meet-you"" gift for the Americans.

column1: I don't want to become a slave to my wealth
column2: he told CNN before the event.

column1: Chen
column3: whose parents were poor farmers
column4: now runs a booming renewable resources and recycling business in eastern Jiangsu province. He said he donated most of the $60 million profit his company made in 2009.

column1: Every dollar I made was with the help of others -- so I want to give it back to society and make my life more meaningful and valuable
column2: he said.

column1: China now boasts at least 189 billionaires (in U.S. dollars)
column2: second only to the United States
column3: according to a just-released list by Hurun Report
column4: a Shanghai-based publishing group that specializes in surveying the country's super rich.

column1: Wealthy Chinese seem unwilling to open their purse strings for charitable causes
column2: however.
a government-sponsored honor roll listed 121 Chinese philanthropists who donated a combined $277 million
column3: less than half of what a single American family -- financier Stanley Druckenmiller and his wife -- gave away in the same year in the United States.

column1: Many Chinese tycoons prefer to keep a low profile. Some worry about their safety and that of their children
column2: while others fear unwanted scrutiny from corrupt local officials.

column1: Yet others blame the lack of a legal framework or favorable taxation policies for their reluctance to publicly pledge donations as Chen did.
I'd rather focus on charity work through my company's own foundation
column2: by setting up education projects in poor provinces and encouraging employees to volunteer their time and effort
column3: Zhang Xin
column4: another confirmed guest at the dinner
column5: told CNN.

column1: Zhang
column3: one of China's biggest property developers
column4: sits on top of family holdings estimated to be worth more than $2 billion.

column1: Despite the philosophical difference
column2: Zhang tweeted that she and many other tycoons at the dinner professed their deep respect and admiration for Gates and Buffett as businessmen and philanthropists
column3: lining up for photos and autographs.

column1: Gates and Buffett say while they understand the concerns
column2: they encourage their Chinese guests to take a great leap forward with long-term impact on their communities.

column1: We hope that people who would join and put their names forth will have a good effect on people 50 years from now -- and I think it will
column2: Buffett said.

column1: No matter the method
column2: analysts say
column3: the timing is good for Chinese tycoons to put their wealth back into society. The government recently revealed that China's Gini coefficient
column4: a measure of income inequality
column5: had been above the 0.4 benchmark since 2000
column6: an alarming position shared by only a few other African and Latin American countries.

column1: It may take some time
column2: though
column3: to see the concept of philanthropy take roots in the minds of China's super rich
column4: since most of them have accumulated their fortunes only recently following the country's economic reforms.

column1: The average age of someone on China's super rich lists is 51
column2: about 15 years younger than their Western counterparts
column3: says Rupert Hoogewerf
column4: chief researcher at Hurun Report.

column1: Chinese entrepreneurs have made their money very quickly and they haven't really had time to think about how to spend it -- they are still in wealth-creation modes
column2: he said.

column1: Gates and Buffett acknowledge the challenge
column2: but remain optimistic.

column1: Philanthropy is new
column2: along with the new wealth here in China
column3: Gates said. ""So philanthropists meeting with each other -- and sharing ideas -- moves you up the learning curve a lot faster than if you are doing it in isolation.""

column1: Citing privacy concerns
column2: Gates and Buffett declined to name any of the participants at the dinner. State media reported guests were a who's who list in China's business world
column3: along with high-ranking government officials -- including the minister of civil affairs
column4: who is in charge of all charity work in the country.

column1: Gates did let on one name: action movie star Jet Li
column2: praising his effort in raising public awareness on the importance of philanthropy.

column1: The public has taken notice.
Wang Yifei
column2: a 28-year-old graphic designer struggling to set up his own business
column3: hosted a ""rival"" dinner to discuss philanthropy at a Holiday Inn Express hotel in Beijing on the same night
column4: packing more than 100 participants into a 56-seat venue.

column1: Those billionaires don't really know what we common people want
column2: he told CNN
column3: explaining his reason for throwing the $6 per head buffet dinner event.

column1: The potential of what ordinary people can do in philanthropy is huge
column2: he added. ""Most donations in the United States come from ordinary people and I think we can achieve the same in China if we can set up a good platform.""

column1: Even all the controversies surrounding the Gates-Buffett dinner may have been a blessing in disguise
column2: analysts say
column3: prompting a healthy debate on a topic largely ignored by the public before and marking a watershed for philanthropy in China

column1: Gates and Buffett are the two biggest authorities on the subject. By coming to China to talk about it
column2: they have sown the seeds in very fertile ground
column3: Hoogewerf said.

column1: 200;"United Nations
Kabul
column2: Afghanistan (CNN) -- Opium production has dropped significantly in Afghanistan
column3: in large part because of a plant infection in the country's war-torn south
column4: a U.N. report said on Thursday.

column1: This is good news but there is no room for false optimism; the market may again become lucrative for poppy-crop growers so we have to monitor the situation closely
column2: said Yury Fedotov
column3: executive director of the U.N. Office on Drugs and Crime.

column1: The development was detailed in the office's 2010 Afghan Opium Survey. Insurgents in Afghanistan have financed their operations through the opium trade.
The report said the total 2010 production was estimated at 3
column2: 600 metric tons
column3: down 48 percent from 2009.

column1: The decrease was largely due to a plant infection hitting the major poppy-crop growing provinces of Helmand and Kandahar particularly hard
column2: the report said.

column1: Plant diseases are a normal occurrence all over the world. In Afghanistan
column2: which produces 92 per cent of the world's opium
column3: they can affect the poppy crop. The current strain attacks the roots of the plant
column4: climbing up the stem and causing the opium capsule to wither away. These signs are similar to those observed in previous such outbreaks in the region
column5: the report said.

column1: Prices of opium are rising after a decline from 2005
column2: the report said.

column1: In the short run
column2: the decline in opium production has pushed prices up. Despite the drop in overall production
column3: the farm-gate income of opium farmers rose markedly. Now that opium is commanding high prices again
column4: the gross income for farmers per hectare has increased by 36 per cent to $4

column1: The report said opium cultivation remained stable with 98 percent of cultivation taking place in nine provinces in the south and west of the country.

column2: which sets out procedures for deporting migrants deemed to be staying illegally.

column1: The Roma sent home to Romania and Bulgaria are EU citizens

column1: President Sarkozy says the illegal Roma camps threaten to become shanty towns. He launched the crackdown in late July

column1: Row over memo

column1: The deliberate targeting of an ethnic minority

column1: France did not correctly transpose the rules on free movement of European citizens and
column2: as a result

column1: This must be corrected and that is why the Commission has acted firmly.""
