The Commission heard presentations on Wednesday from Ms Reding and two other commissioners on France's expulsions of Roma.
The Commission is analysing the situation of all other EU member states under the Directive on Free Movement
column2: to assess whether it will be necessary to initiate infringement proceedings also in other cases

222;"The new rules will require national governments not only to keep their deficits within the current limit of 3% of GDP
column2: but also to actively reduce their total debt towards 60% of GDP.

column1: Governments would be expected to cut one-20th of the excess debt every year.
So for example
column2: a country with 100% debt-to-GDP ratio would be expected to cut it by 2% a year.

column1: Most eurozone members are in breach of the 60% limit. Belgium
column2: Italy and Greece have debt close to or in excess of 100% of their GDP.

column1: And nearly all eurozone governments are currently in breach of the 3% deficit rule
column2: as they struggle to cope with high unemployment and dismal growth.

column1: However
column2: there is expected to be a three-year grace period for governments to meet the financial rules.

column1: Private debt
The desire to crack down on debt makes sense when looking at countries like Greece and Italy
column2: which racked up huge debts in the good times
column3: says BBC Europe business reporter Ben Shore.

column1: But he adds that it does not solve the problems of a country such as Spain
column2: which was never was a debt glutton and actually ran a budget surplus in the years leading up to the crisis.

column1: However
column2: that did not stop it being singled out by international investors as a big debt risk.

column1: The Spanish economy experienced a property bubble fuelled by private household debt - not government borrowing - during the last decade.
That bubble then burst
column2: bringing the construction sector - a major part of the Spanish economy - down with it.

column1: The Commission also wants to address this problem of private sector debt accumulation - what it calls ""economic imbalances"" - with the threat of fines.

A country that has been identified by Brussels as at risk would face an in-depth review resulting in a ""corrective action plan"" - a set of policy demands that the scrutinised government must carry out.
The action plans would first have to be agreed with the other national governments. Failure to carry the plan out would lead to fines.
Big fines
The proposed punishments will raise eyebrows
column2: our reporter adds.

column1: The fine for breaking budget rules will be 0.2% of GDP.
Eurozone governments - but not the UK - would be expected to deposit this amount in an account
column2: so it could be easily deducted if they persistently break the rules.

column1: There would be a separate fine of 0.1% a year for governments who fail to enact their action plans to deal with ""economic imbalances"" when told to do so.
However
column2: the Commission's monitoring and potential admonishment of offending governments may apply to all EU countries
column3: including the UK.

column1: Automatic punishment
More controversially
column2: the Commission wants these sanctions to be automatic
column3: but with a possible escape route if a transgressor can persuade other eurozone countries to let it off.

column1: The Commission said that the proposed new framework would be ""more rules-based
column2: and sanctions will be the normal consequence to expect for countries in breach of their commitments"".

column1: The idea is a response to the failure of the the original ""stability and growth pact"" rules for the euro.
The old rules also said that governments were should be fined for their budgetary transgressions.
But the fines were never implemented
column2: as even the likes of France and Germany failed to stay within the debt and deficit limits.

column1: French disquiet
The French finance minister (centre) greets her Spanish peer as their more austere German counterpart looks on
The proposal for automatic fines is politically controversial
column2: particularly with the French
column3: as it would entail unelected bureaucrats punishing elected politicians.

column1: To foresee a completely automatic mechanism
column2: a power totally in the hands of the experts
column3: no!"" said French Finance Minister Christine Lagarde earlier this week.

column1: She unveiled on Wednesday a budget for 2011 that is noticeably less austere than those of her eurozone neighbours.
Instead
column2: the French government will rely on stimulating faster growth to help it bring debt-to-GDP and deficit-to-GDP ratios within the required limits.

column1: Some economists also warn that in the current environment of anaemic consumer spending
column2: fiscal austerity may prove self-defeating for countries like Ireland and Greece.

column1: They say that the budget cuts will lead to recessions
column2: meaning lower tax revenues
column3: bigger unemployment benefit bills and falling GDP.

column1: This could make the EU's targets for debt-to-GDP and deficit-to-GDP ratios unattainable.
German stringency
However
column2: automatic fines - and eurozone government austerity - are being pushed by Germany.

column1: Berlin has already gained support for its strict view from a separate taskforce set up by the eurozone governments to look into the debt crisis.
The Commission also announced a new drive to make sure EU countries are not massaging their statistics
column2: in response to accusations that Greece consistently misreported how much it was borrowing.

column1: Governments will need to bring all aspects of their budgetary process - including accounting systems
column2: statistics and forecasts methodologies - into line with Europe-wide standards.

President: Bamir Topi
A research scientist and senior member of Prime Minister Berisha's Democratic Party
column2: Mr Topi was elected president for a five-year term by parliament in July 2007. Albanian is a parliamentary republic
column3: and executive power resides with the cabinet of ministers.

column1: Prime minister: Sali Berisha
The centre-right Democratic Party led by the former president
column2: Sali Berisha
column3: was re-elected by a narrow margin in parliamentary elections in July 2009
column4: defeating the main opposition Socialists.

column1: The election count
column2: which produced the closest result since Albania toppled communism in 1990
column3: was accompanied by disputes over procedure and claims of intimidation.

column1: Sali Berisha was re-elected in July 2009
The Socialists refused to recognise the election result
column2: and egan a campaign of mass protests and civil disobedience in support of demands for a partial recount.

column1: Mr Berisha first became prime minister following victory in general elections in July 2005.
That vote was also followed by wrangling over the count
column2: with re-runs demanded in a number of constituencies. It was nearly two months before the result was finally declared.

column1: An erstwhile communist
column2: Mr Berisha formed the Democratic Party in the early 1990s and in 1992 became Albania's first non-communist president since the Second World War.

column1: His bid to liberalise the economy fast increased hardship for the majority. His presidency came to an end in 1997 when the collapse of fraudulent pyramid investment schemes led to violent unrest.
As prime minister
column2: Mr Berisha promised to stamp out corruption
column3: reduce taxation
column4: attract greater foreign investment and develop the infrastructure.

column1: He succeeded in gaining Albania Nato membership in April 2009
column2: and the country formally applied for European Union membership the same month after a June 2006 Stabilisation and Association agreement.

column1: Born in 1944 and a former heart specialist
column2: Mr Berisha is known as an orator and has faced accusations of authoritarianism in the past.

column1: 230;"Media
One of the earliest Christian civilisations
column2: its first churches were founded in the fourth century. It later spent centuries largely under Turkic or Persian control and its rich cultural and architectural heritage combines elements from different traditions. The Armenian language is part of the Indo-European family but its alphabet is unique.

column1: Yerevan wants the world
column2: and particularly Turkey
column3: to recognize that the killing by the Ottoman Empire of hundreds of thousands of Armenians between 1915 and 1917 was genocide. Turkey says that there was no genocide and that the dead were victims of World War I. The governments of the two countries agreed to normalise relations in October 2009
column4: although Turkey has said opening the border will depend on progress on the Nagorno-Karabakh dispute.

column1: Republic Square in Yerevan
An independent Republic of Armenia was proclaimed at the end of the first world war but was short-lived
column2: lasting only until the beginning of the 1920s when the Bolsheviks incorporated it into the Soviet Union.

column1: When Soviet rule collapsed in 1991
column2: Armenia regained independence but retained a Russian military base at Gyumri.

column1: In the mid-1990s the government embarked on an economic reform programme which brought some stability and growth. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 2001.
Unemployment and poverty remain widespread. Armenia's economic problems are aggravated by a trade blockade
column2: imposed by neighbouring Turkey and Azerbaijan since the dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh. The conflict over the predominantly Armenian-populated region in Azerbaijan overshadowed Armenia's return to independence in 1991.

column1: Full-scale war broke out the same year as ethnic Armenians in Karabakh fought for independence
column2: supported by troops and resources from Armenia proper. A ceasefire in place since 1994 has failed to deliver any lasting solution.

column1: There is concern over safety at the Metsamor nuclear plant west of Yerevan. It was closed in 1988 following a catastrophic earthquake in the area but reopened in 1995 for economic reasons. The country is heavily reliant on it for electricity.
Armenia receives most of its gas supply from Russia and
column2: like some other republics of the former Soviet Union
column3: has had to face sharp price rises. The Russian gas giant Gazprom more or less doubled the price in April 2006. Russian gas arrives via a pipeline running through Georgia.

column1: Armenia has a huge diaspora and has always experienced waves of emigration
column2: but the exodus of recent years has caused real alarm. It is estimated that Armenia has lost up to a quarter of its population since independence
column3: as young families seek what they hope will be a better life abroad.

column1: Conversely
column2: Armenia is richly endowed with potential as a tourist destination and recent figures indicate that some success is being achieved in attracting visitors.

column1: 231;"Media
President: Heinz Fischer
Heinz Fischer
column2: a centrist politician committed to the welfare state and Austrian neutrality
column3: was elected to the largely ceremonial presidency in April 2004 and again 2010.

column1: Heinz Fischer - committed to the welfare state
In the 2010 poll he warded off a challenge by Barbara Rosenkranz of the anti-foreigner and anti-European Union Freedom.
He has spent most of his life in politics. After graduating with a law degree from the University of Vienna in 1961
column2: he took a position in the Social Democratic Party (SPOe)
column3: entering parliament as a deputy in 1971 and staying on until 2004.

column1: During this time
column2: he served as science and research minister between 1983 and 1987
column3: before being elected parliamentary president in 1990. He was re-elected three times.

column1: Between 1992 and 2004
column2: he was also a vice-president of the European Socialist Party.

column1: Once in office
column2: he officially renounced any party membership to become independent.

column1: Chancellor: Werner Faymann
Mr Faymann is seen as a pragmatis
A new grand coalition government was sworn in in Austria in December 2008
column2: two months after snap general elections.

column1: It is made up of the centre-left Social Democrats (SPO) and the conservative People's Party
column2: whose previous coalition collapsed during the summer.

column1: Social Democrat leader Werner Faymann took the job of chancellor
column2: while Josef Proell of the People's Party serves as vice chancellor and finance minister.

column1: The Social Democrats won the September elections with 30% of the vote. But they
column2: and the People's Party
column3: with 26%
column4: suffered their worst results since 1945. Far-right parties won nearly 29% of the vote
column5: doubling their support since the 2006 elections.

column1: Mr Faymann is a former Vienna city councillor and was transport and infrastructure minister in the cabinet of his predecessor
column2: Alfred Gusenbauer. He is seen as a pragmatist with a populist streak.

column1: In his inaugural address
column2: Mr Faymann stressed the need for political compromise among members of the previously fractious coalition
column3: and he outlined measures for helping the country to deal with the global economic downturn.

column1: 232;"Ilham Aliyev took over as president from his father
column2: Heydar

column1: Ilham Aliyev succeeded his father Heydar as president
Heydar Aliyev described his son as his ""political successor"". When his father died
column2: Ilham was already prime minister
column3: vice chairman of the state oil company and deputy leader of the ruling New Azerbaijan Party (NAP).

column1: He won the 2003 presidential elections by a landslide. Western observers were highly critical of the campaign which they said had been marred by voter intimidation
column2: violence and media bias. Opposition demonstrations were met with police violence. There were many arrests.

column1: Heydar Aliyev
column2: a former Soviet Communist leader
column3: reinvented himself as a post-independence political strongman and had ruled Azerbaijan with an iron fist since 1993 following a period of great instability. His record on human rights and media freedom was often criticised in the West.

column1: The opposition continues to have strong doubts about Ilham Aliyev's commitment to democracy.

These were reinforced when police used force to break up opposition demonstrations in Baku in the run-up to and following November 2005 parliamentary elections in which the ruling NAP won well over half of the seats. OSCE and Council of Europe observers declared that the vote fell a long way short of international standards.
Mr Aliyev won a second term of office in 2008
column2: scoring an overwhelming victory in an election that was boycotted by the main opposition parties. Western observers said that although the conduct of the election represented a marked improvement on previous votes
column3: it still fell short of fully democratic standards.

column1: He looked set to cement his grip on power even further when a move to lift the two-term limit on the president was approved in a referendum in March 2009
column2: paving the way for a possible third term.

column1: Ilham Aliyev was born in 1961 and has a doctorate in history. His business interests have enabled him to build substantial personal wealth since independence. He is married with three children.

column1: 233;"Media
It has been ruled with an increasingly iron fist since 1994 by President Alexander Lukashenko. Opposition figures are subjected to harsh penalties for organising protests.
In early 2005
column2: Belarus was listed by the US as Europe's only remaining ""outpost of tyranny"". Since late 2008
column3: there have been signs of a slight easing of tensions with the West - a development initially viewed with some concern by Russia
column4: which has since begun to distance itself from Lukashenko's personal rule.

column1: AT-A-GLANCE
Politics: President Lukashenko is seen as ""Europe's last dictator"". He's been in power since 1994
Economy: Soviet-style economy is considered to have been subsidised by cheap Russian gas
International: A key oil and gas pipeline from Russia to Europe runs through Belarus
Timeline
The country became independent in 1991
column2: following the collapse of the Soviet Union.

column1: More than a decade later
column2: the sense of national identity is weak
column3: international isolation continues and the nature of political links with Russia remains a key issue.

column1: In the Soviet post-war years
column2: Belarus became one of the most prosperous parts of the USSR
column3: but with independence came economic decline. President Lukashenko has steadfastly opposed the privatisation of state enterprises. Private business is virtually non-existent. Foreign investors stay away.

column1: For much of his career
column2: Mr Lukashenko has sought to develop closer ties with Russia. On the political front
column3: there was talk of union but little tangible evidence of progress
column4: and certainly not toward the union of equals envisaged by President Lukashenko.

column1: Belarus remains heavily dependent on Russia to meet its own energy needs and a considerable proportion of Russian oil and gas exports to Europe pass through it.
Russia's role as a major energy supplier to the rest of Europe and Belarus's position as a key transit country have come under the spotlight several times since 2006
column2: when tensions first arose between Moscow and Minsk over the price of Russian gas and Belarus's privileged access to duty-free oil.

column1: Relations with Russia deteriorated sharply in the summer of 2010
column2: with disputes over energy pricing
column3: customs union terms and the presence in Belarus of ousted Kyrgyz president Bakiyev
column4: prompting speculation that Moscow might switch support from Lukashenko to another leadership candidate.

column1: 234;"King: Albert II
Outgoing prime minister: Yves Leterme
Mr Leterme handed in his resignation in April 2010 after the government collapsed when a key coalition partner pulled out in a row over francophone rights in Dutch-speaking areas near Brussels
column2: thus paving the way for an early election.

column1: Mr Leterme's premiership has been dogged by intercommunal tensions
He stayed on in a caretaker capacity until early parliamentary elections on 13 June. The separatist New Flemish Alliance emerged as the largest single grouping from the vote
column2: although the French and Flemish Socialists together had more seats overall.

column1: Belgium's fractured political landscape means coalition negotiations are often a complex and lengthy process
column2: and there are fears that this could leave the country without a stable government when the country assumes the EU's rotating presidency in July 2010.

column1: During the three years since the previous general election
column2: in July 2007
column3: Mr Leterme held the prime ministerial office twice and offered his resignation three times.

column1: Though his Flemish Christian Democrats emerged as the clear winners in the 2007 election
column2: a long period of deadlock followed as he struggled to form a coalition government
column3: which then lurched from one crisis to another for most of 2008.

column1: Mr Leterme made little headway on the vital issue of devolving more powers to Belgium's regions
column2: and his premiership saw frequent flare-ups of tensions between the French- and Dutch-speaking communities.

column1: The first time that Mr Leterme tendered his resignation
column2: King Albert II refused to accept it. When he offered to resign for the second time
column3: in December 2008
column4: his departure was occasioned not by inter-communal tensions but by a banking bailout scandal at the height of the global financial crisis.

column1: Mr Leterme was then succeeded by his Flemish Christian Democrat colleague Herman Van Rompuy
column2: who a year later became President of the European Council
column3: leaving the Belgian premiership vacant once more.

column1: On re-assuming office in November 2009
column2: Mr Leterme identified economic recovery and the threat of rising unemployment as his government's priorities. However
column3: it was the divisive linguistic issue that brought about the fall of the government.

column1: 235;"Media
It is now an independent state
column2: but under international administration. Its three main ethnic groups are Bosniaks (Bosnian Muslims)
column3: Croats and Serbs. The war left Bosnia's infrastructure and economy in tatters. Around two million people - about half the population - were displaced.

column1: International administration
column2: backed at first by Nato forces and later by a smaller European Union-led peacekeeping force
column3: has helped the country consolidate stability.

column1: Symbol of hope: Rebuilt bridge at Mostar
But early in 2007 the International Crisis Group
column2: a think tank
column3: warned: ""Bosnia remains unready for unguided ownership of its own future - ethnic nationalism remains too strong.""

column1: The 1995 Dayton peace accord
column2: which ended the Bosnian war
column3: set up two separate entities; a Bosniak-Croat Federation of Bosnia and Hercegovina
column4: and the Bosnian Serb Republic
column5: or Republika Srpska
column6: each with its own president
column7: government

column1: Overarching these entities is a central Bosnian government and rotating presidency. In addition there exists the district of Brcko which is a self-governing administrative unit
column2: established as a neutral area placed under joint Serb
column3: Croat and Bosniak authority.

column1: Dayton also established the Office of the High Representative (OHR). The Office's representative is the state's ultimate authority
column2: responsible for implementation of Dayton and with the power to ''compel the entity governments to comply with the terms of the peace agreement and the state constitution''.

column1: Critics of Dayton said the entities it created were too close to being states in their own right and that the arrangement reinforced separatism and nationalism at the expense of integration.
Negotiations to amend the existing constitution
column2: established by Dayton
column3: in order to strengthen state institutions and transform the country into a non-ethnic parliamentary democracy
column4: have so far failed to make much progress.

column1: EU talks
In a bid to encourage Bosnia to resolve its ethnic divisions and eventually qualify for EU membership
column2: EU foreign ministers gave the go-ahead in late 2005 for talks on a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the country.

column1: The prospect of talks with the EU is thought to have increased pressure for the capture of two key Bosnian Serb war crimes suspects
column2: Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic.

column1: After nearly 13 years on the run
column2: Radovan Karadzic was arrested in July 2008 by Serbian security forces in Belgrade. His trial on war crimes charges opened at the UN tribunal in The Hague in October 2009.

column1: But local elections in October 2008 had in the meantime reinforced Bosnia's ethnic divisions
column2: with nationalist parties doing well among all three ethnic groups.

column1: And only days before the Karadzic trial opened
column2: efforts by the EU and US to break the stalemate on constitutional reform and prepare the country for eventual EU and Nato membership ended in failure when leaders of the three main ethnic groups rejected the proposals.

column1: The Bosnian Serb leadership in particular continues to be resentful at having to accept the authority of the OHR
column2: giving rise to suspicions that its ultimate goal is for the Republika Srpska to break away from the Bosniak-Croat Federation.

column1: 236;"President: Georgi Parvanov
President Georgi Parvanov
Georgi Parvanov won a second five-year term with a landslide victory in October 2006. He beat nationalist Volen Siderov
column2: who opposed EU entry.

column1: Bulgaria's presidents are elected to five-year terms. Although the president is head of the armed forces
column2: the role is largely ceremonial. Legislative power is exercised by the prime minister and parliament.

column1: Prime minister: Boiko Borisov
The centre-right GERB party led by Sofia mayor Boiko Borisov was the clear winner in general elections held in July 2009.
Voters punished the Socialist-led governing coalition of Sergei Stanishev for failing to crack down on corruption and organised crime.
Mr Borisov's poll campaign centred on promises to jail corrupt officials and mafia bosses and pull the country out of its worst economic downturn in years.
Boiko Borisov
Mr Borisov is a black belt and former coach of the national karate team
column2: who began his career as a fireman in Communist Bulgaria. He created a private security company in the early 1990s and was bodyguard to both the ousted dictator Todor Zhivkov and to exiled Bulgarian king Simeon Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.

column1: After Mr Saxe-Coburg-Gotha became prime minister in 2001
column2: he appointed Mr Borisov to one of the top jobs in the Interior Ministry.

column1: While there
column2: Mr Borisov earned himself the image of a tough operator
column3: but his critics accused him of populism
column4: arguing that his well-publicised actions did not result in a serious crackdown on organised crime.

column1: He was elected an MP in 2005
column2: but resigned his seat
column3: opting to run successfully for mayor of the capital Sofia several months later. He formed GERB (Citizens for European Development of Bulgaria) the following year.

column1: As leader of the new government
column2: Mr Borisov is faced with the task of changing Bulgaria's image as one of Europe's most corrupt countries in the middle of an economic crisis. He has said he may ask the International Monetary Fund for help
column3: a move that was resisted by his predecessor.

column1: 237;"Media
Croatia's EU Accession talks were postponed because of its failure to detain Gen Ante Gotovina
column2: wanted by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.

column1: Croatia later got the green light for talks to proceed in October 2005. The fugitive general was arrested in Spain shortly afterwards.
Tourists flock to the medieval port of Dubrovnik
The country hopes to become a member of the EU by 2011 - representing remarkable progress since the time of Tudjman's death in December 1999
column2: when the country was in a parlous state.

column1: Its citizens suffered from government-backed attacks on their civil and political rights. The governing party
column2: the HDZ
column3: was then corrupt and the economy was in difficulties
column4: with around 20% of Croatians unemployed.

column1: Presidential and parliamentary elections at the beginning of 2000 ushered in politicians who pledged commitment to Croatia's integration into the European mainstream.

The constitution has been changed to shift power away from the president to the parliament. Croatia has joined the World Trade Organisation and has pledged to open up its economy. It has achieved growth and inflation is under control.
However
column2: organised crime and mafia-linked violence have continued to be a major concern
column3: and the government is seeking to demonstrate that it is serious about tackling the problem so as not to jeopardise its EU membership aspirations.

column1: A dispute with Slovenia over sea and land borders dating back to the break-up of Yugoslavia also threatened to derail Croatia's journey to EU membership until June 2010
column2: when a Slovene referendum cleared the main obstacle to Croatia's EU accession.

column1: 238;"Media
In 1974 the island was effectively partitioned with the northern third inhabited by Turkish Cypriots and the southern two-thirds by Greek Cypriots.
A ""Green Line"" - dividing the two parts from Morphou through Nicosia to Famagusta - is patrolled by United Nations troops.
The UN drew up the Green Line as a ceasefire demarcation line in 1963 after intervening to end communal tension. It became impassable after the Turkish invasion of 1974
column2: except for designated crossing points.

column1: The island's partition has been in place since 1974
In 1983 the Turkish-held area declared itself the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. The status of Northern Cyprus as a separate entity is recognised only by Turkey
column2: which keeps around 30
column3: 000 troops in the north of the island.

column1: The prospect of EU enlargement concentrated minds in the search for a settlement. UN-sponsored negotiations continued throughout 2002 and a peace plan was tabled. Soon afterwards the EU invited Cyprus to become a member.
But hopes that the island could join united were dashed when leaders of the Turkish and Greek communities failed to agree to the UN plan by the March 2003 deadline.
In the months that followed travel restrictions were eased
column2: enabling people to cross the border for the first time in nearly 30 years
column3: raising hopes that progress might be on the way.

column1: As EU entry approached
column2: a revised UN reunification plan was put to both communities in twin referendums in April 2004.

column1: The plan was endorsed by Turkish Cypriots - though not by their then leader Rauf Denktash - but overwhelmingly rejected by Greek Cypriots. Because both sides had to approve the proposals
column2: the island remained divided as it joined the EU in May. EU laws and benefits apply only to the Greek Cypriot community.

column1: More than two years later
column2: hopes of progress were rekindled at UN-sponsored talks between Cypriot President Tassos Papadopolous and Turkish Cypriot leader Mehmet Ali Talat. The two agreed on a series of confidence-building measures and contacts between the communities.

column1: Hopes were given further impetus by the election of Demetris Christophas as president in February 2008. He immediately began talks with Mehmet Ali Talat on reuniting the country as a bizonal federal state.
However
column2: the initial optimism faded as talks made only slow progress through 2008
column3: and hopes for a deal were dealt a blow by the victory of right-wing nationalists at parliamentary elections in northern Cyprus in April 2009.

column1: Talks stalled through 2009
column2: and the nationalists consolidated their dominance of northern Cyprus by winning the presidential election there in April 2010.

column1: Turkey has a particular interest in seeing the situation resolved as its own EU aspirations are linked to the island's future.

column1: 239;"President: Vaclav Klaus
The former PM and current president is known as a Eurosceptic
Vaclav Klaus of the conservative Civic Democratic Party succeeded Vaclav Havel
column2: with whom he had many clashes in previous years
column3: in the largely ceremonial role of president in February 2003.

column1: Parliament narrowly re-elected him in February 2008.
He was the architect of Czech post-communist economic reforms
column2: serving as finance minister in the first post-communist government and prime minister between 1992 and 1997 before financial scandals contributed to the fall of his government.

column1: Mr Klaus is a bitter opponent of closer EU integration - although he insists that his views are more ""Eurorealist"" than ""Eurosceptic"". He signed the ""Lisbon"" European Union reform treaty in November 2009
column2: the last European leader to do so.

column1: Prime Minister: Petr Necas
The head of the centre-right Civic Democrat party (ODS)
column2: Petr Necas
column3: was asked by President Klaus to form a government after the May 2010 general election.

column1: Petr Necas has vowed to push through an austerity budget
Prior to the election
column2: the Czech Republic had been in political limbo for over a year
column3: and Mr Necas inherits a difficult job.

column1: For the past year
column2: the caretaker government of Jan Fischer has been keeping things ticking over
column3: but pressing problems such as the country's swelling deficit have yet to be dealt with.

column1: Mr Necas formed a coalition with the right-wing TOP 09 party and the centrist Public Affairs party.
Between them
column2: the three parties hold 118 out of the 200 seats in the Czech parliament.

column1: They are agreed that reducing the budget deficit should be the priority of the new coalition.
A physicist by training
column2: Petr Necas joined the ODS in 1991. He was first elected to parliament in 1996 and became minister of labour and social affairs in 2006.

column1: He succeeded Mirek Topolanek as leader of the ODS in March 2010.
He is married and has four children.

column1: 240;"The Danes rejected the euro as the national currency in a referendum in September 2000. Analysts believe that Danish fears of loss of political independence and national sovereignty outweighed any economic arguments about the benefits of joining the eurozone.
Please turn on JavaScript. Media requires JavaScript to play.

Denmark's euroscepticism put it at odds with many of its European partners seven years previously when Danish voters rejected the Maastricht Treaty which proposed monetary union and a common European defence force. Denmark had to be granted opt-outs from these provisions before the treaty was approved in 1993.
The Social Democrats led a string of coalition governments for most of the second half of the last century in a country generally known for its liberal traditions.

column1: Hungary's post-communist economic transition was achieved relatively smoothly. Within four years of the collapse of communism nearly half of the country's economic enterprises had been transferred to the private sector

column1: Ten years later

column1: 248;"In recent years Iceland enjoyed a standard of living that was among the highest in the world. Its prosperity initially rested on the fishing industry
column2: but with the gradual contraction of this sector the Icelandic economy developed into new areas.

column1: Please turn on JavaScript. Media requires JavaScript to play.

column2: Iceland had come to epitomise the global credit boom. Its banks expanded dramatically overseas and foreign money poured into the country

column2: Icelandic banks had foreign assets worth about 10 times the country's GDP
column3: with debts to match
column4: and Icelandic businesses also made major investments abroad.

column1: The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed the Icelandic economy's dependence on the banking sector
column2: leaving it particularly vulnerable to collapse.

column1: In October 2008
column2: the government took over control of all three of the country's major banks in an effort to stabilise the financial system. Shortly after this
column3: Iceland became the first western country to apply to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for emergency financial aid since 1976.

column3: intended to investigate the impact of whales on fish stocks

column2: Mr Basescu has drawn international praise for his anti-corruption efforts and for preparing Romania to join the EU.

column1: In 2005 Mr Basescu started the process of opening the files of the feared communist-era secret police - the Securitate. Researchers cleared him of accusations that he collaborated with the Securitate.
Mr Basescu was 53 at the time of his election. He was transport minister between 1996 and 2000.
His predecessor
column2: Ion Iliescu
column3: had dominated Romanian politics since the fall of communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in 1989. Under his Social Democrats
column4: Romania entered Nato and moved towards EU membership.

column1: Prime minister: Emil Boc
Parliament first approved the appointment of Democratic Liberal Party leader Emil Boc as prime minister on 22 December 2008.
Mr Boc has pledged tough action to stave off financial crisis
However
column2: only 10 months later
column3: his government lost a confidence vote in parliament
column4: with MPs accusing it of failing to improve the country's recession-hit economy.

column1: Parliament subsequently rejected President Basescu's nominee to succeed Mr Boc
column2: Lucian Croitoru
column3: and Mr Boc carried on in a caretaker capacity until presidential elections in November and December 2009.

column1: After Mr Basescu was re-elected as president
column2: he nominated Mr Boc to lead a new government
column3: which was duly approved by parliament on 23 December 2009.

column1: The new centrist government - a coalition made up of the Democratic Liberal Party
column2: an ethnic Hungarian party and several independent allies - immediately unveiled an austerity budget for 2010
column3: and promised tough action to tackle the continuing financial crisis.

column1: Analysts say Mr Boc faces one of the toughest jobs in Romania's post-Communist history in winning acceptance for the belt-tightening measures needed in order to meet the International Monetary Fund's demands and unfreeze tranches of a 20bn euro aid package
column2: which are vital to prevent Romania from plunging deeper into recession.

column1: Government proposals to tackle the budget deficit by cutting public-sector wages and pensions triggered mass protests in Bucharest in May 2010.
Mr Boc's political career has been closely associated with that of Mr Basescu
column2: who nominated him as executive president of the Democratic Party in 2003.

column1: The Democratic Party later merged with the Liberal Democrats to form the Democratic Liberal Party.
A member of parliament in 2000-2004
column2: Mr Boc rose to prominence in 2004 when he beat veteran nationalist Gheorghe Funar to become mayor of Cluj-Napoca
column3: the main city of his native Transylvania. He was re-elected with 76% of the vote in 2008.

column1: An academic specializing in political science and law
column2: Mr Boc was born in 1966 and is married with two daughters.

In the period of rapid privatisation in the early 1990s
column2: the government of President Boris Yeltsin created a small but powerful group of magnates
column3: often referred to as ""oligarchs""
column4: who acquired vast interests in the energy and media sectors.

column1: President Yeltsin's successor
column2: Vladimir Putin
column3: moved to reduce the political influence of oligarchs soon after taking office
column4: forcing some into exile and prosecuting others.

column1: Mikhail Khodorkovsky

column3: is serving eight years in a Siberian penal colony on tax and fraud charges. Yukos assets were later acquired by the state oil giant Rosneft.

column1: Russia resurgent
During Mr Putin's presidency Russia's booming economy and assertive foreign policy bolstered national pride. In particular
column2: Russia promoted its perceived interests in former Soviet states more openly
column3: even at the cost of antagonising the West.

column1: St Petersburg's State Hermitage houses a vast art collection
The tensest moment came in August 2008
column2: when a protracted row over two breakaway regions of Georgia escalated into a military conflict between Russia and Georgia.

column1: Russia sent troops into Georgia and declared that it was recognising the independence of Abkhazia and South Ossetia
column2: sparking angry reactions in the West and fears of a new Cold War.

column1: At the same time
column2: Moscow threatened to counter plans by the US Bush administration to develop an anti-missile system in Eastern Europe with its own missiles in Kaliningrad Region on Poland's borders. President Obama later withdrew the plan
column3: in a move seen in Russian official circles as a vindication of the assertive foreign policy.

column1: Another source of irritation between Russia and the US is Moscow's role in Iran's nuclear energy programme. Russia agreed in 2005 to supply fuel for Iran's Bushehr nuclear reactor and has been reluctant to support the imposition of UN sanctions on Iran.

A gradual warming in relations between Russia and the US early in 2010 culminated in the signing of a new nuclear arms treaty designed to replace the expired Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (Start) of 1991.
Though disagreements remain between Moscow and Washington over US plans for a missile defence shield
column2: there are signs that the thaw in relations could extend to a greater willingness on the part of Russia to apply pressure on Iran over its nuclear programme.

column1: Economic muscle
The annual Victory Day parade marks the end of World War II

Russia's economic power lies in its key natural resources - oil and gas. The energy giant Gazprom is close to the Russian state and critics say it is little more than an economic and political tool of the Kremlin.
At a time of increased concern over energy security
column2: Moscow has more than once reminded the rest of the world of the power it wields as a major energy supplier. In 2006
column3: it cut gas to Ukraine after a row between the countries
column4: a move that also affected the supply of gas to Western Europe

column1: Ethnic and religious divisions
While Russians make up more than 80% of the population and Orthodox Christianity is the main religion
column2: there are many other ethnic and religious groups. Muslims are concentrated among the Volga Tatars and the Bashkirs and in the North Caucasus.

column1: Separatists and latterly armed Islamists have made the Caucasus region of Chechnya a war zone for much of the post-Soviet era. Many thousands have died since Russian troops were first sent to put down a separatist rebellion in 1994.
Moscow is convinced that any loosening of its grip on Chechnya would result in the whole of the North Caucasus falling to anarchy or Islamic militancy.

Human rights groups at home and abroad have accused Russian forces in Chechnya of widespread abuses against the public. Since the 11 September attacks on the US Moscow has tried to present its campaign as part of the global war against terrorism.
In a sign of growing confidence that peace might be returning
column2: the Russian authorities called a formal end to the military operation against the rebels in 2009. Sporadic violence continues
column3: however
column4: with a major suicide bomb blast in September 2010 reigniting the debate about the efficacy of the counter-terror campaign.

column1: 267;"Serbia inherits membership of the United Nations and other international institutions.
Serbia's parliament meets in central Belgrade
Serbia and Montenegro
column2: the two republics still left in the old Yugoslav federation
column3: had agreed in 2002 to scrap remnants of the ex-communist state and create the new
column4: looser Union of Serbia and Montenegro.

column1: The EU-brokered deal under which the union came into being in 2003 was intended to stabilise the region by settling Montenegrin demands for independence and preventing further changes to Balkan borders.

The same agreement also contained the seeds of the Union's dissolution. It stipulated that after three years the two republics could hold referendums on whether to keep or scrap it. Montenegro duly voted for independence in a referendum in May 2006.
The two republics had been united in one form or another for nearly 90 years. With separation from Montenegro
column2: Serbia is cut off from the Adriatic Sea and becomes landlocked.

column1: Yugoslav era

The end of the Union of Serbia and Montenegro marked the closing chapter in the history of the separation of the six republics of the old Socialist Republic of Yugoslavia which was proclaimed in 1945 and comprised Serbia
column2: Montenegro
column3: Slovenia
column4: Croatia
column5: Bosnia-Hercegovina and Macedonia.

column1: Under Yugoslavia's authoritarian communist leader
column2: Josip Broz Tito
column3: the lid was kept on ethnic tensions. The federation lasted for over 10 years after his death in 1980 but under Serbian nationalist leader Slobodan Milosevic it fell apart through the 1990s.

column1: The secession of Slovenia and Macedonia came relatively peacefully but there were devastating wars in Croatia and Bosnia. Serbia and Montenegro together formed the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia between 1992 and 2003.
Kosovo
In 1998 violence flared in the autonomous province of Kosovo in Serbia. The Kosovo Liberation Army
column2: supported by the majority ethnic Albanians
column3: came out in open rebellion against Serbian rule. International pressure on Milosevic grew amid the escalating violence.

column1: Nato launched air strikes in Kosovo and Serbia in March 1999. An exodus of ethnic Albanians to neighbouring countries gathered pace. The UN took over administration of the region after Serbian forces had been driven out.
Kosovo declared independence on 17 February 2008 after the failure of UN-brokered talks on the status of the province. Serbia said the declaration was illegal
column2: and other countries are divided as to whether to recognise it.

column1: Road to Europe
In late 2005
column2: the EU began talks with Belgrade on the possibility of reaching a Stabilisation and Association Agreement. These were called off some months later because of the continuing failure of the Serbian authorities to arrest several war crimes suspects.

column1: One of the most notorious of these
column2: the former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic
column3: was arrested in Belgrade in July 2008 by Serbian security forces and extradited to The Hague
column4: weeks after a pro-Western government took office. European foreign ministers praised the arrest as a significant step for Serbia in its efforts to join the EU.

column1: In December 2009 Serbia formally submitted its application to join the EU
column2: though membership negotiations cannot begin in earnest until two war crimes suspects still at large - including the former Bosnian Serb military commander Ratko Mladic - have been captured.

column1: Relations with Russia
Though the current Serbian government is pro-Western and sees eventual membership of the EU as being in the country's best interests
column2: Serbia is traditionally an ally of Russia
column3: which supported its opposition to Kosovo's independence.

column2: Serbia-Russia ties were further strengthened by the signing of a major energy deal
column3: and in October 2009 Russia granted Serbia a 1bn euro (£0.9bn) loan to help it cover its budget deficit after the economy was hit hard by the global downturn.

column1: 269;"Media
Unlike Croatia or Bosnia-Hercegovina
column2: Slovenia's independence from Yugoslavia was relatively bloodless.

column1: The move was undoubtedly aided by Western European recognition of the Slovenes' aspirations and the low proportion of other ethnic groups in the country.
Ljubljana castle overlooks the capital's old town
Slovenia has always been the most prosperous region of the former Yugoslavia and has found the transition from a socialist economy to the capitalist free market easier than most.
On 1 January 2007
column2: it became the first of the new EU member states to join the eurozone. A year later
column3: it became the first former communist state to take on the EU presidency.

column1: Politically
column2: Slovenia was the most liberal republic within Yugoslavia. Throughout the 1980s there was pressure from Slovenia for greater political freedom and pluralism in the federation.

column1: This reputation was tarnished after independence when thousands of nationals of other former Yugoslav republics were removed from population records and lost residency rights.

Parliament later passed a bill restoring their citizenship but a referendum held shortly before EU entry in 2004 overturned it by an overwhelming margin. Human rights groups expressed dismay at the move which embarrassed the leadership as it prepared to celebrate EU membership.
Slovenia's relations with Croatia have long been strained on account of a rumbling dispute over sea and land borders dating back to the break-up of Yugoslavia.
Ljubljana dropped its opposition to Zagreb's entry into NATO in March 2009
column2: but continued to block Croatia's EU membership bid for a further eight months
column3: only agreeing to lift the embargo after a deal had been signed on the Piran border dispute in November 2009.

column1: The centre-right opposition demanded a referendum on the border deal
column2: which the public narrowly approved in a June 2010 plebiscite.

column1: 270;"After Franco's death in 1975

The constitution of 1978 enshrines respect for linguistic and cultural diversity within a united Spain. The country is divided into 17 regions which all have their own directly elected authorities. The level of autonomy afforded to each region is far from uniform. For example
column2: Catalonia
column3: the Basque Country and Galicia have special status with their own language and other rights.

column1: Andalucia
column2: Navarre
column3: Valencia and the Canaries in turn have more extensive powers than some other regions. Asturias and Aragon have taken steps to consolidate language rights.

column1: The Giralda
column2: Seville: Remnant of a mosque that once stood on the site

column1: In 2006 a Catalan referendum backed by the central government gave the region greater autonomy.
The Catalans won nation status within Spain and the region's parliament gained extra powers in taxation and judicial matters. The country's regional picture is a complex and evolving one.

One of Spain's most serious domestic issues has been tension in the northern Basque region. A violent campaign by the Basque separatist group ETA has led to nearly 850 deaths over the past four decades.
Eta declared a ceasefire in March 2006 saying it wished to see the start of a democratic process for the Basque region. The move divided opinion in Spain.
Tentative moves to negotiate a lasting peace were dealt a blow when Eta carried out a deadly bomb attack at Madrid's international airport at the end of the year. In June 2007
column2: Eta called off its ceasefire.

column1: The group announced another ceasefire in September 2010
column2: but this time
column3: the government said it was not prepared to enter into negotiations unless Eta renounced violence for good.

column1: Until 2008
column2: the Spanish economy was regarded as one of the most dynamic within the EU. However
column3: the mainstays of the economy were tourism and a booming housing market and construction industry
column4: and so the global economic crisis of 2008-9 hit the country hard.

column1: Spain was tipped into a severe recession and by mid-2010 unemployment had climbed to over 20% - double the EU average.
Spain shares the Iberian peninsula with Portugal and its territory includes the Balearic Islands
column2: the Canary Islands and two North African enclaves.

column1: From Velazquez in the seventeenth century
column2: through Goya straddling the eighteenth and nineteenth
column3: to Picasso in the twentieth
column4: Spain has the proudest of traditions in art.

column1: Flamenco music and dance are widely admired around the world while Cervantes' novel Don Quixote is one of the most popular ever written.
Cinema is much loved and the films of directors such as Pedro Almodovar attract huge audiences.

column1: 272;"Media

Switzerland is unusual in having a collective head of state
column2: the seven-member Federal Council

column1: The council was set up by the constitution of 1848
column2: which is still in force today.

column1: Doris Leuthard - president for 2010
Members are elected for four-year terms by a joint session of both houses of parliament
column2: although in practice changes in membership are rare
column3: making the Federal Council one of the world's most stable governments.

column1: The election of a new female minister to the Federal Council in September 2010 gave the cabinet a majority of women for the first time in the country's history.
Each year
column2: by tradition
column3: a different member of the council fills the largely ceremonial post of Federal President on a rotating basis. The office does not confer the status of head of state

column1: For decades
column2: the Federal Council was made up by a grand coalition of all the main parties in parliament
column3: in an effort to ensure stability and promote consensus.

column1: From 1959
column2: membership was apportioned in accordance to a fixed formula which gave the liberal Free Democrats (FDP) two seats
column3: the centre-left Social Democrats (SP) two
column4: the centre-right Christian Democrats (CVP) two and the right-wing Swiss People's Party (SVP) one

column3: and was given a second post

column1: However

column1: 273;"Media
Turkey's progress towards democracy and a market economy was halting in the decades following the death of President Ataturk in 1938. The army saw itself as the guarantor of the constitution
column2: and ousted governments on a number of occasions when it thought they were challenging secular values.

column1: Please turn on JavaScript. Media requires JavaScript to play.
Efforts to reduce state control over the economy also faced many obstacles. After years of mounting difficulties which brought the country close to economic collapse
column2: a tough recovery programme was agreed with the IMF in 2002. Since then
column3: Turkey has seen strong economic growth and a dramatic fall in inflation. However
column4: huge foreign debt and unemployment remain major burdens.

column1: Concerns over the potential for conflict between a secular establishment backed by the military and a traditional society deeply rooted in Islam resurfaced with the landslide election victory of the Islamist-based Justice and Development Party (AK) in 2002.

The secularist opposition has on several occasions since then challenged the constitutional right of the AK to be the party of government. In March 2008 the Constitutional Court narrowly rejected a petition by the chief prosecutor to ban the AK and 71 of its officials
column2: including President Abdullah Gul and Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan
column3: for allegedly seeking to establish an Islamic state.

column1: In recent years there have been several allegations that members of the military - which has long seen itself as the guardian of the secular system - have been involved in plots to overthrow the government.
EU candidacy
Islam has made a comeback after decades of secularism
Turkey became an EU candidate country in 1999 and
column2: in line with EU requirements
column3: went on to introduce substantial human rights and economic reforms. The death penalty was abolished
column4: tougher measures were brought in against torture and the penal code was overhauled.

column1: Reforms were introduced in the areas of women's rights and Kurdish culture
column2: language
column3: education and broadcasting. Women's rights activists have said the reforms do not go far enough and have accused the government of lacking full commitment to equality and of acting only under EU pressure.

column1: After intense bargaining
column2: EU membership talks were launched in October 2005. Accession negotiations are expected to take about 10 years. So far
column3: the going has not been easy.

column1: Turkey has long been at odds with its close neighbour
column2: Greece
column3: over the divided island of Cyprus and territorial disputes in the Aegean.

column1: The breakthrough in its EU membership talks came just weeks after Turkey agreed to recognise Cyprus as an EU member - though it qualified this conciliatory step by declaring that it was not tantamount to full diplomatic recognition.
The Kurdish issue
Turkey is home to a sizeable Kurdish minority
column2: which by some estimates constitutes up to a fifth of the population. The Kurds have long complained that the Turkish government was trying to destroy their identity and that they suffer from economic disadvantage and human rights violations.

column1: The Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK)
column2: the best known and most radical of the Kurdish movements
column3: launched a guerrilla campaign in 1984 for an ethnic homeland in the Kurdish heartland in the southeast. Thousands died and hundreds of thousands became refugees in the ensuing conflict with the PKK
column4: which Turkey
column5: the US and the European Union deem a terrorist organisation.

column1: Kurdish guerrilla attacks briefly subsided after the 1999 capture of PKK leader Abdullah Ocalan
column2: but soon began to increase again.

column1: Partly in a bid to improve its chances of EU membership
column2: the government began to ease restrictions on the use of the Kurdish language form 2003 onwards. As part of a new ""Kurdish initiative"" launched in 2009
column3: it pledged to extend linguistic and cultural rights and to reduce the military presence in the mainly Kurdish southeast of the country.

column1: Nonetheless fighting has continued. A PKK offer in July 2010 to consider a truce if the government were to extend Kurdish civil rights was met with an official refusal to respond to ""terrorist"" statements.

column1: 274;"Media
A significant minority of the population of Ukraine are Russians or use Russian as their first language. Russian influence is particularly strong in the industrialised east
column2: as well as in Crimea
column3: an autonomous republic on the Black Sea which was part of Russia until 1954. The Russian Black Sea Fleet is based there.

column1: Crimea is also the homeland of the Crimean Tatars whom Stalin accused of collaborating with the Nazis and deported to Central Asia in 1944. More than 250
column2: 000 have returned since the late 1980s.

column1: Remembering the millions who died in Ukraine's Stalin-era Great Famine
In 1932-1933 Stalin's programme of enforced agricultural collectivisation brought famine and death to millions in Ukraine
column2: the bread basket of the USSR. Not until its twilight years did the Soviet Union acknowledge the extent of the suffering.

column1: News of another Soviet-era calamity
column2: the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power station
column3: rang alarm bells around the world immediately. About 8% of Ukraine's territory was contaminated as were large areas in neighbouring Belarus. Millions have suffered as a result.

column1: Independence
The first president after independence
column2: former Communist Party official Leonid Kravchuk
column3: presided over a period of economic decline and runaway inflation. His successor
column4: Leonid Kuchma
column5: oversaw steady economic recovery
column6: but was accused of conceding too much to Russian economic interests.

column1: Opposition to Mr Kuchma grew
column2: further fed by discontent at controls on media freedom
column3: manipulation of the political system and cronyism.

column1: The authorities' attempt to rig the 2004 presidential elections led to the ""Orange Revolution""
column2: with reference to the colour of the main opposition movement.

column1: Orange Revolution
Mass protests
column2: a revolt by state media against government controls and the fracturing of the governing coalition brought in European-Union mediation and a re-run of the election.

column1: A fragile alliance of anti-Kuchma forces
column2: from pro-Western democrats
column3: socialists
column4: business interests and nationalists united behind opposition leader and former prime minister Viktor Yushchenko
column5: who won the presidency.

column1: Mr Yushchenko secured the transparency of the democratic process
column2: the rule of law and media freedom
column3: but his efforts to move towards Nato and EU membership made slow progress in the face of Western reluctance to antagonise a resurgent Russia and a divided public opinion in Ukraine itself.

column1: Rivalry with his prime minister
column2: Yuliya Tymoshenko
column3: soured into open antagonism
column4: and neither proved able to cope with the worldwide economic downturn after 2008.

column1: Although trade with EU countries now exceeds that with Russia
column2: Moscow is the largest individual trading partner. Ukraine depends on Russia for its gas supplies and forms an important part of the pipeline transit route for Russian gas exports to Europe.

column1: Gas disputes

A dispute over price rises prompted Russia briefly to cut supplies for use by Ukraine in January 2006 and raised concerns across Europe too. The gas was switched back on only after Ukraine agreed to pay almost twice the former price
column2: which rose sharply again for 2007. In January 2009
column3: Russia again cut gas supplies in a row over unpaid fees.

column1: The Ukrainian economy's dependence on steel exports made it particularly vulnerable to the effects of the global financial crisis of 2008
column2: and in October of that year the country was offered a $16.5bn (£10.4bn) loan by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

column1: 275;"Britain was the world's first industrialised country. Its economy remains one of the largest
column2: but it has for many years been based on service industries rather than on manufacturing.

Despite being a major member of the EU
column2: the country is not part of the euro zone
column3: and the question of whether it will join any time soon appears to have receded for the moment. The government has said a series of economic criteria must be met before the issue can be put to a referendum.

column1: In recent years the UK has taken steps to devolve powers to Scotland and Wales. The Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh and the National Assembly for Wales in Cardiff opened in 1999

column1: Palace of Westminster

column1: Virtual tour
In Northern Ireland
column2: after decades of violent conflict
column3: the Good Friday agreement of 1998 led to a new assembly with devolved powers
column4: bringing hopes of lasting peace. The assembly was suspended in 2002 amid a row over alleged IRA activities. Its suspension was to last for three and a half years.

column1: In a bid to restart the political process and after consultations with Dublin
column2: the UK passed legislation paving the way for the recall of the Northern Ireland Assembly in May 2006.

column1: But assembly leaders missed a November deadline to form a power-sharing executive. Assembly elections in the following March led to the eventual swearing-in of the leaders of the power-sharing government on 8 May 2007
column2: ending five years of direct rule from London.

column1: Diversity
The UK is ethnically diverse
column2: partly as a legacy of empire. Lately
column3: the country has been struggling with issues revolving around multiculturalism
column4: immigration and national identity.

column1: This is against a background of concerns about terrorism and political and religious radicalism
column2: heightened after the suicide bomb attacks on London's transport network in 2005.

column1: Some politicians and commentators say a stronger sense of shared British values is needed to foster integration within a mixed society. And while some advocate tough policies on limiting immigration
column2: others attempt to put the case for it as a positive force.

column1: One of the more recent trends in migration has been the arrival of workers from the new EU member states in Eastern Europe.
Culture
The UK has been at the forefront of youth culture since the heyday of the Beatles and Rolling Stones in the 1960s.
It has a rich literary heritage encompassing the works of English writers such as William Shakespeare and Charles Dickens
column2: Scot Robert Burns
column3: Welshman Dylan Thomas and Northern Irishman Seamus Heaney.

column1: Traditional music has deep roots across the UK
column2: which has also produced classical composers from Henry Purcell in the Baroque period to Benjamin Britten in the 20th century.

column1: 276;"Pope tells of youth under Nazis
Already one of the Vatican's most powerful men
column2: he presided over the funeral of his predecessor Pope John Paul II and was said to be among the late pontiff's closest friends.

column1: Pope Benedict was born in Bavaria in 1927 and is the oldest man to become pope in more than 100 years. He is the first German pope since the eleventh century.
Drafted into the German armed forces during World War II
column2: he deserted as it drew to a close and was a prisoner of war in 1945. He has said that the brutality of the Nazis later helped lead him to the priesthood
column3: and in one of his first papal addresses he condemned the Holocaust.

column1: He became cardinal-archbishop of Munich in 1977
column2: and in 1981 the new Pope John Paul II appointed him head of the Congregation of the Doctrine of the Faith.

column1: In this office
column2: the successor to the historical Inquisition
column3: Cardinal Ratzinger set out his conservative intellectual stance
column4: including rigorously uncompromising views on birth control
column5: sexuality and euthanasia.

column1: Pope Benedict has not adapted to the public limelight as easily as his predecessor
column2: and a number of controversies have resulted from his uncertain handling of the media.

column1: His decision to readmit Richard Williamson
column2: an ultraconservative bishop and Holocaust denier
column3: to the Church angered Jews and many loyal Catholics
column4: and his quotation of comments by a Byzantine emperor highly critical of the Muslim Prophet Muhammad provoked protests by Muslim clerics and public figures.

column1: Both these controversies were eclipsed by the coming to light of numerous sex abuse scandals involving Catholic clergy throughout the world. The Vatican dismissed claims that the Holy See had attempted to hush up accusations of clerical paedophilia rather than take action to stop the abuse as an ""ignoble"" attack on the Pope.

The port in the capital
column2: Batumi
column3: is used for the shipment of oil from Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan. Its oil refinery handles Caspian oil from Azerbaijan which arrives by pipeline to Supsa port and is transported from there to Batumi by rail.

column1: Batumi is also an important gateway for the shipment of goods heading into Georgia
column2: Azerbaijan and landlocked Armenia. The Ajarian capital is a centre for shipbuilding and manufacturing. Ajaria has good land for growing tea
column3: citrus fruits and tobacco.

column1: History

The people of Ajaria are ethnically Georgian and the region also has a substantial Russian-speaking population. Under Ottoman rule from the 17th until the 19th century Islam predominated. The word Ajarian came to mean a Georgian Muslim.
Tensions erupt on the internal border between Georgia and Ajaria
In 1878 Ajaria was annexed by Russia and
column2: following the Bolshevik revolution
column3: incorporated into Georgia as an autonomous republic within the USSR. Under Stalin
column4: Islam
column5: like Christianity
column6: was ruthlessly repressed. Nowadays about half the population professes the Islamic faith.

column1: Unlike the breakaway regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia
column2: Ajaria has been spared major violence and ethnic unrest since Georgia became independent after the collapse of the Soviet Union.

column1: The region was led between 1991 and May 2004 by Aslan Abashidze
column2: who maintained close ties with Moscow. Election results gave him at least 90% of the vote every time and he ruled in what many observers described as an autocratic style.

column1: Aslan Abashidze ousted
Former Ajarian leader Aslan Abashidze stepped down and fled
After Eduard Shevardnadze was overthrown as Georgian president and the results of the November 2003 Georgian parliamentary elections were annulled
column2: a state of emergency was declared in Ajaria. Its leadership refused to recognise the full authority of Mikhail Saakashvili as Georgian president.

column1: In May 2004
column2: Mr Abashidze claimed that Georgian forces were preparing to invade. His forces blew up bridges connecting the region with the rest of Georgia. Mr Saakashvili ordered the Ajarian leader to comply with the Georgian constitution and start disarming or face removal.

column1: Large numbers of demonstrators took to the streets of Batumi. In an echo of events in Tbilisi the previous autumn
column2: Mr Abashidze resigned.

column1: Russia then agreed to close its military base at Batumi in 2007. The base was a source of great tension between Moscow and Tbilisi.

But improving relations were jeopardised in November 2007 by Spanish King Juan Carlos' II first visit to the territories in more than 30 years

column1: 280;"Media
The Channel Islands were owned by the Duchy of Normandy
column2: and passed to the English Crown when William the Conqueror became King of England in 1066. While England lost mainland Normandy in 1204
column3: the islands remained possessions of the Crown and were divided into the two bailiwicks later that century.

column1: Corbiere lighthouse Jersey
Since then the bailiwicks have maintained separate institutions
column2: laws and media
column3: with the exception of a common independent TV station
column4: Channel TV.

column1: During the Second World War the islands were occupied by Germany
column2: causing considerable suffering to the locals. Some were deported as slave labourers
column3: Jews were sent to concentration camps
column4: reprisals for partisan activities were harsh
column5: and many were reduced to near starvation by the end of the war. Accusations of collaboration and cover-up poisoned relations between many islanders for decades.

column1: The total population is about 160
column3: of whom the overwhelming majority is made up of native islanders of Norman French and British extraction. There are also groups of European Union citizens
column4: with a prominent community from Portugal.

column1: As Crown Dependencies the islands are not part of the United Kingdom or European Union
column2: nor are they colonies or overseas territories of the United Kingdom like Gibraltar. They are possessions of the British Crown with independent administrations. Their assemblies pass their own legislation with the assent of the Crown granted in the Privy Council.

column1: The Crown is responsible for defence
column2: diplomatic representation and citizenship
column3: although the islands maintain their own controls over housing and employment that apply to British as well as other citizens.

column1: The islands have the right to establish direct relations with foreign governments. Although not parts of the European Union
column2: they are in a customs union with it.

column1: The bailiwicks are governed by elected parliaments called States
column2: while the smaller islands of Alderney and Sark also have their own assemblies - the States and Chief Pleas respectively.

column1: The bailiffs are the chief civil officers
column2: and preside over the States and court of law. They are appointed by the Crown
column3: and usually serve until retirement or death. Their powers have been steadily transferred to the States over the last 100 years
column4: culminating in the adoption of a ministerial system and appointment of chief ministers in 2005.

column1: The economy of the islands is dominated by financial services
column2: tourism
column3: electronic commerce and agriculture. The relatively light tax burden has encouraged a booming offshore finance sector. Pressure from the European Union and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development is obliging the islands to change their taxation systems for the sake of compliance
column4: as with other offshore centres.

column1: 281;"Media
Chechnya has been a thorn in Russia's mountainous southern border for nearly two centuries. The Russians finally overcame the resistance of Imam Shamil in 1859
column2: claiming the Caucasus region for the empire after a long and bloody campaign that caught the imagination of many 19th Century Russian writers from Lermontov to Tolstoy.

column1: Thousands of Russian soldiers remain in Chechnya
The Chechens had to wait for more than 60 years before they briefly escaped Russian dominion again in the chaos following the October revolution.
However
column2: that period of independence was short-lived and by 1922 the republic had been forced back into the Russian fold.

column1: World War II and the Nazi invasion presented another glimpse of freedom from Moscow's rule. When the war ended
column2: Stalin sought vengeance. He accused the Chechens of collaborating. Their punishment was mass deportation to Siberia and Central Asia. They were allowed to return only in 1957 when Khrushchev was in power in the Kremlin.

column1: Post-Soviet years
When the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991
column2: Dzhokhar Dudayev
column3: a former senior officer in the Soviet air force
column4: declared independence from Russia. Yeltsin responded by sending a few hundred Interior Ministry servicemen to the republic. They were met at the airport by Chechen fighters and sent back home on buses
column5: the first in a series of humiliations for Moscow.

column1: Moscow says the situation in Chechnya has now 'normalised'

This was followed by three years during which armed groups gained an increasing hold on Chechnya and Dudayev became more outspoken in his defiance of Moscow where the leadership argued over how to handle the situation.

In 1994 Russia sent its forces in a very poorly planned bid to bring the rebellious region back to heel. Early promises of a quick victory were soon silent as the Chechens put up fierce resistance to the Russian assault and the death toll mounted.
Amid growing public outcry over rising losses in the Russian army
column2: Moscow withdrew its forces under a 1996 peace agreement. The deal gave Chechnya substantial autonomy but not full independence. The Chechen chief of staff
column3: Aslan Maskhadov
column4: was elected president.

column1: However
column2: Russia failed to invest in reconstruction. Maskhadov could not control brutal warlords who grew rich by organised crime and kidnapping. Many victims were murdered by their captors.

column1: KEY DATES
1991 USSR collapses
column2: Dzhokhar Dudayev elected president
column3: declares independence

column1: 1994 Russia sends forces to crush independence movement
1996 Khasavyurt accords bring ceasefire but not independence
1997 Aslan Maskhadov elected president
1999 Russia blames Chechnya for wave of bombings
column2: sends troops back

2003 New constitution gives Chechnya more autonomy but enshrines its position within Russian Federation. Akhmad Kadyrov elected president
2004 President Kadyrov killed by bomb. Kremlin-backed Alu Alkhanov succeeds him.
2005 March - Separatist leader Aslan Maskhadov killed by Russian forces
column2: succeeded by Abdul-Khalim Saydullayev

column1: 2006 March - Ramzan Kadyrov
column2: son of assassinated president Akhmad Kadyrov
column3: becomes PM

2006 July - Warlord Shamil Basayev

column1: 2007 March - Ramzan Kadyrov becomes president

In August 1999
column2: Chechen fighters crossed into the neighbouring Russian Republic of Dagestan to support a declaration by an Islamic body based there of an independent Islamic state in parts of Dagestan and Chechnya. This body also called on all Muslims to take up arms against Russia in a holy war. By now Vladimir Putin was Russian prime minister and Moscow was fast and firm in its reaction. Within a couple of weeks the rebellion was over.

column1: The late summer of the same year saw several explosions in Russia in which hundreds died. The Russian authorities did not hesitate to blame the Chechens.
Mr Putin sent the army back to subdue the republic by force in a second brutal campaign which
column2: despite Russian claims of victory
column3: has yet to reach a conclusion.

column1: Western criticism of Russian tactics and human rights violations in Chechnya was all but silenced following the 11 September attacks on the US. Russia has since portrayed Chechen rebel forces as part of the global terror network and uses this to vindicate its methods.
A controversial referendum in March 2003 approved a new constitution
column2: giving Chechnya more autonomy but stipulating that it remained firmly part of Russia. Moscow ruled out participation by the armed opposition and there were widespread concerns that the republic was far too unstable to ensure a valid outcome.

column1: Parliamentary elections in November 2005 saw the pro-Kremlin United Russia party win over half the seats. Separatist rebels dismissed the election as a charade but President Putin said that the legal process of restoring constitutional order had been completed.
Since then there has been increased investment in reconstruction projects and the shattered city of Groznyy is being rebuilt. While Russia is keen to highlight these signs of rebirth
column2: sporadic violence continues.

column1: In April 2009
column2: Moscow announced that the situation in Chechnya had improved to such extent that it felt able to end its military operation against the rebels.

column1: 282;"Corsica is largely mountainous; high cliffs and rocky inlets characterise much of its coast. The interior boasts deep forests
column2: glacial lakes
column3: gorges
column4: maquis-covered slopes and snow-capped granite peaks. Wilderness areas attract walkers and nature-lovers.

column1: Calvi - a tourism hotspot on the north-west coast
Napoleon Bonaparte
column2: emperor of the French
column3: was born in Ajaccio
column4: the capital of Corsica's southern departement. The Maison Bonaparte in the town is now a museum. The island's architectural features include Genoese fortresses
column5: watchtowers and baroque churches.

column1: Local culture finds expression in folk music and handicrafts. The Tuscan-influenced Corsican language is taught in the island's schools.
The island is studded with standing stones and other monuments
column2: evidence of human occupation in neolithic times. The Greeks
column3: Carthaginians and Romans all left their mark. Vandals
column4: Goths and Moors were among the later invaders.

column1: The Genoese from Italy ruled Corsica from the 1400s-1700s
column2: and occasionally came to blows with the local aristocracy
column3: nationalists and the French. A nationalist rebellion led to the foundation of a Corsican republic in 1755. But independence was short-lived; the Genoese ceded the island to France
column4: whose troops invaded in 1769.

column1: Nationalist groups seek independence from France
Corsica is one of France's least-developed regions and receives large subsidies from Paris. Tourism is an important part of the island's economy
column2: but large stretches of the seaboard remain undeveloped. Much of the population is concentrated in the main towns of Bastia and Ajaccio.

column1: Separatist groups seeking greater autonomy for the island carried out bombing campaigns from the mid-1970s
column2: often targeting police stations and administrative buildings. In 1998 France's top official on the island was assassinated.

column1: A referendum organised by the French government to consolidate the two administrative divisions of Corsica into a single region with enhanced powers narrowly failed to win approval in 2003.

In March 2005 the main separatist faction - the FLNC-Union of Combatants - broke off an open-ended ceasefire that it had declared in late 2003. There was a spate of minor bomb attacks around the time of the presidential elections in April and May 2007.
