Crimea was annexed by the Russian Empire during the reign of Catherine The Great in 1783 and remained part of Russia until 1954 when it was transferred to Ukraine under the then Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev.
Ethnic Russians still make up the bulk of the population
column2: Ukrainians under a quarter and the Muslim Crimean Tatars about 12%.

column1: Sevastopol: A key base for the Russian Black Sea Fleet
For centuries under Greek and Roman influence
column2: Crimea in 1443 became the centre of a Tatar Khanate
column3: which later became an Ottoman vassal state.

column1: Rival imperial ambitions in the mid 19th century led to the Crimean War when Britain and France
column2: suspicious of Russian ambitions in the Balkans as the Ottoman Empire declined
column3: sent troops.

column1: Tatar deportation
Given autonomous republic status within Russia after the Bolshevik revolution
column2: Crimea was occupied by the Nazis in the early 1940s.

column1: The Tatars were accused of collaboration by Stalin and deported en masse to Central Asia and Siberia in 1944. Many did not survive.
Only as the Soviet Union collapsed were they allowed to return. By the time over a quarter of a million did so in the early 1990s
column2: it was to an independent Ukraine where they faced very high unemployment and extremely poor housing conditions.

column1: There have been persistent tensions and protests over land rights
column2: and allocation of land to Crimean Tatars remains a highly contentious issue.

column1: After Ukrainian independence
column2: political figures from the local Russian community sought to assert sovereignty and strengthen ties with Russia through a series of moves declared unconstitutional by Kiev.

column1: Yalta: The port city is a mecca for tourists
The 1996 Ukrainian constitution stipulated that Crimea would have autonomous republic status but reasserted that Crimean legislation must be in keeping with that of Ukraine.
Crimea has its own parliament and government with powers over agriculture
column2: public infrastructure and tourism.

column1: The Crimean Tatars have their own unofficial parliament
column2: the Mejlis
column3: which states its purpose as being to promote the rights and interests of the Crimean Tatars.

column1: Ukraine-Russia tension
The port of Sevastopol is a major naval base and has been home to the Black Sea Fleet since Soviet times. Following the collapse of the USSR
column2: the fleet was divided up between Russia and Ukraine.

column1: The continuing presence of the Russian fleet in Sevastopol has been a focus of tension between Russia and Ukraine. In 2008
column2: Ukraine - then under the pro-Western President Viktor Yuschenko - demanded that Moscow not use the Black Sea Fleet during the its conflict with Georgia.

column1: Both countries had agreed to allow the Russian fleet to stay until 2017
column2: but after the election of the pro-Russian Viktor Yanukovych as president in 2010
column3: Ukraine agreed to extend the lease by 25 years beyond 2017
column4: in return for cheaper Russian gas.

column1: There was also friction over plans - later scrapped by Mr Yanukovych - by Mr Yushchenko to strengthen ties with Nato. In 2006
column2: ethnic Russians took to the streets to disrupt preparations for Nato-led naval exercises off Crimea.

column1: There is a rumbling border dispute between Moscow and Kiev in the Kerch Strait. Tensions rose sharply in late 2003 after Russia started building a causeway between the Russian coast and the island of Tuzla
column2: just off Crimea.

column1: 284;"Media
Several dozen Muslim peoples have settled among the high valleys over the centuries.
The Avars form the largest ethnic group and account for about a fifth of the population. A further substantial proportion is made up of Dargins
column2: Kumyks and Lezgins. About 10 per cent are ethnic Russians. There are also Laks
column3: Tabasarans and Nogai
column4: to name but a few of the other significant groups.

column1: The republic's constitution declares the protection of the interests of all of Dagestan's peoples to be a fundamental principle. It is a delicate balance to maintain
column2: in what is Russia's most ethnically diverse province.

column1: The republic has oil and gas reserves and also the fisheries potential offered by a share in the resources of the Caspian sea. However
column2: it is prey to organized crime and regional instability. The crime barons may prosper but the people are amongst the poorest in Russia. They live in the shadow of lawlessness and the threat of violence.

column1: History
Dagestan was the birth place of Imam Shamil
column2: the legendary fighter who in the 19th century spearheaded fierce resistance by tribesmen of Chechnya and Dagestan to the spread of the Russian empire. The name of Imam Shamil is still revered by many in both republics.

column1: Russia tries to police Caucasus peaks
When the Bolsheviks sought to enforce control in the Caucasus in the early 1920s
column2: Dagestan became an autonomous Soviet republic within the Russian Federation. During the Stalinist period its peoples escaped the mass deportation inflicted on their Chechen neighbours and many others.

column1: Since the fall of the Soviet Union
column2: the republic's authorities have been regarded as loyal by the Kremlin and as corrupt and incompetent by many elsewhere. Oil and caviar mafias are reported to flourish. Kidnappings and violence are commonplace. Firearms are ubiquitous and assassinations are a regular event.

column1: Moscow consistently says it sees the hand of Chechen-based separatism as the cause. Others see the roots in lust for profit against a background of lawlessness in a gun culture.
Budennovsk and beyond
Chechen warlords
column2: ever eager to make trouble for Moscow
column3: have openly led armed operations in Dagestan on several occasions.

column1: These attracted international attention for the first time in 1995 and 1996 when Shamil Basayev and Salman Raduyev crossed the border and seized hundreds of hostages in hospitals in the Dagestani towns of Budennovsk and Kizlyar in the name of the separatist cause. Scores died and the Kremlin now finds it hard to come to terms with the fact that Basayev and Raduyev got away.
Gun law is powerful in Dagestan
The Muslims of Dagestan
column2: for whom Sufism combined with local tradition is the main faith
column3: have generally been anxious to avoid the conflict that has afflicted Chechnya.

column1: However
column2: in the latter part of the 1990s there were reports that more radical and militant elements
column3: said to be linked with Wahhabism
column4: were acquiring influence. There was tension when two mountain villages near the Chechen border sought to introduce Shari'ah law in 1998.

column1: Violence flared in August 1999 when an Islamic body was reported to have declared an independent state in parts of Dagestan and Chechnya and called on Muslims to take up arms against Russia in a holy war. It also called for the arrest of Magomedali Magomedov
column2: the republic's leader at the time
column3: accusing him of working with the Russians.

column1: Russian forces prepare to fight in 1999

Chechen fighters crossed into Dagestan in support. There were fierce clashes with Russian forces but within a couple of weeks the fighting was over. The militants were silenced. This incident contributed heavily to the return of Russian troops to Chechnya.
The republic has seen numerous bombings targeted at the Russian military which has forces stationed at Kaspiysk
column2: Buynaksk and Budennovsk. Scores were killed in 1996 and 1999 in Kaspiysk and Buynaksk when bombs went off near blocks of flats housing Russian officers. Dozens more died in 2002 when bombers targeted a Russian military parade in Kaspiysk.

column1: Russian forces have since been the target of numerous smaller scale attacks. At least 10 died in a bomb blast in the capital
column2: Makhachkala in July 2005. Violence continues: a leading journalist was killed in 2008
column3: and in 2009 a senior police investigator and the republic's interior minister were shot dead.

column1: Russia accused a Dagestan militant
column2: Magomedali Vagabov
column3: of being behind the attack on the Moscow metro in March 2010 in which 39 people were killed. The attack was carried out by two female suicide bombers from Dagestan. In August 2010
column4: Russian forces killed Vagabov in a counter-terrorism operation in Dagestan.

column1: The Kremlin is not alone in blaming Islamic militants for orchestrating the violence. Many say organized crime is the crucial factor. Clan and political rivalries are seen as another ingredient.
As concerns grow over the volatility of the North Caucasus
column2: lawless Dagestan offers little short-term hope of stability.

column1: 285;"These potential resources have given extra weight to the argument for full independence from Denmark.
The Faroes' landscape is barren and often spectacular
But a planned referendum on the issue was shelved in 2001 after Denmark said it would halt aid within four years if voters favoured the independence proposals.
A local parliament looks after the islands' affairs
column2: although Copenhagen is responsible for defence and foreign relations.

column1: The Faroes were first settled by Irish monks in the 6th century AD. The first Norse settlers were farmers.

The islands became part of the Kingdom of Norway in the 11th century and came under Danish control in the 14th century when Norway joined the Kingdom of Denmark. Under the 1948 Home Rule Act the islands became self-governing.

The islanders' traditional hunt for pilot whales has attracted international attention. Supporters of the hunt say whale meat is an important source of food over the winter. Animal rights activists have called for the cull to be banned.
Fishing is the main economic activity on the islands
column2: and Danish subsidies remain an important source of income. Copenhagen has said it will review the subsidy agreement should the Faroes profit from offshore energy reserves.

column1: 286;"Named in Arabic ""Jabal Tariq""
column2: after the Muslim commander Tariq Ibn-Ziyad
column3: who turned ""the Rock"" into a fortress in 711
column4: Gibraltar has been an important naval base for more than 1
column5: 000 years.

column1: Gibraltar: Seafaring traditions span the centuries
This long maritime history has resulted in a diverse population. Most Gibraltarians are bilingual in English and Spanish
column2: and are of mixed Genoese
column3: British
column4: Spanish
column5: Maltese and Portuguese descent. Recent arrivals have included migrant workers from Morocco.

column1: Gibraltarians are British citizens. They elect their own representatives to the territory's House of Assembly; the British monarch appoints a governor. Gibraltar is self-governing in all areas except defence and foreign policy. It is home to a British military garrison and naval base.
The EU has pressured Spain and Britain to resolve the issue of Gibraltar's status. Both sides
column2: under the Brussels Process launched in 1984
column3: have attempted to reach an agreement.

column1: But Spain's insistence on eventually acquiring full sovereignty
column2: and Britain's determination to retain full control of Gibraltar's military base
column3: have been among the stumbling blocks.

column1: Gibraltar's 1969 constitution states that there can be no transfer of sovereignty to Spain against the wishes of locals. In a 2002 referendum Gibraltarians resoundingly rejected the idea of joint sovereignty. Spain and Britain were said to have reached ""broad agreement"" on the concept.
Passenger flights between Spain and Gibraltar were blocked for nearly 30 years
Free travel between Spain and Gibraltar was fully restored in 1985
column2: but travellers continued to suffer delays at the border. In late 2006
column3: passenger flights between Spain and Gibraltar resumed for the first time in nearly 30 years.

column1: The air link was restored after Gibraltar
column2: Spain and Britain signed agreements aimed at improving living conditions on the Rock. The three-way talks did not cover the issue of sovereignty.

column1: With no large-scale agricultural or industrial activity
column2: much of Gibraltar's income comes from customs duties
column3: offshore finance
column4: internet gaming
column5: tourism and the provisioning of ships.

column1: 287;"The climate in Greenland is extremely harsh. More than 80% of the island is covered by an ice cap which is 4km thick in places.
Uummannaq locals enjoy perpetual daylight for two months each year
Many of the Eskimo (Inuit) people survive by hunting and fishing and are struggling as fish stocks become depleted. The island's population is only 57
column2: 000. Inhabitants face severe social problems
column3: notably unemployment
column4: alcoholism and HIV/Aids.

column1: Recent environmental studies have raised fears that global warming is causing Greenland's ice cover to melt increasingly fast and that this could have serious implications for future sea levels and ocean currents unless the process is rapidly halted and then reversed.

US plans for a national missile defence system have highlighted the strategic importance of Greenland. The Americans have expressed interest in using their Cold War radar base at Thule in the north of the island as part of this defence system.
Dozens of Inuit families were forced off their lands in 1953 to allow expansion at the base. Many Greenlanders would like to see it closed down. Others see economic reasons for keeping it.
A substantial proportion of Greenland's population favours independence. However
column2: the former colonial power
column3: Denmark
column4: has the final say on the matter.

column1: In 2008 Greenlanders voted in a referendum for more autonomy. The deal gave them greater control over their energy resources
column2: treated Greenlanders as a separate people under international law
column3: and granted the native Inuit language Kalaallisut (Western Greenlandic) official status in place of Danish. The Danish subsidy is to continue.

column1: Early elections were held just before that deal came into force in June 2009 in order to decide how to implement it. The pro-independence Inuit Ataqatigiit party beat the Social Democratic Siumut party
column2: which had governed for 30 years.

column1: 288;"Media
The Ingush and Chechen peoples have close historical
column2: cultural and linguistic ties
column3: although the Ingush have not shared in the fierceness of the resistance to Moscow put up by the Chechens over the past 200 years.

column1: Part of the Russian empire since the early 19th century
column2: Ingushetia was formally joined to Chechnya under Soviet rule in 1936 when it formed around one-fifth of the Chechen-Ingush Autonomous Republic within Russia.

column1: Like the Chechens
column2: the Ingush
column3: despite their history of relative loyalty to Moscow
column4: were deported to Central Asia towards the end of World War II by Stalin who accused them of collaborating with the Nazis. They were allowed to return only in 1957 when Khrushchev was Soviet leader.

column1: There was tension after Dzhokhar Dudayev came to power as Chechen leader in 1991. When he declared Chechen sovereignty the Ingush resisted. There was some fighting along the border between the two regions and Russian troops were sent in to establish order. The Ingush subsequently voted in a referendum to form the Republic of Ingushetia within Russia. Although firmly tied to Moscow
column2: the republic has its own anthem and state symbols.

column1: The Ingush and North Ossetians have a history of rivalry. Ingushetia lays claim to the neighbouring Prigorodny district which was included in the Russian Republic of North Ossetia when Stalin deported the Ingush in 1944. For many years after their return
column2: the district had a substantial Ingush population.

column1: Post-Soviet period

In late 1992 violence erupted in Prigorodny district. The two sides have fundamental differences as to the reasons. The North Ossetians assert that it was sparked by Ingush radicals seeking to include Prigorodny in the newly formed Republic of Ingushetia. The Ingush assert that the North Ossetians attacked first and that they acted in self defence.

The fighting left many dead. Moscow sent troops to establish order. The Ingush population was expelled from the district and Ingushetia faced its first post-independence refugee crisis. Tensions persist and there are differences as to how many refugees have returned home.
Post-Soviet Ingushetia has had to deal with several refugee crises

Another refugee crisis presented itself when thousands of Chechens fled across the border into Ingushetia when Russian troops returned to Chechnya in 1999. The last refugee camp was reported to have been closed five years later. Russia rejected concerns voiced by human rights groups that many of the former residents had been forcibly repatriated in Moscow's zeal to expunge indications of continuing conflict in the area.
Ingushetia lives in the shadow of the instability of its Chechen neighbour and poverty is widespread. From time to time
column2: the violence has spilled over the border and Russian forces are regularly targeted by attackers.

column1: There was a major escalation in June 2004 when several dozen people
column2: including the Ingush acting interior minister
column3: were killed in attacks reported to have involved hundreds of gunmen armed with grenades and rockets. The incident
column4: and subsequent clashes
column5: prompted the Kremlin to order a change of leadership in a bid to reduce the level of violence.

column1: However
column2: there was a renewed spate of attacks by militants in 2009
column3: including a suicide bombing at a police station that killed at least 25 people - the deadliest attack in the republic since 2005 - and an attempt on the life of President Yunus-Bek Yevkurov. Moscow reacted by announcing another overhaul of security in the republic.

column1: 289;"Media
The Isle of Man was permanently settled by Celts and fell under Viking control in 1079. The Viking legacy is seen in many place names and the title of the Tynwald parliament
column2: although the Celtic Manx language predominated until the 19th century.

column1: Man passed to the Scottish crown in 1266
column2: and then to the feudal lordship of the Stanley family under the English crown. The British crown acquired the lordship in 1764
column3: but never incorporated the island into the United Kingdom.

column1: Tourism plays a significant role in the economy
The Tynwald parliament was granted autonomy in 1866
column2: and steadily advanced to democracy in step with the United Kingdom. Established no later than 979
column3: it is one of various assemblies that claim to be the oldest parliament in the world. The Tynwald elects the Council of Ministers
column4: presided over since 1986 by a chief minister. Most members of the Tynwald are independents.

column1: Native-born people make up 47.6 per cent of the population
column2: with the rest almost entirely accounted for by immigrants from the United Kingdom. People born in England make up 37.2 per cent alone.

column1: As a Crown Dependency
column2: the Isle of Man is not part of the United Kingdom or European Union. The Tynwald passes its own legislation with the assent of the Crown granted in the Privy Council. The Crown is responsible for defence and diplomatic representation
column3: and acts on the advice of the UK Ministry of Justice. The Isle of Man has its own controls on immigration and housing.

column1: The Isle of Man has relatively low taxes and this has encouraged a major offshore financial sector that accounts for most of GDP. Over recent years the Manx government has made a concerted effort to cast off the island's reputation as a tax haven
column2: signing tax information exchange deals with over a dozen countries.

column1: Its strategy was rewarded in April 2009 when it was included in an OECD ""white list"" of jurisdictions meeting international standards on taxation.

Inclusion in the list came just a few months after British Chancellor Alistair Darling dubbed the island a ""tax haven sitting in the Irish Sea"". The British government has subsequently praised the island's efforts at improving financial transparency.
Light industry and tourism also play a significant role in the economy
column2: while agriculture and fisheries are steadily losing their significance.

column1: The Manx government has boosted the island as a location for film and TV productions
column2: and more than 80 films have been made there since 1995.

column1: 290;"Media
Since the 2004 school siege at Beslan in neighbouring North Ossetia
column2: Russia has repeatedly targeted what it says are Islamic extremists operating in Kabardino-Balkaria.

column1: Mosques in the capital
column2: Nalchik
column3: have been closed and there have been armed operations against suspected Islamic militants
column4: some of whom have been killed
column5: along with members of the security forces.

column1: In October 2005 militants staged a large-scale
column2: armed assault on government buildings in Nalchik. Russia responded swiftly
column3: deploying hundreds of troops and special forces with orders to shoot to kill. Many dozens were reported dead
column4: including militants
column5: civilians and Russian forces.

column1: Security forces have targeted suspected Islamic militants
Yarmuk
column2: a local militant Islamic group with Chechen links
column3: said that its fighters had been involved on the ground as part of a Caucasus Front.

column1: The organisation of a Caucasus Front against Russia was decreed in May 2005 by the late Chechen rebel leader Abdul-Khalim Saydullayev. The decree was perceived as a bid further to widen Chechnya's conflict with Russia.
Kabardino-Balkaria is home to the two highest peaks in the North Caucasus
column2: Mount Elbrus and Dykh Tau. It shares a border with Georgia. To the east and west lie the Russian republics of North Ossetia and Karachayevo-Cherkessia. To the north is Stavropol region. It lies 50km west of war-torn Chechnya.

column1: The area was contested by the Russian and Ottoman empires between the 17th and 19th centuries when it came under Russian control. After the Bolshevik revolution
column2: the Kabardino Autonomous Region was formed in 1921
column3: and the Balkar district added a year later. The region gained autonomous republic status in 1936.

column1: The population is made up of mainly-Muslim Kabardins
column2: as well as minorities of Turkic-speaking Balkars - around 10% of the people - and Russians. There is friction between the Kabardins and the Balkars
column3: and in 1992 the Balkars voted for secession.

column1: Accused by Stalin of collaboration with the Nazis
column2: the Balkars were deported to Central Asia during World War II and their name was dropped from the republic's title. It was restored in 1957 when they were allowed to return. The region became a federal republic of Russia in 1991 following the collapse of the USSR.

column1: The economy relies heavily on subsidies from Moscow.

Regions and territories: Kaliningrad
The Russian exclave of Kaliningrad on the Baltic Sea is sandwiched between Poland to the south and Lithuania to the north and east.
Annexed from Germany in 1945
column2: the territory was a closed military zone throughout the Soviet period.
Russia threatened to deploy short-range missiles there if the United States went ahead with its plan to build controversial missile defence bases in Poland and the Czech Republic.

column1: OVERVIEW
Koenigsberg
column2: as the city of Kaliningrad was once known
column3: was founded by Teutonic knights in the 13th century. It became one of the cities of the Hanseatic League and was once the capital of Prussia. The philosopher Immanuel Kant spent all his life in the city and died there in 1804.

column1: The region was part of Germany until annexation by the USSR following World War II when it saw bitter fighting and suffered rampant destruction. The German population was expelled or fled after the war ended.
Kaliningrad has strategic importance for Moscow
During the Soviet period
column2: Kaliningrad Region
column3: administratively part of the Russian Federation
column4: was separated from the rest of Russia
column5: more than 300km to the east
column6: by the then Soviet republics of Lithuania
column7: Latvia and Belarus.

column1: Since Lithuania joined the EU it has been impossible to travel between the exclave and the rest of Russia over land without crossing the territory of at least one EU state. There has been friction
column2: particularly with Lithuania
column3: over transit regulations. President Putin described as a matter of Russian national security the inauguration of a new sea route linking the region with Ust-Luga
column4: near St Petersburg

column1: Kaliningrad was one of the most militarised and closed parts of the Soviet Union. Up to half a million servicemen were stationed there. The military were the region's chief economic mainstay in the Soviet years. When the USSR ceased to be
column2: that military presence was decimated along with the economic benefits it provided.

column1: Kaliningrad is still of great strategic importance to Moscow. It houses the Russian Baltic Fleet at the port of Baltiysk and is the country's only European ice-free port.
Uneven development
The economy has experienced both ups and downs
During the Soviet period
column2: agriculture was a key industry. The market for Kaliningrad's produce was largely dismantled with the collapse of the USSR. The economy nosedived in the early 1990s. Russia provided very little real investment. Unemployment soared and poverty became very widespread
column3: particularly in rural areas. Organised crime and drugs became increasingly problematic. HIV infection rates rose.

column1: In a bid to tackle the region's problems
column2: in 1996 the Russian authorities granted it special economic status and tax advantages intended to attract investors. Although corruption was an early deterrent
column3: the region's economy benefited substantially.

column1: Kaliningrad underwent an unprecedented boom
column2: and in 2007 a new $45m airport terminal was opened.

column1: The European Commission provides funds for business projects under its special programme for Kaliningrad. The region began to see increasing trade with the countries of the EU as well as increasing economic growth and rising industrial output.
However
column2: the global financial crisis of 2008-9 affected the region badly
column3: and by the beginning of 2010 unemployment had climbed to over 10% - considerably higher than the Russian average.

column1: Rumblings of discontent came to a head after a sharp increase in the cost of public transport
column2: and in January an estimated 10
column3: 000 people attended a rally calling for the dismissal of Kaliningrad governor Georgiy Boos
column4: in what was one of the biggest opposition protests in Russia in a decade.

column1: Moscow keeps a wary eye on developments. The Kremlin is particularly sensitive over calls from within the region for a referendum on whether to seek greater autonomy within Russia with a view to strengthening ties with the European Union.

Head of the republic: Kirsan Ilyumzhinov
A Buddhist millionaire businessman with a reputation of eccentricity
column2: Kirsan Ilyumzhinov has ruled Kalmykia virtually unchallenged since 1993.

column1: Kirsan Ilyumzhinov has led Kalmykia since 1993
He was elected president at the age of just over 30 after promising voters $100 each
column2: and pledging to introduce what he called an ""economic dictatorship"" in the republic.

column1: Soon after his election
column2: Mr Ilyumzhinov introduced presidential rule
column3: concentrating power in his own hands. He was re-elected unopposed in 1995 and again in 2002.

column1: In line with new legislation on the appointment of regional leaders
column2: Mr Ilyumzhinov resigned and was re-nominated by Russian President Vladimir Putin in 2005. The Kalmyk parliament endorsed the move.
eyebrows were raised when he claimed in a TV interview that he had been abducted by aliens and taken aboard their spaceship back in 1997.

column1: The comments are thought to have cast a shadow over his efforts to be re-nominated as president in October 2010
column2: when his current term runs out.

column1: Mr Iyumzhinov denies persistent accusations of diverting the republic's resources for his own use as well as of human rights abuses and of suppressing media freedom. When Larisa Yudina
column2: editor of the republic's only opposition newspaper was murdered in 1998
column3: he strenuously rejected allegations of involvement.

column1: In 2004 police dispersed demonstrators who had accused him of human rights violations and demanded his resignation.
Mr Ilyumzhinov acquired his wealth in the economic free-for-all which followed the collapse of the USSR.

He has been president of the International Chess Federation (FIDE) since 1995 and has been enthusiastic about attracting international tournaments to Kalmykia. His flamboyant plans to build an extravagant Chess City in the republic have led to protests by its impoverished citizens.

column1: 293;"Printable version
Regions and territories: Karachay-Cherkessia
The Republic of Karachay-Cherkessia lies in the northwest of Russia's troubled North Caucasus region. To the north and west lie the Russian territories of Stavropol and Krasnodar.
From the lowland steppes of the north
column2: the ground rises to the southern border with Georgia which runs through the Caucasus mountain peaks.

column1: The Karachay and Cherkess are two separate Muslim peoples. The Cherkess are ethnically and culturally related to the Kabarda and Adygey peoples and the Karachay to the Balkars. The republic is also home to Abazin and Nogay minorities. Ethnic tensions flare sporadically.
History
The region was absorbed by an expanding Russian Empire in the first half of the 19th century.
In the 20th
column2: the divide-and-rule tactics of the Stalin era involved weakening resistance by splitting related groups and joining unrelated ones in shared administrative units. As part of this pattern
column3: the Karachay-Cherkessia Autonomous Region was first created in 1922. Several further administrative adjustments and readjustments followed.

column1: In 1943 the Karachay people were deported to Central Asia for alleged collaboration with the Nazis. They were allowed back in 1957 and the Karachay-Cherkess autonomous region recreated.
Although it has not experienced the levels of violence seen elsewhere in the North Caucasus
column2: the republic lives in the shadow of the troubles which have plagued the region. Russian forces have mounted numerous security operations and reported foiling intended attacks by Islamist militants.

column1: Crime
column2: sometimes violent
column3: and corruption further undermine stability. Inter-clan rivalries simmer and occasionally surface in angry outbursts. Poverty is widespread.

column1: Karachay-Cherkessia gained republic status in the early 1990s following the collapse of the Soviet Union. Soviet-era Communist leader Vladimir Khubiyev was re-appointed as president by Boris Yeltsin.
He remained in the post until the republic's first direct presidential elections in 1999 when Vladimir Semenov
column2: a Karachay and former commander of Russian ground forces
column3: defeated the late Stanislav Derev
column4: a Cherkess businessman. The vote was followed by furious protests and allegations of fraud.

column1: Crisis flared again in November 2004 following the brutal killing of seven businessmen in controversial circumstances. The former son-in-law of then President Mustafa Batdyyev was later convicted or organizing the murders.
The republic is keen to develop its tourist industry and winter sports are particularly popular. The highest peak in the Caucasus
column2: Mount Elbrus
column3: lies on the border with Kabardino-Balkaria.

column1: 294;"President: Fatmir Sejdiu (resigned)

Fatmir Sejdiu was elected by parliament in February 2006. The leader of the Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK)

column1: Fatmir Sejdiu stepped down in September 2010
Mr Sejdiu resigned in September 2010
column2: after a court ruling that he had acted unconstitutionally by keeping a party post while in office. The following month
column3: Mr Sejdiu's party pulled out of the governing coalition
column4: in which it was the junior partner to Prime Minister Hashim Thaci's PDK.

column1: Mr Sejdiu was a close ally of the former president
column2: writer-turned-politician Ibrahim Rugova
column3: who died of cancer just days before UN-mediated talks on Kosovo's future status began in February 2006.

column1: Ibrahim Rugova was nicknamed the ""Gandhi of the Balkans"". He led an ethnic Albanian campaign of passive resistance against Serb rule in the 1990s. He was twice elected president in unofficial elections
column2: and won official presidential elections in 2002.

column1: Mr Sejdiu was born near the town of Podujevo in northern Kosovo. He studied law in France and the US and speaks both English and French.
Prime minister: Hashim Thaci
Hashim Thaci is a veteran of the ethnic Albanians' drive to break away from Serbia.
Mr Thaci's minority government fell in November 2010
He began agitating for the Kosovo Albanian cause while still in his teens
column2: and first came to prominence as the political leader of the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA)
column3: the guerrilla group that took up arms against Serb forces in the late 1990s.

column1: He became known outside Kosovo when he formed part of the Kosovo Albanian negotiating team at internationally-sponsored peace talks at Rambouillet
column2: France
column3: early in 1999.

column1: He made such a powerful impression at the talks that he succeeded in sidelining veteran Kosovo Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova - who was more in favour of passive resistance to Serbia - and was appointed leader of the Kosovo Albanian negotiating team.
After the talks broke down and NATO launched its air campaign against Serbia that resulted in Kosovo becoming a UN protectorate
column2: Mr Rugova reasserted his authority within the province and officially became president in 2002.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Mr Thaci underwent a gradual process of transformation from fiery left-wing guerrilla to respectable politician. His Democratic Party of Kosovo (PDK) emerged out of the KLA and finally won an election in November 2007.

column1: Some analysts believe that the years spent by Mr Thaci as prime minister-in-waiting allowed him to hone his political skills and made him into one of the province's most moderate leaders.
On being elected prime minister
column2: he made an attempt to reach out to Kosovo's dwindling Serbian minority by switching to speaking Serbian as he called on the Serbs to consider Kosovo their home.

column1: Mr Thaci's party consolidated its position in local elections in November 2009
column2: in a vote that was seen as a crucial test of the democratic credentials of the Kosovo government.

column1: The governing coaltion collapsed in October 2010 when the junior partner
column2: the Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK)
column3: withdrew.

column1: The following month
column2: parliament passed a vote of no-confidence in Mr Thaci's minority government
column3: and snap elections were set for 12 December.

column1: Hasim Thaci was born in 1968 in the Drenica region
column2: a stronghold of the ethnic Albanian revolt against Serbia.

column1: He was a student activist in 1989-91

column1: He is married

column1: 295;"The ongoing bitter rivalry for control between ethnic Armenians and Azeris has roots dating back well over a century into competition between Christian Armenian and Muslim Turkic and Persian influences.
AT-A-GLANCE
Territory is inside Azerbaijan
column2: but population is mainly ethnic Armenian

column1: War followed 1991 declaration of independence; up to 30
column2: 000 killed
column3: more than one million fled their homes

column1: Relations continued to be strained after 1994 ceasefire; first signs of a thaw appeared in 2008
Populated for hundreds of years by Armenian and Turkic farmers
column2: herdsmen and traders
column3: Karabakh became part of the Russian empire in the 19th century.

column1: Armenia insists that it was part of an early Christian kingdom
column2: citing the presence of ancient churches as evidence. Azeri historians argue that the churches were built by the Caucasian Albanians
column3: a Christian nation whom they regard as among the forebears of the Azeri people.

column1: Islam arrived in the region more than a millennium ago.

For long periods Christian Armenians and Turkic Azeris lived in peace but they were both guilty of acts of brutality in the early 20th century. These live on in the popular memory and fuel mutual antagonism.
There have been many deaths to mourn
The end of World War I and the aftermath of the Bolshevik revolution in Russia brought carving up of borders. As part of their divide-and-rule policy in the area
column2: the Soviets established the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Region
column3: of which the population was predominantly ethnic Armenian
column4: within Azerbaijan in the early 1920s.

column1: Armenian discontent at this situation smouldered throughout the Soviet period. Ethnic Armenian-Azeri frictions exploded into furious violence in the late 1980s in the twilight years of the USSR.
As the violence escalated
column2: the ethnic Azeri population fled Karabakh and Armenia while ethnic Armenians fled the rest of Azerbaijan. With the break-up of the Soviet Union
column3: in late 1991
column4: Karabakh declared itself an independent republic. That de facto status remains unrecognised elsewhere.

column1: Although there was no formal declaration of war
column2: there was large-scale combat between Azerbaijani and ethnic Armenian forces. That fighting ultimately brought victory for the ethnic Armenians who then pushed on to occupy Azerbaijani territory outside Karabakh
column3: creating a buffer zone linking Karabakh and Armenia.

column1: Ceasefire

A Russian-brokered ceasefire was signed in 1994 leaving Karabakh de facto under ethnic Armenian control. The deal also left swathes of Azeri territory around the enclave in Armenian hands. No final settlement has ever been signed. Both sides have had soldiers killed in sporadic breaches of the ceasefire. The closure of borders with Turkey and Azerbaijan has caused landlocked Armenia severe economic problems for nearly 15 years.
The territory's future is unresolved
It is estimated that between 20
column3: 000 people lost their lives during half a decade of conflict
column4: and that more than one million fled their homes. The Azeris have yet to return to areas of Azerbaijan now under ethnic Armenian control and have little prospect of returning to Karabakh itself. Similarly
column5: the Armenians who fled Azerbaijan during the conflict have not returned there.

column1: The ethnic Armenians who now account for virtually the entire population of Nagorno-Karabakh prefer to call it Artsakh
column2: an ancient name dating back around 1
column3: 500 years.

column1: The situation throughout over a decade since the ceasefire agreement has been one of simmering stalemate. Azeris bitterly resent the loss of the land which they regard as rightfully theirs. The Armenians show no sign of willingness to compromise or give one square centimetre of it back.
Russia
column2: France and the US co-chair the OSCE's Minsk Group
column3: which has been attempting to broker an end to the dispute for over a decade.

column1: In 1997 the group tabled settlement proposals seen as a starting point for negotiations by Azerbaijan and Armenia but not by the de facto authorities in Nagorno-Karabakh itself. When the then Armenian president
column2: Levon Ter-Petrosyan
column3: tried to encourage Nagorno-Karabakh to enter into talks he was forced to resign amid cries of betrayal.

column1: Thaw
Azerbaiijan declared illegitimate a referendum held in the region in December 2006. The vote approved a new constitution and referred to Karabakh as a sovereign state. Nonetheless
column2: there have since been signs of life in the peace process
column3: with occasional meetings between the Armenian and Azeri presidents.

column1: These contacts have yet to bear fruit
column2: though Armenia's Serzh Sarkisian and Azerbaijan's Ilham Aliyev agreed in November 2008 to intensify their efforts to find a political settlement. Significant progress was made at talks between the two leaders in May and November 2009
column3: though there are still a number of hurdles to be overcome.

column1: 296;"Media

Russian President Vladimir Putin said the attackers were international terrorists with links to Chechen separatists and funding from al-Qaeda. He accused them of seeking to unleash violence across the North Caucasus in order to strike at Russia's south.
Ousted Chechen separatist president Aslan Maskhadov
column2: who was killed just six months later
column3: condemned the seizure of the school but blamed Russian policy in Chechnya
column4: describing the attackers as ""madmen"" seeking to avenge the Chechen people for atrocities carried out by Russians.

column1: Remembering the victims: The Beslan siege ended in a bloodbath

The only attacker thought to have survived was later sentenced to life imprisonment. Campaigners continue to accuse the Russian authorities of a cover-up and want further investigation into events leading up to and during the siege.
History
Ethnic Ossetians and Russians make up most of the population of North Ossetia. Russian influence in the area increased in the 18th century with the founding of a military outpost at Vladikavkaz.

In the early 1920s the territory was part of the short-lived Soviet Mountain Republic - made up of six districts including Chechnya and Ingushetia. Autonomous status was given to the districts in 1924; in 1936 North Ossetia became an autonomous Soviet republic.
North Ossetia has a history of loyalty to Moscow but this has not exempted it from internal conflict and violence in recent years.
A nail bomb attack on the central market in the capital Vladikavkaz in 1999
column2: which killed 60 people
column3: was blamed on Muslim extremists. Russian military targets in North Ossetia have been attacked on several occasions in recent years with scores of personnel killed.

column1: North Ossetia fought a bloody conflict with its eastern neighbour
column2: the Russian republic of Ingushetia
column3: shortly after the collapse of the Soviet Union.

column1: Ingush forces
column2: in pursuit of a historical claim to Prigorodny district on the right bank of the Terek river
column3: were repelled in 1992 with the support of Moscow. Hundreds died in the fighting
column4: and many ethnic Ingush civilians fled North Ossetia for Ingushetia. A peace agreement has yet to be reached.

column1: The North Ossetian and Ingush sides have made conflicting claims about the extent of the return of Ingush refugees to North Ossetia.
Ossetians divided
War broke out in the South Ossetia region of Georgia
column2: just over the border from North Ossetia
column3: in August 2008. Russian forces drove Georgian troops out of the region
column4: which declared independence from Georgia in 1991 and has been run by a secessionist government ever since.

column1: Thousands of South Ossetians fled to the North in the 1990s amid the violence that followed the declaration of independence. North Ossetia maintains strong ethnic links with the territory.

Rich in resources - including unexploited oil and gas reserves - North Ossetia is the most industrialised and urbanised republic in the North Caucasus. It also has tourism potential; plans for a ski resort were announced in 2003.

column1: In August 2008

column1: History
The Ossetians are believed to be descended from tribes which migrated into the area from Asia many hundreds of years ago and settled in what is now North Ossetia.
As the Russian empire expanded into the area in the 18th and 19th centuries
column2: the Ossetians did not join other peoples of the North Caucasus in putting up fierce resistance.

column1: By tradition
column2: the Ossetians have had good relations with Russians and were regarded as loyal citizens
column3: first of the Russian empire and later of the Soviet Union.

column1: They sided with the Kremlin when Bolshevik forces occupied Georgia in the early 1920s and
column2: as part of the carve-up which followed
column3: the South Ossetian Autonomous Region was created in Georgia and North Ossetia was formed in Russia.

column1: Violence flares
In the twilight of the Soviet Union
column2: as Georgian nationalist Zviad Gamsakhurdia came to prominence in Tbilisi
column3: separatist sentiment burgeoned in South Ossetian.

column1: Russian troops were welcomed as liberators in the 2008 conflict
After several outbreaks violence between Georgians and Ossetians
column2: the region declared its intention to secede from Georgia in 1990 and
column3: the following year
column4: effective independence.

column1: The collapse of the USSR and Georgian independence in 1991 only strengthened South Ossetia's determination to break with Tbilisi.
Sporadic violence involving Georgian irregular forces and Ossetian fighters continued until the summer of 1992 when agreement on the deployment of Georgian
column2: Ossetian and Russian peacekeepers was reached.

column1: Political stalemate followed. Separatist voices became less strident during President Shevardnadze's rule in Georgia
column2: but the issues returned to the foreground when Mikhail Saakashvili replaced him as president.

column1: Making clear his intention to bring the breakaway regions to heel
column2: Mr Saakashvili offered South Ossetia dialogue and autonomy within a single Georgian state

column1: But his offer fell far short of separatist demands
column2: and in 2006 South Ossetians overwhelmingly voted to restate their demand for independence in an unrecognised referendum.

column1: Tensions came to head in early August 2008
column2: when
column3: after nearly a week of clashes between Georgian troops and separatist forces
column4: Georgia launched an devastating air and ground assault attack on South Ossetia
column5: briefly gaining control of Tskhinvali.

column1: Georgian forces fire a rocket during the brief war with Russia in 2008
Declaring its citizens - most South Ossetians had Russian passports - to be under under attack
column2: Russia sent in its troops and launched air attacks on the Georgian troops.

column1: Within days
column2: Russian forces had swept the Georgians out of both South Ossetia and Abkhazia
column3: and then proceeded to occupy parts of Georgia
column4: causing panic in Tbilisi.

column1: Recognition
Following Western protests
column2: Russia pulled its forces back towards South Ossetia and Abkhazia under a cease-fire agreement
column3: but days later proceeded to formally recognise both South Ossetia and Abkhazia.

column1: In April 2009
column2: Russia bolstered its position in South Ossetia by signing a five-year agreement to take formal control of its frontiers with Georgia proper
column3: as well as those of Abkhazia.

column1: AT-A-GLANCE
Territory broke away from Moldova after a bloody conflict
A majority of the population are Russian speakers
Russian troops are stationed in Trans-Dniester
In the post World War II carve-up of the region
column2: Moscow created Moldova's forerunner
column3: the Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic
column4: from two disparate elements: the mainly Russian-speaking Dniester region
column5: formerly an autonomous part of Ukraine
column6: and the neighbouring region of Bessarabia
column7: which had been part of Romania from 1918-1940.

column1: But in the Soviet Union's dying days
column2: alarm grew in the Dniester region over growing Moldovan nationalism and the possible reunification of Moldova with Romania. A 1989 law which made Moldovan an official language added to the tension
column3: and Trans-Dniester proclaimed its secession in September 1990.

column1: The breakaway territory's paramilitary forces took over Moldovan public institutions in the area in 1991. Fighting intensified
column2: culminating in a battle on the right bank of the Dniester in June 1992. Up to 700 people were killed in the conflict.

column1: A ceasefire was signed in July 1992
column2: and a 10-km demilitarised security zone was established. The settlement was enforced by the Russian 14th Army forces already stationed in Trans-Dniester.

column1: Russian presence

The ongoing presence of Russian troops has been a stumbling block in peace talks and the West is concerned about the Soviet-era arsenal in the territory. A pull-out began in 2001 but was halted when Trans-Dniester blocked the dispatch of weapons. Subsequent agreements to resume failed to reach fruition.
Long-running talks supervised by the OSCE
column2: Russia and Ukraine have yet to yield a political solution. Attempts by Moldova to exert economic pressure on the Dniester authorities have failed to produce the desired result.

column1: Soviet symbols live on in Trans-Dniester
In 2004 a Russian-brokered plan
column2: which would have made the presence of Russian troops permanent
column3: sparked mass protests in Moldova and was shelved. Ukraine has since come up with settlement proposals but these too have stalled.

column1: There are disputes over language issues. Though dominated by Russian-speakers
column2: around 40% of the population in Trans-Dniester have Moldovan - which is virtually identical to Romanian - as a first language.

column1: In 2004 the Trans-Dniester authorities forced some schools to close
column2: ostensibly for using the Latin alphabet to teach Moldovan. The dispute sparked tit-for-tat measures
column3: including economic sanctions and a rail blockade.

column1: Trans-Dniester contains most of Moldova's industrial infrastructure
column2: but its economic potential is limited by its international isolation. It has its own currency
column3: constitution
column4: parliament
column5: flag and anthem. One of the last bastions of Soviet-style rhetoric
column6: the territory has nonethless privatised some of its industrial enterprises.

column1: The region is plagued by corruption
column2: organised crime and smuggling. It has been accused of conducting illegal arms sales and of money laundering. Poverty is widespread.
